description:
Hon's does one thing, and does it very well: wun tun soup! I get my mine with bbq pork and DELICIOUS hand-pulled egg noodle. 

Broth, wun tuns, noodles all prepared right in front of house, an old formica diner counter. Priceless.
author: Todd B.

description:
SERVICE:
Friendly, straightforward, and quick. My takeout order was ready w/in 5 mins. 

FOOD:
1) Wonton Noodle Soup: Good wontons, but the soup was just decent and the egg noodles were bland.

2) Rice Rolls: These were delightfully chewy and bouncy. I recommend getting this w/ the hot sauce and sweet peanut sauce! 

RECOMMEND? For rice rolls, yes
Ehh, I've had better wonton noodle soups.
author: Jenny L.

description:
Nostalgia doesn't have a price...the last time I was here was in 2000, I was so happy to see and taste the ngow jaap with the fat noodles, it tasted the way I remembered and even the little lady was still here. The fatter noodles have a better texture for me, but stick with the regular thin noodles if you prefer softer.

Flavor was savory and so unique to this place, I haven't been able to find it anywhere else. My daughter had the wun tuns and she loved the broth.

Service is prompt but not the warmest, then again, this place has been around longer than I worked in SF. I can't wait for my next visit.
author: V K.

description: Seems to be a family operation. Father has limited English fluency, but daughter can translate. Small and quaint, very clean. Food is quite tasty and cost competitive. Cash only. The overall price is the printed price plus tax.
author: Kimberly H.

description: Amidst all the changes in San Francisco, it's good to know that places like Hon's continue to persevere.  An old-school Chinatown noodle soup joint; nothing fancy, but a solid bowl of Cantonese-style noodle soup, with thin egg noodles and plump won tons, served quickly and efficiently.  You could eat much fancier meals in San Francisco, but better meals?  I don't think so.
author: Richard P.

description: WONTONS ARE SOOOO YUMMY. the flavors just spilled into my mouth once I bit into it. The broth is also very flavorful!
author: Janet T.

description:
Late afternoon yesterday I checked into the Hilton Financial District.  I had not had lunch yet.  Hon's was really close to my hotel.  It was a tad chilly and a good noodle soup is what I was dreaming of.

Walked to the counter and ordered a quart size won-ton w/beef, pork, noodles.  It came out in seconds.  However, the soup was awful.  The broth had no flavor.  The noodles looked like the vermicelli I buy in Ralph's.  Beef? Pork?  Could not find any in the soup.  The soup was heavy on the noodles vs. protein.

I ate about 1/3 of the soup and left.  Yeah, it was only $7; however, what I was served was a complete waste of money.  Cash only.

Will I return?  No way.  San Francisco is a town known for world class Chinese food.  What I was served is inexcusable.
author: Jay A.

description:
Today was my first visit to Hon's and I went during the lunch rush. I had to wait around seven minutes before I was able to grab a seat at the bar area. After getting a seat the service was very very quick. I sat down was given some hot tea and then placed my order and within five minutes I had my bowl of bbq pork and wonton noodle soup.

The broth was  so-so to be honest but the wontons and the bbq pork was fantastic. The wontons are pork and shrimp and very flavorful. The bbq pork was melt in your mouth yum and the noodles were a great addition. The soup hit the spot on this chilly day. I would definitely go back for another bowl.
author: Stephanie A.

description: Decent little won ton and noodle place. Quick/easy service at the counter. It sells all kinds of raw won ton making ingredients in bulk - pretty cool.
author: Jimmy S.

description: My favorite for 30 years!!  I live in the central valley. We always choose wuntun house when we visit chinatown.
author: Sylvia L.

description:
It's been a few months since I went back to this place and it surely went down the drain.  The noodles aren't the same as before.  It lacked firmness and the texture isn't good.  A party of 3 went, and 2 of us got sick after eating the veggies.  The lady who took my order and act as the cashier had visible snot rolling down her nose and not a care in the world. 
 Doubt I'll be coming back to this place for a long time.
author: Henry T.

description: Very bad service after change ownership, wait long time for food, they give my food to other table two times. Finally give a wrong order to me. Not suggesting come in lunch time.
author: Li G.

description: Small grimy place that serves up good food. I got the pork Shanghai noodles which was very tasty.
author: Sunil R.

description: First time trying out this place. The Beef Brisket Wonton Noodle Soup tastes amazing. The nostalgia traditional Hong Kong style wonton noodle soup is perfect for the chill weather in SF. Portion is more than enough for one person and at great price that you cannot find anywhere else in SF Financial District. Friendly staffs and quick service. Will definitely come again!
author: S W.

description:
The curry beef rice at Hon's Wun Tun House is untouchable! So good and it's always fresh. This place is as traditional as it gets and I hope it stays this way for a long, long time.

The wun tun noodles are also really good, but I don't these as often as the curry beef rice. This place is super affordable, something you don't see too often in gentrified San Francisco.
author: Nicholas H.

description:
Hello comfort food, it's been a while. Most days, I'm a sushi person, but some days, I just need some comfort soups. Good thing this spot is around the corner.

I picked up a rice roll, beef curry, and 24 wontons. The soup is spot on, nothing avant-garde, but exactly how won ton soup should taste. Exactly. The won tons were falling apart a little bit and they could've used a bit more filling, but the texture and taste was again, spot on. The beef curry was more meat than chewiness, but that's definitely a personal preference and the portions on this were huge-- could easily feed 2.5 people, even 4 if you had rice to accompany it. The rice rolls were a little more lacking-- generally, restaurant rice rolls have shrimp, green onion, and sesame, so these were a little plain. They were definitely fresh and soft to the touch, so they had that going for them. It's a solid spot for Cantonese comfort food and reminded me of being in Hong Kong. The interior of the shop was also pretty clean by Chinese restaurant standards, so that's always a huge plus. 3.5 stars.
author: Nicole H.

description:
Although I love the hardworking staff here, the food here can only be described as mediocre.  The thing is the restaurant is named after the dish so it needs to be outstanding but sadly there are places that are far better.  

Food 2.5
Service 4
Overall 3
author: Patrick C.

description: Had the shrimp and pork noodle wonton soup thinking wonton was in their name so it must be good. Welp I was wrong. The soup was bland, tiny wontons barely had any meat, total waste of money and time. They don't take credit cards (no signage telling you that at all or on the menu which took me by surprise); I had to walk to an ATM that the old lady directed me to. ‍ This place is on the edge of Chinatown, I went from my Hilton Hotel next door thinking it was quick and easy...ended up being quick and gross.  Should have walked two blocks in a different direction into Chinatown. Travelers beware!
author: John C.

description: Hon's Wun Tun House has been around for many years. I always come to this restaurant whenever I'm craving for a wun tun meen (wontons noodle soup). Their wontons are good portioned and the pricing here is super affordable compared to other places in SF. I would say that many people say that their service is not great and that they are rude is because of language barrier. They are not rude at all, they just can't speak fluently. It is a family owned restaurant so don't expect too much other than authentic wontons soup. The restaurant closes early so if you are craving, be sure to come earlier to get your fix. I also heard from the restaurant owner that they will be retiring soon :( so come try their wontons out asap! Street parking is a pain but you can always park in the Chinatown parking lot for safety reasons.
author: Sammi L.

description:
One thing I notice on the menu that another reviewer mentioned is the way they spelled wontons as wuntuns. 

The menu is very simple and not too long everything has rice, noodle or wontuns depends what your craving. It's a great place to come for a quick lunch. I recommend coming before 1 because usually it's packed since all the people that work around the area coming to Kearny street for lunch.

Heads up, there is different people in charge of different areas of the restaurant. Like 1 in charge of cooking, 1 in charge of stocking ingredient, 1 for serving and 1 for payments and charges. I accidentally asked the lady to order and she said I have to wait for the other guy to take our order. I guess this is how they are organized.

Now for the food, we ordered #10 beef stew wonton noodle soup. The portions are small, I remember coming here long time ago and they served so much more than now. Wontons were good and so were the noodles and beef. One thing to notice is that the noodles are not hand pulling but they are still better than ramen.

Overall, it was a nice, quick lunch meal experience. $7.20 for a wonton noodle soup not bad I guess in San Francisco fidi district. No tax FYI.
author: Christopher G.

description:
It was a bitterly cold, gray and wet day, and I was trapped in the Financial District, fighting off the earliest symptoms of an oncoming cold.  The end of the Women's March had coincided with the end of my shift at a local coffee shop, and public transportation was backed-up and over-flowing with thousands of fired-up demonstrators and their over-sized poster boards.  There was no point in trying to go home, so instead I took to the streets in search of some warm broth and noodles to soothe my body, spirit and soul.

As I wondered the concrete corridors of downtown San Francisco in search of an open (and not crowded) dispenser of pho, ramen, or really any hot, broth-based delectable, I finally stumbled upon Hon's Wun Tun House on Kearny.  I shuffled in from the cold, admiring the cheap somewhat retro lay-out of the establishment, and I took a seat at the bar.

While the digs were delightful in their simplicity, what was not altogether enjoyable - and actually rather quite distressing - was the musky and pervasive scent of wet dog that filled the restaurant and my nostrils.  There was no escaping this vile odor.  But since my craving for soup was great and my alternatives few, I simply accepted the unique smell of the House and breathed through my mouth.

The menu was pretty easy to figure out and featured a range of delicious standards that piqued my appetite and interest.  Moreover, the prices were remarkably reasonable by any standard, but especially considering the House's location!

An elderly woman took my order and I waited patiently with clenched nostrils for my order of Stewed Brisket of Beef with Noodle soup ($5.05).  After about 10 minutes it arrived, served in a white plastic bowl.  The soup was exactly what I had asked for: steaming beef broth, tasty strips of brisket among plentiful noodles.  The portion was satisfying, neither overly large nor under-ly small, and certainly a good deal for the price!  

I scarfed down my soup and felt my budding cold retreat from the nourishing and warming assault of beef, broth and noodle.  I paid and left, stomach satisfied and olfactory senses relieved to be outside once more.  

In truth, I found my experience at Hon's mostly exceptional.  However, I cannot ignore the fact that the smell on that particular day was absolutely overpoweringly awful, and this definitely put a negative spin on the entire experience.  However, the food and prices were great, and if you can get behind cheap couture, then you might even actually like the ambiance like I did.  

I have since begun a new job in the Transamerica Pyramid just around the corner from Hon's, and I fully intend to revisit and get a second impression of this place.  I have a feeling that the smell may have just been a fluke, and by no means reflects the typical atmosphere of the House.  If this is the case, then Hon's is actually a hidden diamond in the FiDi for all your noodle and wun tun needs!
author: Max T.

description: We were craving won ton soup and dropped into this little place.  I ordered the dumplings with pork and shrimp.  My husband had brisket, noodles, and won tons.  Won tons are made of the same meat inside but are half the size.  His brisket was more like gristle or tendon.  The broth had a hint of anise.  My broth was thin with a few scallions floating around.  My bowl of soup cost $6.50 and can't complain about that.  But, I would have wanted some veggies, heartier broth.  I make a better won ton soup at home.  The staff was cordial.
author: Liza H.

description: Beef tasted great. Rice noodles and soup weren't fresh. Waitress poured soup over rice noodles that were probably sitting out for quite some time, as they weren't as soft as they could have been. Portion was also small... you made need to order two.
author: Lucy T.

description: Must go and try! I have been looking for traditional Cantonese noodle in San Francisco for a long time! Finally, I found the best traditional noodle soup in San Francisco Chinatown! Tasty soup and tender noodle with delicious beef stew, yum yum!!!
author: Yeqi Z.

description: I had a wonton beef noodle soup with extra beef tendon. It was cheap, food wasn't great. The lady who served me good was nice.
author: Helen L.

description: Small portions. Small wontons. Smallest beef cubes ever. Taste comes from tons of msg. Dirty glasses. I wanted to like this place but oh well. Cash only.
author: Jennifer M.

description: Had pig's feet for the first time ever. It was an enjoyable dish with a small but flavorful serving of pig's feet over cabbage and a generous portion of white rice for 7.80. I came on Christmas at around 3 pm, and was surprised how busy it was. Not too many tables or space, so it feels crowded and isn't the nicest ambience, but the food is definitely worth the trip. I was also into the warm complimentary cup of tea -- yum. Cash only!
author: Angel T.

description:
There's something nostalgic about the place. It has a certain old school charm that I love. While the city has changed so much over time, it seems like this place has stayed original. 

It's a quick easy meal of fresh wonton soup. No frills. There's the option of getting it with noodles, some stew on the side, some veggies on the side. I add the oily chili sauce to my wonton and it's awesome. 

They do have rice dishes available, and some rice rolls as appetizers - nothing too special looking but that doesn't make it less delicious.
author: Veronica L.

description:
The wonton noodle soup comes with bite sized dumplings and authentic soup and noodles. The environment was pretty typical of old street shops in Hong Kong. 

I've been here 4 times in a couple of weeks. It's basically your humble Hong Kong street shop where you go for that one speciality dish instead of expecting great customer service and a flashy atmosphere. The 老板娘 never made eye contact with me or responded to my Cantonese. But today when a couple of 鬼佬 sat near me, she immediately became this upbeat and outgoing person in front of them. Not sure if I'm overthinking it. 

Almost $10 for a bowl, which is pretty affordable for the Financial District. Everything is ready to eat within 2 mins after ordering. I just come for the quick wonton noodle soup during lunch break.
author: Natalie P.

description: It's a small place where you can eat easily a soup. Not bad and better. Noodles are very fresh and good. Broth is not really tasty but for having something warm it's a place to know close to Northbeach.
author: Marie-Claire L.

description:
Great traditional noodle house that really only serves noodle soup and wontons.  They have a few other items, but the beef broth here for the soup is pretty awesome. I highly recommend trying it out. The noodles are home made and thin.  The pork and beef they put in the soup is really good.

I came here with the wife, got the brisket with extra dumplings and wontons and loved it.
author: Robert G.

description: Great food and great staff. Tons of people come and just order their noodles to go since they are made in house and authentic. They know me as a regular. I would travel far and wide and this is the only place I eat Won Ton Noodle Soup in the San Francisco Bay Area. I order the Won Ton Noodle Soup with extra Won Tons and Scallions. Free top offs and broth refills upon request. Well... @ least for me.
author: Dookie B.

description:
baby, baby! I found a great noodle house!

this is a family owned and operated hole in the wall restaurant that sits right between Financial District and Chinatown.
outside of the hustle and bustle of the Chinatown and the wandering tourists.
very cheap, very tasty, and the people are friendly.
I don't mind to come back here and trying different dishes.
author: Rudy H.

description: Ate lunch here again. Basic economy lunch. Best to walk there. Basically an eat and run place. Cooking in boiling pots of water in window. Looks like cash only, low overhead.
author: Clifford W.

description: This place needs a little bump up in ratings IMO. Hon's serves up a light, but tasty broth with thin, springy noodles and delicious wun tun's or other toppings at a reasonable price. If you're alone, you can pop in, crush a bowl at the counter, and be on your way for only $7 most of the time. Given the current crisis of most ramen houses serving subpar tonkatsu soup at high prices, I'd suggest Hon's first to anyone wanting a good, light, cheap noodle soup for lunch in the FiDi/Chinatown area. Nothing beats it on a foggy day.
author: Joe L.

description:
I got the spicy tendon with beef brisket noodle soup and added wontons.  Oh my it was good.  Deep beef flavor, tender beef parts, toothsome tendon.  The noodles were a bit of a mess so I might do without those next time.  The wontons were good but a bit small.  If they could be a bit bigger, it would make this the perfect dish.  

It's cash only.  And people eat quickly, diner style.  There is no ambiance.  But that's why the average entree here is around $8.  $5 if you go the basic noodle soup option.
author: Christina C.

description:
I had this place bookmarked because I just wanted to see how SF served their wonton noodle soup.  It wasn't bad though it was sorta a small bowl but I shouldn't be greedy.  

I didn't have to wait long as I sat at the bar stool seats by the counter area.  There were a few tables around, I would say maybe 8 or 9 tables.  The place is small.  

Service was quick as my bowl of soup came out shortly after I had ordered it, although, what I had ordered was a simple dish.  As I was enjoying my soup, the guy next to me ordered something that looked and smelled really good.  I wanted to ask him but dammit, I'm too shy...I should've asked him...coulda, woulda, shoulda...ah well... ¯\_(ツ)_/¯
author: Ming T.

description:
Hon's is one of two "traditional noodle house" in Chinatown that I've been to. This one is on the outskirts of Chinatown while Yin Du is just a couple of blocks away. Hon's is almost as traditional as it get. What's missing is the stinking open trash can on the pavement that welcomes you as you enter.  Rest of the playbook is similar to Yin Du. You will be hit with a strong smell that clears your sinuses and opens up your nostrils in one shot. If you have not already fainted, you will proceed to be ignored by the sole cook cum server cum cashier. When you finally get his attention you will get your wonton noodle soup with extra noodles to-go all for a princely sum of $5.80 + $1 for extra noodles. Again you have to undergo the torture of sitting at the sticky counter. What goes through your mind is how many people have enjoyed their soup here since this was properly wiped down? You look around and wonder how can these people actually dine-in? Are they immune to the stench? Does the problem lie with you?

Before you have an answer to all these perplexing questions you are on your way with your order in hand. As expected noodles and broth are in the same container, so you wolf them down as soon as you reach home so as not to have to eat mushy noodles. You realize that this is average. Noodles are cheap, broth is a little salty, wontons are fine nothing special and that you have to throw in your lot with all the others and dine-in; so that is what you do the next couple of times, till you realize that you have been coming here more often that Yin Du, even though both are practically the same. It's time for another rotation.
author: Ahmad J.

description:
3.5 stars. Location is small, service is fast, and be prepared to share tables. They rush you out and I think it is cash only.

Bowl of hot won tun noodle soup on a cold day just hits the spot. Pretty small portion.
author: Karen H.

description: Love this place! I've frequented this spot a lot when I used to work at the financial district. Had the Wun-tun noodle soup with shrimp and pork and their curry beef with rice. It's like old times! It's not the fanciest or cleanest place around but they make a damn good soup!
author: Stacey H.

description: Can't get much more classic Chinatown than this place. Quick, cheap, delicious wun-tun noodle soups. You can ask for different noodles. If you're very hungry, it's unlikely that the wun tun nooble soup will fill you until dinner time though. Still, delicious, warm, soupy goodness.
author: David J.

description: This place used to be delicious and inexpensive. I went out of my way to come here. I hadn't been in awhile and wanted to share the experience with my husband. When I mentioned that I was planning on going to my hairdresser, he said DON'T! They got greedy. They raised the prices and skimp on the portions.... and he was right. How disappointing.
author: Betty V.

description:
OK here's the good news you can see them cooking right there in the front of the restaurant. It's got a very authentic feel; almost like you were at some restaurant in China. A lot of Chinese people eat here which speaks highly of their cuisine. This is definetly not a tourist place. No bar which keeps your meal of cheap if you're bringing a date. And good wholesome noodles. Some guy was ranting and raving about the wontons which I don't know I don't even know if I want to say whether it's good or bad. The old lady waitress is kind of interesting because she has the shakes and when she brings your soup it's kind of exciting and scary at the same time. And she's incredibly impatient and a cool sort of way Kind a like she's egging you on to get this order done.  It's kind a like that Seinfeld episode where Jerry goes to get the soup i'm halfway expecting her to scream no soup for you!   
I'm giving it five stars because it is what it is and if you come in expecting this type restaurant you will be pleasantly surprised.   Come in and enjoy the rude ... it funny as all getup. DONT Even think about using a credit card here these guys haven't paid taxes since 1964
author: Jesse P.

description:
This is my second time to this place and I wasn't impressed the first time, the soup I taste was bland.
And the second time, my friend brought me here and he suggested me to put their Chili oil in the soup and BOOM   their chili oil's the bomb!please try them out !It really matches the soup!
I was extremely picky about Wontons tho, I've taste better wonton in China but overall this is the best wonton so far in US.
author: Emily H.

description:
You know it's going to be authentic when a restaurant chooses a non traditional spelling of its main dish and openly flaunts that as part of its name. It's wun tun to them folks, not won ton.

This is a hole-in-the-wall Chinatown establishment that serves the Chinese equivalent of chicken noodle soup. As expected, you don't come here for the ambience.

Pro tip: The eating space is tiny unless they seat upstairs, but if you're ok with sharing space at the bar that might shorten the wait time.

Service is mixed. The lady seating people and handling the cash register was less helpful and friendly overall than the man who actually took our order and waited on us. He gave us our complimentary hot tea. He also noticed me sharing my broth because the SO did not get enough, and immediately brought us more broth.

Apparently these won tons are hand made by one employee...the one working mad crazy up by the front window.

We each ordered the regular wonton soup. It came with thin yellow noodles that were definitely NOT hand made. The broth was good, but better after I added more soy sauce. The wontons were well flavored. In all, a filling, delicious meal for under 7 bucks. I wish the noodles were fresher though.
author: Sue V.

description: Too much msg. Food and noodles quite bland. The place smells bad. Why did I go in and still eat? On a rainy day it looked inviting and authentic especially after reading some of the reviews here. The wontuns have an interesting flavor. But not worth the msg reactions at all.
author: Bharath H.

description:
My father has taken me here since I was a child. It is definitely old school- old appliances and whatnot, but that doesn't matter to me since the food is always great. I enjoy the fishball wonton noodle soup doused in their chili sauce. They also have a stewed tripe with tendon and it's a great dish if you love tripe. 

When you order to go, they give big portions that are sure to fill you up. Although,I believe the to go portions are a bit bigger than when you sit in.

If you love noodles and soup as much as I do, I recommend going to this restaurant! But cleanliness and great service isn't their thing here. It's a husband and wife running this place for years and the husband has been ESPECIALLY short with me. He has yelled at me for him misunderstanding my to go order. My father has also told me a story when he took his friend to eat here before and he received his dish with a cockroach in it... 

I haven't experienced anything of that nature so I'll still be going to get my wonton fix.
author: Nina I.

description:
When I was little, my best friends mom use to make home made won tons in her small dark kitchen in her tiny little apartment.  When I went over, it was mandatory for me to eat 3 bowls of her slippery pork filled won tons with home made soup broth.  It was one of the best bowls of won ton's a little kid can ever eat!

Coming into this place brings me back to my days as a little girl.  They had the same slippery won tons, which made my inner bones warm up from the chilly days of San Francisco... The service is super speedy!  They just boil those bad boys and they are practically instantly done!  I'll be sure to make this one of my go-to spots for delicious home made won tons...
author: Jenny T.

description: This place is really so good. I wasn't really looking forward to go, but my mom kept insisting this place was the best. So I gave in and tried it. I was a bit disappointed because I can't eat the wontons since I do not eat pork but then I found they had a beef brisket and beef tendon noodle soup. IT WAS LITERALLY SO GOOD. I loved it! The tendon was so extremely soft and the beef was simply cooked to perfection. The food was even brought out so fast. Less than ten minutes and I went twice on Saturday night and Monday night. The place isn't busy so at first it may seem like it's not so great but the food is really good. Maybe that's just me, but at the very least you should try this place. You might just love it! Also it's kinda weird that the bathroom is all the way downstairs and that you have to walk through the kitchen but tbh I work at a chinese resturant and the fact that they let you walk through shows that they are clean even in the kitchen. Of course it should be but a lot of places just aren't. Anyways definitely will come back when I get the chance.
author: Sarah E.

description:
I was looking for a place to have an early lunch on a Saturday in downtown SF near my hotel and found this place as I was walking by.  I was hungry and didn't really felt like walking much further so I decided to give this place a try even though it was showing 3.5 Yelp stars... I was expecting it to be average going in but I was wrong. 

Food: Had a won ton noodle soup and a BBQ pork rice dish.  Won ton itself was mediocre, but the noodle was horrible.  The BBQ pork rice dish was also not memorable... flavor was ok, but I've had way better BBQ pork at other Chinese Fast Food places.
Service: Looks like it is a small family owned restaurant and it shows.
Establishment: Small and dirty.  Our table was dirty when we sat down and when the waitress came to "clean" the table so only wiped about 30% of the actual table.
Other: There is a microwave in the kitchen area which is in plain view.  They were not shy using it either to warm up food... no-no for me.

Not I place I would ever go into again if I had a choice.
author: Brian H.

description:
I love hole in the walls. The SO walked by this place on his way to work and told me that he knew this place was destined for greatness by the way the noodle strainers were laid out -- it just looked like home. After being foiled twice when we tried to go (they're not open on Sundays oops), we finally made it in for Monday lunch.

It's a fairly simple menu with a variety of different noodles dishes. You can also get Hon's signature rice noodle rolls, tea eggs, fish balls, etc. Not a ton of variety of appetizers, but let's face it, you were here for the noodles.

SO got the classic number one -- egg noodles with won tons while I, as per usual, was tempted away by the Shanghainese style noodle soup -- pickled cabbage and shredded pork which doesn't sound appealing but is actually quite good and just reminds me of home. 

Food came out in probably less than 3 minutes which was fantastic. The number 1 was so good. Egg noodles were delicious, won tons were amazing -- it was just such a simple, yet perfectly executed dish. Even my Shanghainese noodle soup, which is not what you should be getting at a Cantonese restaurant was pretty spot on. I'm a happy kid.

We also got an order of three tea eggs which were delicious and super authentic as well.

Final price was probably less than $15 even after tip and tax. I will say that it's probably easier to come into this place with a Chinese speaker as it is with most Chinatown establishments. 

tldr; really good noodles served really quickly at a great price. Wonderful place to grab a quick, delicious, filling meal.
author: Jasmine X.

description: Love this place! No frills authentic Wonton Soup dine in, with quick and friendly service! It's cash only though, and it's neighbor has an ATM machine if you forgot to bring some.
author: Ha N.

description:
I have traveled extensively in China, and this place has the  authenticity of a Guangdong day to day street place. In any other city outside of China, I would give five stars for the food,four for the service,2 for ambience. However, in San Francisco, there are better places to eat, with broader menus.  
I still love and recommend Hons. For 10 bucks, there aren't many places you can do better, anywhere, and no, I am not sharing the places I would give five stars, they're too crowded already. Go here. The soup is really wonderful, and having worked in the FD for seventeen years. I assure you, for them to have survived as long as they have they have to be good. As for why there are so many four star reviews, San Francisco is a tough market. Also San Franciscans are spoiled.
author: Martin B.

description: This place made me feel like Anthony Bordain! But in a bad way! It was off the beaten path, Probably had a C- grade, and had all the grime that you'd think were the makings of a delicious mom and pop bowl of yum! Without the yummy! I ordered the #1. Wonton Noodle Soup! The noodles were too hard and starchy, and the broth lacked any real flavor! My two stars are for the Wontons which were okay! If you must venture into this spot go for Wonton soup only! Oh and skip the glass of Hot tea all together! It reminded me of the dirty water that Mama Fratelli served up on The Goonies Movie! Yuk lol!
author: Keesha F.

description: First things first, do NOT be fooled by this places low prices. Although the menu will state one price, they will charge a greater price. Secondly if you do go, I would not recommend any of the noodle soups that include won ton or beef. The meat in my the won ton is non-existent. Literally one of my won tons was just the wrapper! The beef is also dry, I don't know how that's possible in a SOUP, but come to this place if you want to experience that. Overall not impressed with this place. Would not recommend if you are looking for a traditional HK noodle don't come here.
author: Jason T.

description:
Came here as I had a sudden urge for Wonton noodle soup/Wan tan Mee.  It's the first thing on the menu.  The portion was typical for this noodle soup.  Honestly, I've had the same dish/bowl in SE Asia, as well as multiple places in Hong Kong.  The noodles were fine, but if you like a more basic tasting noodle, it does not have that type of flavor.  The wontons were good, and the soup was fine.  All in all the bowl was satisfying, and I would probably get it again, but I had better in Hong Kong (although honestly, I wasn't in Hong Kong, and it's a lot farther to fly there then to just come to this restaurant).

The place itself is nothing to write home about.  It's a small somewhat typical "diner" like Chinatown restaurant.  It's right near the park and parking garage in Chinatown.  There are a bunch of tables for 4 people, and one table that maybe seats 5 or 6 in the place, along with counter service.  The guy who makes noodle soup is doing so right up front at the window of the restaurant.  I did not see anyone pulling or making noodles on site.  Prices were inexpensive.  The tea came from a large dispenser like many similar Chinese restaurants, and served in a small glass.
author: B L.

description:
Can I get a #23 please? Ordering here is quick and simple! Cute little Chinatown hole in the wall restaurant. 

Taste-
Noodles: You have two different types of noodles to choose from. There's the regular egg noodles which are super skinny and thin and then there's the rice noodles which are the flat and wide white noodles. I prefer the rice noodles just because they're soft and pliable in comparison to the egg noodles which are a little more al dente but that's just the normal texture of the noodles. 

Dumplings/Wonton: The wontons come in cute little bite size pieces that I would say have more noodle than meat. The dumplings are 2/3 times the size of the wontons. Basically they're pretty much the same, same meat and shrimp filling inside of a noodle wrapper, it's just the dumplings are larger in size. They also have vinegar, soy sauce, and chili oil for you to make a dipping sauce for your wontons or dumplings! 

Service-
Typical Chinese style restaurant. Quick to have you order and quick to deliver you your food! 

Restaurant Atmosphere-
The tables are open for anyone, aka community tables! If you're a small party sitting at a larger table, others will probably sit down and enjoy their meal with you! 

This place isn't amazing, but it's a good meal for the price. Only thing is that their bowl is a little small so if you come in hungry it may not be enough for you. They don't have different sizing options but you can always get extra noodles or more wontons/dumplings! Would recommend!
author: Tori W.

description: Even their waitress was not too friendly but i would say that here is one of the resto where serve an authentic Cantonese wonton noodle soup and other Cantonese dishes.
author: Tiratiwan L.

description: I came here for wonton noodle soup and it hit the spot. It was simple, home-made and delicious. Very friendly family feeling environment.
author: Darius L.

description:
I'd been walking down Kearny Street and all of the sudden I get this whiff in my noise that transports me back almost decade: to the time when I first visited San Francisco. I'd been staying at a hostel right around the corner of this place and I would come here for a cheap dinner...wonton soup, of course!

So, as I was walking down Kearny, I was actually on my way to a networking function at a nearby hotel. When I arrived at the hotel and I saw the bland food that the buffet offered, I suddenly faced the following dilemma: should I spend the next hour sitting through a boring presentation and making small talk with complete strangers or should I go to Hon's Wun-Tun House and eat a dinner, reminiscing about the good old times?

I'm not gonna tell you how the story ends, but I can tell you that much: Hon is still making the soup himself!
author: Uli B.

description:
So I've eaten here when I was living in Chinatown eons ago! I just revisited this place and everything tastes the same. :) Talking about consistency!

I had the wonton noodle soup with wide egg noodles. It was a to go order and was a little less than $7. For to go orders: go to the cash register and let them know what you want for to-go. You'll get it pretty quickly (5-10 mins or less). There's no veggies that go with it, just soup, green onions, wontons and noodles.

If you wanted no frills Cantonese noodle soup for lunch, this is the place!
author: Mary H.

description: Food is full of MSG.  I'm not allergic to MSG but I immediately know it after the meal as I'm super thirsty.  The owner raises the price a few times in just one year.  In the time between two raises of price, they serve u less noodles in the bowl.  To me, it's another method of raising the price.   I know things are getting more expensive esp in SF but with the price raises, I expect to have the same amount of quality AND quantity of the food but it's not the case.  I feel that the owner is not honest!   I used to come quite often even with the overloaded MSF in my stomach, but now I just feel cheated if I still go.
author: Shirley C.

description:
Super cheap. $7 for a bowl of noodles and won ton. 

This place has questionable hygiene for cheap, quick meal come here. It's easier to order if you know Chinese but just saying the numbers in English works too.

Got the beef noodle wonton soup. The meat was pretty tender and the noodles and soup were standard.
author: Mimi T.

description:
It's got that hole-in-the-wall Chinatown feel without having to walk too far from your FiDi office job.  Extremely good value for a lunch in the area and sure beats the quasi-Chinese by-the-pound deli options prevalent the FiDi.  Filling, but mostly in a carb-y way.  Might be worth adding meat or extra dumplings to up your protein quotient.  

Rice Rolls: Like those Rice Noodle Rolls you'll get from a Dim Sum cart, except without any filling save for a scallion slice here and there.  Comes with a sweet sauce (hoisin?) and sriracha for dipping.  It's fine for snacking, but not very substantive.  I could see these pairing better with some beer.

Wonton Noodle Soup: Had to try the signature dish.  Comes in a reasonably sized portion, like what you'd serve yourself at home, not an XX-Large bowl from a pho joint.  Pretty generous amount of wontons and noodles for the price.  The noodles are quite chewy; I liked them.  The wontons are a little skimpy on the meat filling, but the wrapper was a nice texture.  My first reaction was that they were a little stringy on the broth in favor of filling the bowl with more noodles.  As I was completing my lunch, I didn't mind as much.  The broth alone was kind of bland, so no big loss.
author: Adam B.

description:
There's definitely a nostalgic charm to Hon's Wun Tun House with its unassuming interior and straightforward menu but all things considered, it's a decent but unremarkable bowl of wanton noodle soup.

They've raised their prices over the years but it's still an inexpensive meal between $5-$10. The flip-side is that portion sizes are a little small. You'll probably feel like you want something more after a bowl of noodles. The noodles have a decently springy texture and the homemade wanton skins are perhaps the best part here - really silky. I've had better wantons though and they skimp a little on the fillings. Stewed beef tendons are a good option if you want something heartier. I prefer the stewed beef broth for added richness and flavor. 

It's hard to say if the nostalgic charm of Hon's is enough of a draw over the many noodle soup joints around. Still for a Chinatown/FiDi stalwart, it's still a decent spot for noodles and I hope more of these spots stick around.
author: Jon L.

description:
This is a very casual spot which serves food pretty quick despite only having one server. It was perfect for me since I was in a hurry, and ordered, ate, and paid in 15 minute. 
I got the wonton noodle soup, and thought the wontons were pretty solid, but the noodles were just plain tasteless. In fact I avoided the noodles almost altogether which is why I may have finished my meal so quickly. I also got a tea egg for 85 cents which was yum! Bring cash.
author: Sharon H.

description: Hong Kong wonton noodle. Number 23 barbecue pork and wonton in soup for $9.20 is the favorite. Same two people have been running for years still doing it. The man is the owner and the cook.
author: Ocean P.

description:
I dunno why people love this place so much, but I can't stand dirty, smelly run down, greasy, oily Chinese restaurants. This place grosses me out.

I suggest going to Yin Du on Pacific for your wonton soup cravings!
author: Alice X.

description:
Great place to grab bowl of bbq pork won ton!

Food is great.  I recommend the bbq pork won ton and also Niu Lan which is beef in soup sort of dish (I think that's how it is spelled out in mandarin) ((The place is a cantonese place though, heads up!)) 
Another great thing about the won ton soup is that the won tons are not huge like some other places.  They perfectly fit in your mouth, are flavorful, and cooked just right.  Sometimes the big won tons are over cooked and just not really easy to eat.  (They also give around 6 won tons)
Sometimes when you go in you can see the workers sitting at the table wrapping the won tons with such speed too!  Kind of entertaining to watch while you eat.  

The location isn't the best and they close pretty early.  So for that I had to drop a star.  The interior is not the nicest.  It sort of reminds me of little restaurants I would see in Hong Kong.  Satisfactory but nothing special, over the top, or incredible clean looking when you glance around.  

I would definitely come back again though when I'm in the area and craving something warm to eat.  

Overall 3 stars
author: Jessica W.

description: This is a hole in the wall type of place.  I think there are about 8 tables or so.  I had the wonton with noodles and it was tasty.  The wonton was shrimp and pork and the shrimp flavor came through nicely. The broth could have used just a bit more flavor.  Very reasonable prices.  The wonton-noodle soup came to $6.30 including the tax.
author: Mae I.

description: Hon's is an authentic dive that's been around forever. They serve you great food at a reasonable price. There's a reason it's a dive, it's not some suburban place with a cleaning staff of 12 - they are here to sell u food. If you like it, come back. If you don't - don't. So any review that focuses on "service"  or that the seats are cracked or the linoleum is yellowed, they don't get it. Don't eat here or at least, no one needs your review. Stick to eating at SUBWAY at westfield mall. 99.9% of hons is about the food and it's priced as such. So, if you go to restaurants to eat good food, eat here. If you go to restaurants because the napkins are cute, you won't like it here.
author: Joe B.

description: Old school noodle shop!  Love it...it's been so long!  Braised Pigs feet, wonton noodles with beef stew & tendon, brings back so many memories, perfect for the cold weather!
author: Gary W.

description: I found out about this place about a year and I've been going there for lunch at least once every two weeks since then. I always got the Won Ton Noodles, but I've seen many others who ordered the Beef Brisket Noodles/Ngau Lam Min. Their noodles is the best! And I love their chili sauce as well. The portion isn't huge but it would be just enough for me so that I wouldn't be in a food coma when I get back to work after. It was $6.30 per bowl of Won Ton Noodles when I started going there but the last few weeks it went up to $6.90. The elderly lady who works there is so sweet! Cash only.
author: Jessie O.

description: This is my favorite wonton house. My mom's been going here for over 20 years now and now I am trying it again after years of remaining absent. Hands down best wonton noodles in the bay area.
author: Andrew C.

description:
Came here and ordered to go with a coworker. This restaurant is definitely a hole in the wall type of place. No greeting from anyone when we walked in. Typical etiquette for a restaurant in Chinatown so I didn't think too much of it. Coworker wasn't very pleased with that though.. 

Ordered a number 33 which is beef tendon with fish ball noodle soup. Broth was lukewarm at best. Said on the menu that it was spicy but it wasn't even mildly spicy when I tried it. But they did include lots of noodles (which I liked) with 6 fish balls and three pieces of beef tendon that were chewy and delicious. 

Prices may have gone up. Didn't get a chance to look at the prices but the lady who rung me up said the total was $10.04. Then changed it to $10.40 and then changed it to $10.50. Just a couple of cents so it wasn't a big deal but definitely sketchy.
author: Cynthia T.

description: Was expecting more of this place given the reviews, but it's a very simple restaurant. Food had no taste and the beef was old. Would not recommend it.
author: Ralf B.

description:
Boy, the greasy spoon-est dive in Chinatown. Almost nothing has changed in 40-odd years, and I swear I see the same people working here from back then, and they were aged already!

This place is as it was in my youth in the 60's around here, where the fancy places like Kan's catered to the wealthy ( mainly non-Chinese ) and and places like this were always filled with Chinese people who ALWAYS spoke Chinese, and almost always Cantonese.

My personal favorite of the noodle-soup places was Junmae Guey, where it was really crowded only at the front where they sold take-out stuff, as compared with here, which was always like inside a sardine can, but the food really was good here. 

Now for the the lack of the 5th star: it is not the decor, which is simple but OK, nor the cleanliness, which is pretty good for this area. It is just that I, being born and raised in Hakata, Japan, am used to and favor a much stronger-tasting soup, which simply is not the case here nor at virtually any Cantonese place. That's it.
author: George T.

description: Always a good place for win-tun noodles!  Friendly staff.  Prices are "right".  Delicious wun-tun noodle soup.  My favorite is order #10 Stewed beef brisket win-tun and noodle soup.  Price $7.08!! Can't beat that! Eat here every week!
author: Bennie B.

description:
great food run tun noodle was super fresh with the rice noodle
4 star was because small portion other it would have been 5 star
author: A W.

description:
One of the best noodles joints in San Francisco!!!! From the outside it doesn't look like the nicest place but when you see the head chef cooking all the noodles from the window, you can help yourself but watch and then you get hungry!! 

The place is small with a seating area on the main floor and a counter area where usually individuals eat. There is an upstairs but I never been up there and have no idea what's up there. It is common for people to sit next to people they don't know but when you are eating this great food.... Who cares?!!! 

The food is excellent! They are known for there won ton and it doesn't disappoint! The won ton has the perfect texture and ingredients!! Also, the egg noddles they include with the won ton are delicious! To make things even better, the cost of a bowl of noodles is around $4.00!!! Can't beat that! 

My favorite dishes are: the won ton egg noodle soup, plain egg noodle soup, pigs feet egg noodle soup, and beef flank noodle soup! 

I don't live in the Bay Area so anytime I come visit, hon won ton is the first place I go!!! 

The only reason I mark one star off is they take cash only and it can get a little crowded and to be honest, it's not the nicest joint to eat at but the food is GREAT!
author: Yao C.

description:
Now they open to later hours and open on weekends.

Still same menu with typical HK restaurant service.

Wonton soup is still the way to go!  They need to clean their restaurant better, however.
author: Ken H.

description:
This place reminds me of practically every single noodle shop in Hong Kong, which is a good thing! The dumplings are tasty. The noodles are fresh. The broth is hot and flavorful.

Similar to HK noodle shops, be open to sit with strangers because that's what'll happen if you come during the lunch rush.

I usually order the beef stew noodle soup or the wonton noodle soup with all soups ranging anywhere from $5 to $10 (I think the menu prices on yelp are out of date). 

All the workers are look like they're north of 60, which means they're probably all around 90.. Cause you know.. Asians age well. 

Walk into Hon's and experience another part of the world.
author: Chris W.

description:
My go to spot when I'm craving some Chinese noodles on a cold day. I usually get the beef intestines mix with noodles but it's good with hor fun too! It gets pretty crowded during lunch hour and I usually come by myself so there's always a seat at the bar. It's one lady who takes the order in English and Chinese. Sometimes you will be lucky when the other guy waiters take your orders. Don't expect service because this is a quick eat and leave place. 

I agree the portion is pretty small and the noodles aren't that amazing. The broth is your typical beef stock. But it's super close to my work so this place will do. 

Try the curry beef brisket with rice and it's pretty good too!
author: Sarah I.

description: I really come here for one reason, the fresh egg noodles. I think all the other items are okay, but the freshly made egg noodles does shine here. They have good pull and chew.
author: Phat T.

description:
When I moved to SF, the first thing I ate was a wun-tun noodle soup at Hon's.

Although Hon's was not comparable to the Great NY noodletown in NYC, I couldn't find any better Cantonese style egg noodle soup in Downtown SF Chinatown area than Hon's.

Cheap, fast, and pretty good. 

I frequented Hon's, until I started going to Hy Ki Mi Gia in Tenderloin.
author: K Y.

description: Amazing wun Tub soup,one of the best won-Tun noodle soup I ate in USA . I tried many won-Tun soup in USA, no one made original soup like this . Strongly recommend
author: Difan X.

description:
Chinatown sort of starts to merge with the Financial District around this area.

Great food, worth its price and the wonton is dreamy.

All the wonton and noodles are freshly made in-store so the taste and quality are superior. Their menu contains dishes with either noodles, wonton, or rice and all dishes are quite tasty. Seating is fine and maybe not great for groups since it is a medium-sized space and can get busy during lunch.
author: Junming G.

description: Came here to revisit a childhood grub hub. Not to much of my surprise, like most long standing small Chinese restaurants in San Francisco, the taste I seek is no longer presents. HOWEVER, I would say that the noodles here are still very good with a consistency that doesn't get soggy after sitting in the soup.  The wontons and beef stew in the noodles are still very flavorful. Unfortunately portion sizes are fairly small, some may need order other bits in addition to an order of noodles to be full. Of the three appetizers, I would go with the eggs if I can only choose on for the three. The curry fishballs and the rice noodles weren't really to expectations.
author: Alan L.

description:
Cash only. Great prices. Decent food.

While most items on the menu are less than $10 (but above $5), the taste was OK. I definitely have had tastier. I bought the BBQ pork with "wun tun" (won ton).

The restaurant is a little bit run down, there is bar seating like a diner and small tables. 

Easy to find, almost a corner location.
author: Amy H.

description:
This place use to be not only good but inexpensive .
I haven't been here in ages but I decided to stop
by to get some beef stewed and I see they raised
all their prices . Everything is now close to $10
And the portion is also extremely small.

I left after paying $10 and I was not even close to
Satisfied . The fun with the sweet sauce was also
Crazy expensive with little fun. The owner just got too greedy and started raising the price on all items. It is too bad because this place use to be the place to go for Wonton
author: Jonas Y.

description: I love this place. It's a small hole in the wall wonton noodle shop and they close early at 7pm. I wish they were open later. The menu is super simple. It's mostly noodle soup and you can get your wonton noodle soup with various additions such as beef brisket, beef tendon, trip, fish balls....I recommend getting it with the beef brisket. The sizes are smaller than what you would expect for noodle soup but the cheap pricing reflects that. It's only $7 for a bowl of beef brisket and wonton noodle soup and the portions are smaller but perfect.
author: Mai C.

description:
Hon's Wun Tun House is a traditional homemade, old school style wontons noodle place. It was my first time there, but I do like their wonton noodles soup. Place is small with 8-10 small tables and right across from Portsmouth Square. We came during non-busy hours ... still 3 tables eating.

I started off with the Wonton Noodle Soup - oh for some reason the glass of tea with the wonton noodles really reminded me of old traditional Hong Kong style cafe. Anyways, the broth was very good and it tasted like they used traditional dried flounder and shrimp for the broth. Wontons were bouncy. Portion was a little smaller than I expected - good for afternoon snack I guess.

Hubby ordered the Braised Beef Noodle Soup - beef was very tender. I think they used the same broth in this, but added extra scoop of the braised beef sauce, which was good.

Noodles here are very al-dente! Just the way I love it!
author: Sandi C.

description:
I walked past this place over a year ago and thought it looked really good, finally took the time to check it out. The place has sort of an off smell when you come in. But after a few minutes you get used to it. The smell seems like a combination of cleaning solvents and broth.

At lunch time this place is fairly busy. On a Thursday night at 5:30, just the opposite. When it's slow the food comes really fast, it only took about 5 minutes to get our order. 

The dumplings are great. The noddles are slightly chewy and very tasty. They hand make the noodles and most of the other stuff is from scratch. 

Dinner for 2 came to under $13 with a coke.  

The cooking, the food and the atmosphere is similar to that of a Hong Kong establishment, at least one of the closest of its kind in San Francisco.
I would recommend trying it at least once.
author: Ben M.

description: I like the pork and wonton noodle soup.  The soup is light and has the flavor of dried shrimp.  The serving size seemed light compared other places, but would be good for a snack. Can always order something else to make it filling.
author: Dan C.

description: I've gone here for years and even make special trips to get the #12, Szechuan Sauce Noodles. Fantastic with a unique (I've not found it anywhere else) topping of bits of meat in sauce over the noodles (which are very thin, have a bit of bite to them). This is NOT the sesame based dish. The won ton and shrimp ball soups are great too, but I can't get enough of the #12 to shift over. Service is plain in a basic setting. Counter service or tables.
author: Rick C.

description:
AVOID this place by all means! They got my order wrong, delivered a bowl of dry (undercooked) and bloody (the meat was raw) noodles in lukewarm broth. The service is the WORST and they would not admit their error. The owner lady (skinny old grandma) forced me to pay even though it was their fault. Not feeling like arguing, I paid my tab and left after only taking one nasty bite of my noodle soup. 

Worst place in all of SF! This place needs to be shut down for the awful way they treat their customers and the sub zero quality food. DO NOT support this business.
author: Jenn M.

description:
This is my new weekly soup stop. 

They have the best won tons in china town. They are made fresh daily. You can even buy them uncooked if you want to cook a batch when you get home. These are small delicate won tons, with just the right amount of shrimp mixed in so they melt in your mouth. I much prefer these to the heavy meatball won tons that you find at other places.

The soup broth is also perfect. Plenty of flavor but not too salty. I also love the way the roast pork is thinly sliced, in the BBQ Pork Won Ton Soup with noodles. There's nothing worse than encountering a thick chewy piece of BBQ pork when enjoying a bowl of Won Ton soup. 

I am not crazy about their beef tendon or curry beef. 

But their Won Ton Soup is as good as it gets.
author: David T.

description: I was introduced to this by a friend who used to work in Chinatown for a few years. This hole-in-the-wall is just amazing and so cheap. I can get over the service, the food is worth it. I always get the #1 and add beef organs (on the back of the menu), although the beef brisket seems to be the popular add-on amongst my friends (I just really love beef organs).
author: Kim L.

description: We ordered the beef stew lo mein and wonton noodle soup. It's a small restaurant and can get busy so we had to share a table in order to avoid the wait. The food came pretty fast but the portions are pretty small. It's pretty cheap in the Fidi/Chinatown area so you kind of get what you pay for. The lo mein and beef stew was very flavorful and the noodles were pretty good. The wontons were ok, nothing too special. The broth wasn't amazing. I actually thought the beef stew broth that came with the lo mein tasted better than the won ton soup, which usually isn't the case. I would probably come back, but since there are so many other noodle places in the china town area, there are other places that I would probably  prefer to go to instead.
author: Bailey L.

description: Upon walking into Wun Tun I was taken aback by the strong fishy/catty smell.  Yes, you read that correctly, it smells like fish and also cats.  An order of won ton soup will run you $6.50 and is dished up in a pint container (so about the amount of soup you get from the Soup Company).  The pint container was about ¾ filled with won tons and then they ladled about  1/2 cup of broth over the top.  The won tons were ok, nothing special but not bad.  As other reviews comment, there is very little filling in the dumplings, they are mostly wrapper. The broth was also just OK, sort of bland, not extremely pleasantly smelling, but not off-putting.  The fact that this place is stinky, dirty and the soup was nothing special and also over-priced....I won't be back.
author: Emma H.

description:
The taste is decent. The wonton noodle itself is not proportional (immense amount of noodles, 5 small wontons and less than 3 oz of beef brisket. I am giving this a 2 star because of the inconsistent ways the boss lady had collected payment for this particular #10  Stewed Beef Brisket & Wun-Tun Noodle Soup. Sometimes it's $7.95, sometimes it's $8.54, sometimes it's $8.60 and today, she mumbled $8.. I gave her $9 cash. She counted and inserted my money into the cash register and quickly collected another lady's payment. It's okay if she assumes the $1 involuntary tip, the problem is my order came AFTER the lady BEHIND me, and, I wasn't even given a plastic bag. 

I blame myself for not walking 2 blocks up for some real service and most likely a better quality #10.  Over the past few years prices at this Hon's, originally known for its cheap eats, had doubled.. fyi boss lady - Greed does no one good . Ive got to go... drink an amf in ur honor.
author: Catalina C.

description: Perfect no frills noodles and wontons. Love this place. Don't forget to get a tea egg or three! So good.
author: Joe J.

description: This is a hole in the wall joint located across the street from the parking structure so do not expect a beautiful environment. Do expect a no nonsense bowl of delicious wonton noodle soup however. I dare say is one of the best around. Price and quality gives this place 4 stars in my book.
author: John W.

description: A great quick eat! I got the beef and wonton noodle soup- a decent serving of beef chunks, a few wontons (they're AMAZING-best part of the dish) and noodles, which were super thin and chewy which isn't my taste. overall, the food was pretty decent for a quick eat- they literally serve you in 2 minutes and expect you to leave in a few.
author: Jessica D.

description: Beef tendon (tendon as in 'tender') provides magical relief for aches and pains of muscles and joints, sometimes called "osteoarthritis". This is all homemade: best soup broths possible served here! Try tendon and brisket in soup with noodles for luxury; noodles in soup for simplicity.
author: J.Fred D.

description: They have the best Cantonese Wun Tun in the Bay Area. I have been to so many Cantonese Wun tun places,but none of them can compare to Hon. Yet the major con is the place itself is too small, so you have to share table with others or sit in the tiny bar table. Other than that, I want to give 10 stars!
author: Kristy W.

description: the price is good and the taste is good too. but the reason I left 4 stars is they don't accept card. CASH only!
author: Sloan L.

description:
Today's the first time that I got to try this place with some coworkers after our first attempt in trying to get a table during the lunch rush hour last time failed. Loll...so like most wonton noodle places in Chinatown, this one was pretty small inside also. However, they do have a bar for singles or doubles to sit at as well as regular tables. Fortunately, for us this time we were able to beat the lunch rush just in the nick of time because after we got seated, more people came. One of my coworkers and I ordered the beef brisket and wonton noodle soup with the flat wide rice noodles while my 2 othecoworkers ordered just the wonton noodle soup with egg noodles. We also ordered a plate of Chinese broccoli to share! 

Our noodle soups came out really fast after placing our order. The bowls are on the smaller end but there were a good amount of noodles in there. While everything was really good, my favorite is definitely the wonton! Really yummy but wish the wonton was a little bigger! But the broth was pretty flavorful too. And I really appreciated how they cut up the Chinese broccoli for you so that you don't have to stick a whole long piece into your mouth. While this place is a little further down from where I work, I would come here again, especially on a cold gloomy day!
author: Mary C.

description:
Love, love, LOVE this place!!! I cannot believe that I haven't done this sooner...maybe that was my passive-aggressive attempt at keeping this lil spot all to myself?! lol

I've been going here for close to 10 years now; if you blink, you'll miss it. It's dirt cheap, super-quick & DELICIOUS...the noodles are al dente, the wontons are to die for, and you can buy both uncooked & try to obtain the same goodness in the comfort of your abode.
author: Amoura B.

description:
* My all time favorite childhood restaurant to go to in the city for Chinese noodle soup!


WHAT TO GET
* Most of the time I would get their curry beef with noodle soup and I love to put spoonfuls and spoonfuls of hot sauce into my soup to spice it up!  Their curry beef is so good!  You have to try!
* If you want something daring, try their tendon with noodle soup! 
* If you want something safe, get their won ton noodle soup!
* If you feel like you wanted some greens with the meal, get an order of their Chinese broccoli in oyster sauce.  I personally think it is a rip off because they give such a small portion of those veggies and charge around 5 bucks for it.  It is relatively much cheaper to buy it in bulk a block up at Chinatown and cook it yourself.  However, I guess you are paying for them to cook it and serve it to you.

I see a lot of business people dining here during lunch hours from Financial District so it gets pretty packed and hot.  

Mind the decor!  I don't think this place was set up to impress modernity.  They are not known for their ambiance, but for their food!  It's one of those restaurants where you just order, eat and leave.  It wasn't set up for you to enjoy the layout, presentation and service.

After years of many people touching their menus, they finally got new (now shiny) menus! 

CASH ONLY!  If you don't have cash, Financial District is down the block! Plenty of ATMs/banks there!

Love this place!  It brings back so many memories and creates new ones as well!
author: Tiffany D.

description:
This place is the kind of place you can call your own. Don't bring anyone fussy here. It's dowdy and no-frills and the trip to the bathroom involves going downstairs through a storage area.

That said, they make a great, cheap, bowl of wonton noodles. My family has had restaurants on both sides and this is as good as I've tasted. The wontons are cooked through but not overcooked with the skins falling apart. The portion is generous but not monstrous. The service is very fast and unlike many Chinese restaurants which do not cater to the tourist trade, the wait staff will smile and say thank you.

Edited: They make their own noodles and wonton skins. You can taste the freshness.
author: Kenn F.

description:
Simple and delicious.***Cash only.*** Made my soul very happy. Also, very clean in comparison to the other Chinatown Mom and Pop shops I've been to. The place is run like a well-oiled machine. 

The broth/meat is simmering in a huge pot, noodles are already cooked, and garnishes are ready to go. You place your order and will have a steaming hot bowl of wonton (noodle) soup in front of you very quickly. 

They close early at a whopping 7 PM (isn't that when dinner starts?!). We showed up at 6:45 PM and ordered the braised beef soup with thin egg noodles and extra Chinese broccoli as well as a side of Chinese tea eggs. Noodles were perfectly al-dente and the rich, five-spice heavy mahogany-colored broth hit all the right notes. 

Problem with showing up late is that they run out of some noodles and meat portions are smaller too (seems like they cook in bulk and serve until it runs out). 

I'm basically on a quest to find the yummiest-tasting (Chinese or Taiwanese) beef noodle soup in San Francisco. So far, this place is pretty high up. Not sure if I like the beef noodle soup better here or at House of Xian. Both are lovely in their own right.
author: Arushi S.

description: This place is an institution and has been around for decades. I love their wun ton soup with beef brisket. Service is what you typically would expect from an old school Chinese restaurant, but the food comes out very quickly and the price is more than reasonable. This place knows what it is, and doesn't try to be something it's not. Not really a place for a date night but definitely the place to go if you're looking for a quick bite to eat on a chilly San Francisco night.
author: Sam C.

description:
A typical China town spot with the purpose of serving authentic fresh food at the right price without unnecessary delay. 

They have around 8 tables which are yellow and could use refurbishment. The other half of the restaurant is the kitchen, which appeared to be primarily a giant pot of broth, a giant pot of noodles, other steaming pots, and counter space to prepare the rest of the food. But once again the ambiance is not why you should come here. 

The flat rolled up noodles (I forget the actual name) are divine, and the shining glory of this place. They sell them to-go but you have to get them in the morning as they sell out fast! 

The wun tun dumpling noodle soup I had hit the spot! It wasn't intensely flavorful but I was craving something warm and not too heavy. They have many more adventurous items like beef tendon noodle soup as well.
author: Amelia J.

description:
You should bring more cash here than you would to a strip club, because its dishes are incredibly cheap and you'll always want more.

The broth has more umami flavor than the other cheap Hong Kong looking shops do. The portions are definitely small, but still a great value for what you get. 

I recommend the Won Ton Noodle soup with wide egg noodles. It's harder to find this type of noodle around the city aside from Hai Ky Mi Gia in the Tenderloin.

I love the rustic diner style of this place and the window shop kitchen style. I saw the cutest tiny little grandma eating there and becoming friends with the owner. Grandma goals beats wonton goals. 

Will be returning with more cash money in the near future.
author: Vi T.

description: Great noodle but the tendon and soup was a little bit unusual.  Good comfort food for a change  !
author: CAScuba Y.

description:
$5.25 for a small bowl of wonton noodle soup

$6.45 for a bigger bowl of wonton noodle soup
- the menu has it listed as wonton "double noodle" soup
- double meaning 2x noodle, not wonton
- and $1.20 just to add one extra noodle bunch and not additional wonton? wat. that's too baller for me. i'll go home and make my own double noodle

I'd rather get the regular wonton noodle and order a side of veggies or something. And to be completely honest, I come here on work days to satisfy my wonton cravings, for the convenience of the location, and the quick service. We ordered and within minutes, the food was on our table.

CASH ONLY.
author: Sandy T.

description:
I come here often for the best BBQ pork won ton noodle soup in town! They know me there now so they don't hesitate to say hello, but this is a relationship that took a few 4 regular visits to forge. 

Don't forget this is a Chinese restaurant that is meant to cater to Chinese, so the service doesn't play by American rules. If you're looking for someone to address you right when you come in and come to your table every 10 minutes then you'll be disappointed. Know what you need to do with these types of places. Look for the person bringing out the food, say hello, then sit down, and wave them down when you know what you want. Simple and efficient if you know that's what's up.

The broth is super important (ahem... Souper important) and it's killer here. I always add a little chili oil to kick it up. It's normal for things to be less spicy or not spicy because they want to ensure that you can make it to your preferred level of spice. The won tons here are supreme! Hand made and delicious. I've eaten at many places in Hong Kong and this place stands up against them.
author: Andrew W.

description:
Hole in the wall that serves decent wonton noodle soup. 

Food (4/5): I always get wonton soup whenever it's on the menu, so this was right up my alley. I got the wonton soup with veggies (they only had cabbage that day), stewed/braised beef, without the noodles. Nothing mindblowing, but really solid food!

Service (4/5): The servers are busy and trying to get around in a tight space, but they were friendly enough and it's obvious they're working hard.

Value (5/5): So cheap and affordable! I think I paid around $7, but that was with extra veggies.

Note - I wouldn't come here with a large group unless you're prepared to wait. Most tables seat 4, but there is one circular table in the corner where you can squeeze (literally) 8 people. We ended up doing that, but if anyone wants to get out you'll all have to get up!
author: Abby S.

description:
Cheap good food for a cold (August) San Francisco day.No frills food at a low price. Portions are smaller than other nearby Chinatown restaurants. Service was quick. 

My wife and I both ordered  #15. Wun-Tun & Double Noodle Soup       5.99

She considered it mediocre and just like other soups she had. 2.5 stars. I liked mine more, perhaps because of the cool day. I thought of it as 3 stars. Full of noodles and many little won tons (wun tuns).

Additionally I had  #25. Stewed Beef Brisket Over Noodle       6.72.

This was also a smaller portion than I am used to seeing. It had about eight small chunks or pieces of beef, about three mouth fulls. The noodles had a slightly beefy broth on them to give them flavor. 2.5  stars. 

I remember visiting this place with my parents on my first San Francisco visit in 1972.  It is still there. Also heard that many of the staff have been in this place for a number of years.I doubt that much change has taken place since the 1972 visit. 

Cash only (no surprise there).
author: Steven G.

description:
I stopped in one day on my walk home from work because I really wanted some wonton soup for dinner. 

For $5, I got a BIG container of noodles and wontons (enough for two meals!) that was hot and tasty! Very quick and friendly service!
author: MaryKate M.

description: very authentic cantonese food that i finish my dish in 5 min. noodle is fresh and meats are yummy.
author: Ashton L.

description:
This place changed! I remember the first time I came here at least a decade ago with my mom. She introduced me to Hon's. I specifically loved their noodles because they added a little fried pork fat (kinda like chicarons) to the top of their wonton noodle soup. 

Well they don't do that anymore. The soup broth is good and the noodles are nice and bouncy. But I miss the fried fat..
author: L M.

description:
I have been a loyal customer for the last 10 years and I still am. This is not a place for you and your buddy co-worker to take your lovely time to eat and gossip. You will be harassed to leave if you hog up the table after you are done.  It's more like you come, you eat, and you leave (after you've paid of course). You don't ask questions, you don't make eye contact, and you don't make special requests. Don't look around because you will find something you rather not see at a restaurant. Menu is simple. Don't expect great customer service, or any service if at all. Their waiters are all folks past their retirement age, so be patient. Before you eat, take some time to wipe off the chopsticks and small dipping plate. They are cheap, so don't be coming in expecting to fill up your tummies if you have a big appetite. You do have the option of adding extra noodles or extra wonton. Ok, now the expectations are set, let's talk about food.

They are famous for their wontons and that's what most people will come here for. I like it that they don't make jumbo sized wontons. It's a perfect size to slurp one in one bite. The broth is flavorful (I'd also like to add a tint of hot sauce in my bowl of wonton soup to give it a kick). You get your choices of thick egg noodles, thin kind, as well as the flat rice noodles. I've tried them all and all are phenomenal. However, you need to have the owner make it. One time while the owner was unavailable, the waiter stepped in. He killed the noodles for me and made it way too soft. From thereon, I made sure the owner is there when I check in this place.

People complain about the cleanliness of this restaurant. I've eaten here for more than 10 years and have not had any issues. Cash only, but don't bother waiting for the waiter(s) to come pick up the money. Leave the tip on the table and pay at the cashier.
author: Em T.

description:
Quick service and great prices! Not a great place for large groups though. Great for eating alone or with a group smaller than 5.
Wonton noodles were very tasty and the rice rolls tasted a little plain, but they were still worth a try! 
Authentic wonton place to eat. I would definitely eat here again!
author: Laura K.

description: Straight up good wonton noodle soup. No frills, fast service and excellent food. Come here to get your fix!
author: Chantee F.

description: Good noodle the dishes without the soup or it served on the side is better than the ones with the soup mixed in. Tea eggs are good too. Don't expect much in terms of ambiance it's a grubby restaurant so order, eat it and leave.
author: N A.

description:
what i ordered... wun tun noodle soup

Either somebody bribed a city official or they doctored the sign or the inspection was at the very first day of service...... they have a 98 out of a hundred for food safety.

my observation... by the bar side.
- dirty and broken down ceiling 
- a slow cooker full of something reddish, overflowing all over the counter
- a mound of noodles on a pan, a lot of the threads hanging and touching the not so clean shelves 
- a stainless steel pail half filled with broth on the dirty blackish flour 
- THE soup master touching all parts of his body with his bare hands that he uses to gather around his ingredients 
- cashier lady who takes the cash only payment with her bare hands and helps out the chef and the bussers as needed which she does contstantly 

.... i admit i did ate some of the soup but i regreted it after noticing all of the thing's going on around me.

Soup was Ok, broth was so-so.... it had an overpowering shrimp flavor, won ton was small in sizes but good tasting and noodles were ok

ambiance... bad (dirty and cluttered)
service... so-so (drop and go)
cost... $ (fair)
author: Gors P.

description: Excellent won ton and noodles!  Too bad I live in LA or I would go more often.  Small hole in the wall but those have the best food.
author: Vivian W.

description:
When you walk around chinatown and get the scent of egg noodles mixed with wonton supreme broth in the air, realize that this is the place that's generating such heavenly goodness. VERY Comparable to a good bowl of wonton mein in Hong Kong. The broth is rich, salty, and MOST IMPORTANTLY...Consistent. Order up a number 10 (beef stew, wonton, noodle soup) and it comes out piping hot in less than 2 minutes when you go from 3-5pm. I'd say a big downfall is the absolutely shitty bowl they serve it in, but that tends to grow on you after your 50th bowl. You will understand a great noodle spot when the thought of it makes you hungry, even when you just ate. 
I will never go anywhere else for wonton noodle soup in Chinatown ever again.
author: Brian C.

description: Love this place!  Mom and pop...delicious noodle soup!  It's a must every time we come to San Francisco! $4 - $5!!!
author: Janine K.

description: Hon's lives on! So happy this gem hasn't been squeezed out. They have been making excellent wonton the exact same for as long as I can remember.
