In fact, most of the staff is the same from 15 years ago, when I first started eating here. I've eaten tons of wontons in SF, and these are the best. They are simple, delicate and consistent. The casing is so thin and fragile and it's a pleasure to bite through. The broth is homemade and apparently takes at least 4 hours, but what goes inside is secret. I usually get the #3 and add veggies. This comes with a dozen wonton. If you get the noodles or beef brisket, you will only get 6 wontons. The curry beef is also suggested. Compliment with a tea egg. When you eat here, know that you will be rubbing shoulders (almost literally at the food bar) with some old-time legends of Chinatown. It's almost straight out of a Wong Kar-wai film. Enjoy and support the old-school!
author: Brian J.

description: Hon's Wun Tun House has been in San Francisco for a very long time. I am so glad they are still around serving up wontons and noodle. Small portions so when I am really hungry, I have to order double. I always feel like a big eater when I do that, but oh well. And this is one of those authentic wonton places that have the vinegar on the table, so you can eat it with the wontons and noodle. Omg! So good. I don't come here as often, but it's always good to revisit old spots.
author: Missy X.

description: Went here for lunch last Saturday while working in the city at Neimans! The place is tiny and a little crowded which is a good sign!! I ordered the bbq wonton noodle soup! It was ready in seconds and SO GOOD! Great broth, tasty wontons and lots of noodles! It's worth the crowd!!
author: Tormain H.

description:
The service is as expected here for a Chinese restaurant (i.e. you need to madly wave your hand back and forth to get any attention at all). It's quite a small place with about seven tables and bar seating. If you're in a small group or come individually, expect to pay at the cash register. The service is fast and efficient. They have one chinese lady manning the register and another old man who buses tables. Unfortunately, both seemed oddly crippled, but performed their duties just fine. Don't expect a smile or a good attitude from anyone working here though. They just get straight down to business. And don't worry, the old chinese lady does speak english.

The wonton's here are the real deal though and probably the best part of this restaurant. I ordered the stewed beef brisket wonton noodle soup. You can also ask for the wide rice noodle. The beef brisket was not my favorite as it came along with lumps of fat, tendon, skin, and cartilage (basically all the works). The noodles were pretty ordinary yellow egg noodles, but they were cooked to just the right texture. The soup was also not too bland and not too salty. Each meal comes with a complementary cup of tea.

The prices were very decent and affordable. Great for a quick, simple meal anytime.

Additionally, they sell the wonton and noodle separately by the pound in case you'd like to bring them home to cook. Other items on the menu include pig's feet, beef trip, and beef tendon.
author: Audrey L.

description:
Fast and fresh no frills good food.

noodles al dente chinese style best still in SF.  broth clean.

curry rice one of my favorites, been getting this most of the time over noodles or both when hungry.

cha siu fan.  plain and simple greatness.
author: Kevin L.

description: I probably will never find a place that encapsulates all the complexities of the Hong Kong wonton, but I was hoping that this place would at least have wontons with a good prawn-to-pork ratio. The soup is unremarkable as were the noodles, but they didn't disappoint as much as the wontons. Perhaps the best thing about this place is its nostalgically cheap price point, but that's not enough to justify a special trip here for wonton noodle soup.
author: Jessica L.

description:
I thought this place disappeared on Kearny street, because I haven't been here in so long. There were 4 Beatles alive back then, I think, and Walter Cronkite might have been still doing the CBS Nightly News. I think it might have been before CNN and Cable, but after Neil Armstrong's One Small Step. 

So suffice it to say, if this isn't the epitome of your classic Chinatown Dive Noodle house, then you should go home and break open that Cup-o-Noodle.  If you looked up Chinatown Dirty Dive Noodle House on Wikipedia, you might see this pictured there. 

It is the same as it was decades ago. About 10 choices of toppings. I went with Nau Nam Won Ton Mein (beef brisket). It is a little bowl, filled with vermicelli sized egg noodles, some won tons, and the pieces of brisket. The cup of hot oolong tea in a clear plastic cup is gratis. There is hot oil, soy sauce, and hot chili in the little tiny-spooned clear glass condiment container in front of you. The broth is tasty, but looks like dishwater. Most dishes are about $5.99. 

It started to rain, and I was walking by. I got a hot bowl of noodles, and a flood of old memories coming here with my Chinese friends back in the day, when Chinatown was on Grant, not Clement street.
author: Wanugee N.

description:
Okay, so we were walking down the street and all of a sudden we see steam and huge portion of noodles from this restaurants window. This reminded us of the movie The Ramen Girl. So of course we had to dine her to see if the starch was worth while!! 
    Well, it was so-so. Personally it was way to fishy for my taste, I just had a bowl of their Noodles and some Won Tons as well as rice rolls, and I love fish and sea food, but I did not expect the noodles to taste that fishy. I was a bit disappointed. The won tons were good and very soft, the rice rolls lacked something they were plain even with the sriracha.
  --The service was just okay, they were not warm and fuzzy at all, but I mean thats okay, a smile would count as good enough service for me.
**  It may have been too authentic for my taste, you could say!! 
                             _Thanks anyways!!
author: Lizeth M.

description: I've been here since I was a kid and nothing has changed. Same tables, same owners, and same menu. Prices are still really cheap though considering they are in the Chinatown/Financial District. They have the best wonton soup. No other place in Chinatown can make their wontons as tasty. I always come with my parents, and I order the same thing every time. I'm all about a bowl of wontons ($6-7), and some rice rolls. The wonton soup comes with about 12 wontons and it's very filling. I will keep visiting as long as they are in business!
author: Jeanne C.

description:
Finally came here after bookmarking and passing by this place for years. I was bum out that it did not live up to it's reputation. The portions were small. I order a "large" but the bowl seems like small. I had about 4-5 wontons with barely any meat in it and mostly wonton wrapper. Barely any beef tendon also. 

Cost $8.75 with tax. Plus tips about $10.

Maybe this place was once good or perhaps people still come here for the nostalgic old school Chinatown ambiance.
author: U L.

description: Best wonton soup in town, easily. Other stuff is pretty good, but nothing matches its namesake.
author: Jason Z.

description: "My" secret spot in Chinatown. Love the won tons here... I always get a double portion of won ton soup, no noodles. Sometimes shrimp, sometimes regular. I always put in a lot of that awesome chili sauce that they make themselves in-house... mmm my mouth is watering just thinking about this place! This is a hole in the wall; hidden gem. If you want a place that looks fancy, this isn't the spot for you. If you're all about delicious won ton soup, eat here. You won't be disappointed. Like the street-peddler from Aladdin says, "Like so many things, it is not what is outside, but what is inside that counts." ;)
author: Alex G.

description:
Soup - Bland. It's mainly lacking the seafood flavors that give the broth a big umami taste. 

Noodles - Not al dente. They didn't have that toothsome bite that makes eating won ton noodles so much fun. 

Won Tons - I didn't mind that they're small, but they were shrunken and shriveled. Won tons shouldn't be big, but they should be plump. Inside, the shrimp was minced up and didn't provide a firm texture to contrast with the other soft components. The shrimp really needs to be kept at least in large morsels or else it's just a constant softness throughout. The taste actually wasn't that bad. They use the right warm spices to season the stuffing.

I'm all about cheap janky places, but this one's not really tasty enough for me to come back. My quest for good won ton noodle soup continues...
author: Nei N.

description:
Time/Date: Weekday. 
Meal of the day: Lunch around 1:30pm
Would I recommend it?  YESSSS! 

Tip:  Get there before 12pm or after 1:30pm; or it's going to be PACKED! 

What I ordered: 
* Won Ton Noodle Soup 


Food Quality: Best Won Tons everrrrrr! The best! And, the noodles are soooooo smooth! The noodles' texture instantly puts me on Cloud Nine the second it enters my mouth. And, the won tons are the best! So juicy and the meat is just cooked so perfectly! And, all their noodles and won tons are freshly made! MUST TRY! 

Seating Area: 
It's a small restaurant, so all the tables are pretty close to each other. So, if you ever want to eavesdrop, you don't need to make much effort (LOL). Since it's a Chinese restaurant, the place is pretty plain overall. The waiter basically wipes the table off for you while you are seated. 


Customer Service: 
Friendly is not the word I would use, but they are overall pretty polite. They also do To-gos, so you can always order ahead if you don't want to eat there. Each staff is usually very busy, so they rush every single task that they do. So, don't ever feel like they are being rude or anything. That's not their intention (LOL).  

Parking: 
LOL! Who are you kidding trying to drive there? Take Uber or walk there! There are about -10 parking spots there! First person to find parking wins a Noble Prize! 

Overall: 
Best Won Ton Noodle Soups! Must try!!
author: Katy W.

description: I like this place a lot. I ordered curry beef stew, very tasty, very yummy!!!! I will try wonton soup next time. I feel the place is a little bit smelly, but probably just some type of smell I don't like.
author: Emma C.

description:
I've been coming here ever since I was little. My parents would always try to leave the house so early just to beat the traffic and lunch rush. I never would of thought a small restaurant on Kearny street would have such good food. 

I've been introducing it to all my friends and now my boyfriend. We always come in and get the wonton noodle soup. If you're extra hungry Id highly advise for you to order the wonton double noodle soup. They don't give much wonton, so ask for extra. The Chinese broccoli is served with oyster sauce, and my boyfriend gets the beef curry with rice. 

It's honesty the best wonton house around. Seat yourself, glance the menu, and give it a try.
author: Lisa K.

description: The soup was nice and clean, but it was missing something.  I am not sure if it needed a bit more salt or what it was, but it lacked a certain taste that I commonly associate with Won Ton noodle soup.  The noodles were al-dente and the wontons were what you'd expect from a $6.30 noodle soup.  Overall, this was a good light lunch, but there wasn't anything about it that would make me choose this place over the other establishments in the area.
author: Alexander P.

description: Hole in a wall wonton resturant in Chinatown near the Financial District. This is the kind of place where you eat your food and go. Do not plan on staying here and chat with your friends. Just eat and go. Super cheap. The bowls are pretty small so order something else on the side like their rice rolls or extra wontons. Their wonton noodle soup (I like mines with the flat rice noodles) is delicious especially on a gloomy day. Their wontons are small and they are thinly wrapped. The broth is flavorful, not too sweet or salty. Pay at the register with CASH only. Don't think you should use the restroom here, like I said, just eat and go.
author: Crystal C.

description: Was here back in 2013 with my sister. We were in San Fran the first time and were visiting Chinatown trying to find something to eat. Walked pass this place a couple times, saw a line waiting to be seated so decided to give it a try. It was the most authentic won ton we've ever had in the US! It's not a fancy place but definitely brought back a lot of childhood memories. Thank you!
author: Stal-U W.

description:
This is not a self proclaimed foodie's spot, but a classic Down -n D place. It's great.  This is what Chinatown is about.  Great tasting Classic Chinatown Faire.  Best won ton soup in the city ... I've been coming here for as long as I can remember and it's consistently good.  

Here's the qualifier ... I usually coincide my stop here with my $5 hair cut in Chinatown.  I suppose if you spend more than $30 on a haircut, you're too fancy for this place ... Go to R&G instead. :)
author: Rod C.

description: Ordered the wonton noodle soup togo. They are extremely fast. Literally got my food all bagged up before I even finished paying. Great place for take out if you have a short lunch break. The wonton it self wasn't that tastey in my opinion. But I like my food on the saltier side. It's a good option if you're craving wontons.
author: Lina C.

description:
overall this is the only place I would recommend to people for nice wonton noodle.
The only place that you can really taste the Hong Kong taste if u know what I mean.
The soup base are made from shrimp shell with no MSG added. The wonton is just the right size not too big not too small. The most important is the noodle you won't get that ammonia smell like other restaurant has from either not rinsing it good enough. For the noodle to have the right bite feeling you have to cook itt just right with the correct temperature of cooking and the timing has to be right also. some places cook it too long and rinse it too long than the noodle will not have that right bite feel.very highly recommend if you people really want to get that Hong Kong wonton noodle taste. It is a shame that I have been to other wonton restaurant like Ming's on Noriega and King of wonton on Irving both very disappointed and both of these so call wonton noodle restaurant are prepare by these so call Cantonese chefs.If you people do want to get the real HK tsste just go to Hon's but this is a very busy place if you can't wait than you should just go for trash.
author: Tommy M.

description:
I used to go here often back 5 or more years ago when i had classes in chinatown.
And even til now , this place's wonton is always the best wonton ever. Ive been to many restaurants my whole life. And this place is still ALWAYS makes the BEST wontons. MY FAVORITE Wonton restaurant always . i still crave for it . the wontons are amazinggggg u need to try it even if u hate wontons!
author: N S.

description: my husband first introduced this place to me years ago. He has been going to this spot since he was a kid, his dad would bring him. our son who is now 11 yrs old loves going here. the taste of the broth is consistently good and service is great! my husband and son always orders the beef brisket and wonton noodles soup and i the wonton plus veggies noodle soup. love it!
author: Karen V.

description:
I tried this place for the first time at lunch today and had the wonton noodle soup with extra szechuan sauce (spicy pork red-ish sauce). I loved it! It tastes just like what they have in Hong Kong. The wontons are small enough to fit the whole thing in your mouth (and I have the smallest mouth ever!). I hate it when I have to bite into wontons coz most likely the liquid will just ooze out and can at times find my eyes to land on . The noodle is al dente and the szechuan sauce is yummy. Service is ultra fast. Ideal for a quick satisfying lunch that won't leave you extra stuffed and sleepy at work after lunch.

The extra star I gave is for their service. Yes yes I know it may sound weird for a place in Chinatown to get any star for service. Well, embarrassingly I didn't have enough cash to pay for my lunch. I could've sworn I had a $20 bill in my wallet - but then of course I was wrong. Ugh. So i was 60 cents short. Ughh. And there was no Chase ATM anywhere near. Ughhhhhhh. When I asked the chef and (I assume) owner if there's any Chase nearby - he said "It's okay! Don't worry about it!" I felt so bad and insisted that I'll be back with the cash. He kept saying "It's okay. Next time." while smiling. So I thanked him and promised him that I'll be back again.

I will definitely keep my promise and come back there again for a meal! But this time I'm gonna drag the hubster so he can pay for us. And so I can eat more stuff. .
author: Priscillia I.

description: This is a hole in the wall restaurant. The prices are pretty cheap but the portions are smaller than a normal dish. Order at least two dishes and you'll be full.
author: Hau N.

description:
Sufficiently tasty and cheap. Look hard enough and you'll find tiny bits of shrimp in your won tons.

Pretty authentic too. Again you go because it's tasty and cheap. You don't go for any other reason.
author: Brian W.

description: Wonton noodles taste good, but not enough wonton.  Szechwan sauce over noodles are pretty good as well. It's mild spicy sauce with ground pork over noodles. Prices for each items are around $6-7.
author: Lynn P.

description: The middle aged guy who cooks soup in the front gave me hella attitude and who couldn't speak well Chinese nor English. The ladies there were nice. He also hella dirty. It was 6pm , I saw him cleaned the trash can underneath the sink and didn't wash his hand and then grabbed the wonton and dropped into the big soup pot. Aw....... I feel like I will get sick from this.... I only giving three stars for the ladies who work there and their good wontons.
author: Elaine Y.

description:
A small chinese-style diner tucked away on Kearny and Clay in Chinatown/ Fidi. 
Don't expect great service. 
Don't expect the best chinese food you've ever eaten in your life. 
Do expect a good, solid bowl of wonton noodles- handmade noodles cooked perfectly al dente, just like they do in Hong Kong. 
The wontons are tiny. The beef brisket portion is small. 
Go for the noodles- they sell them fresh too, so you can bring them home and cook it yourself with some charsiu and fatter/ bigger wontons you make yourself. 
Don't make your own wontons? then maybe can't complain about the tiny wontons here. hmmmm
author: Jocelyn L.

description: Just good old school wonton noodle soup and beef stew. No fancy menus or decor, as old school traditional Hong Kong food stop as you'll find anywhere. Prices have crept up with inflation but otherwise just the same as it was when I first ate here 25 years ago. Love it!
author: Mikey L.

description:
Pretty darn good for $5! 

I had a bowl of wontons with har fun. Not a fan of egg noodles. The wontons were tasty, however, the soup was a little bland. And I wish they had more wontons instead of noodles in it! 

Can't complain for the price!
author: Angela L.

description: This cheapie C-Town hole in the wall offers bowls of soup with fresh noodles, hand made dumplings, and rich pork broth.  Service might be friendly or brusque depending on the mood of the couple who run it. Hard to give such authentic places any less than five stars.
author: Nick C.

description:
This is one of those MOM and POP's places that you grew eating wonton's when you were little.

They are still Open. 
My friend Tony L. was one of those kids who grew eating from this restaurant.  He orders the same meal every time (The dan dan Mein - Cantonese style Shredded pork with their special sauce and mixed in with wonton noodles).  And their famously Fresh Wonton soup.

A small list of the menu (very simple) that offers about 20 dishes and prices are merely from $ 4.50 - 7.95) 

I was obligated to try the wonton soup which was pretty good, pretty average size that when you bite in you can see what's inside.  Wonton skin is super think and silky that slips in your tongue.  Soup was nothing ordinary.

Then I tried the Beef Tendon Curry over rice (About $ 7.00 for the dish). It was not bad, Nothing to say about the white rice, just mixed it with the soupy curry .  Tendon beef was SUPER soft and tendered.  I cannot compare to the portions from before (As I heard it got smaller)..  But it was perfect for me to finish it.

Staff here is a bit slow, please be patient since they have been working here for a while.

CASH ONLY By the way.
author: Helena H.

description: Get # 12 spicy Szechuan sauce over noodles and even adding the chili oil sauce gives it a better roasted chili flavor since it's not spicy to begin with. My favorite Jia jiang mein of allllllll time and I have tried several in my life!!!! This dish is what they were originally famous for over 30 yrs ago when my mom lived in the city and it wasn't so touristy back then. It was her favorite comfort food at the time and it's still damn good! I hope they carry on this family business since the owners seem older now or else I will miss this noodle dish so much. One of my favorite Chinese noodle dishes in the Bay Area and I grew up here. Others that made the top 3 are hai ky mi Gia for their silver noodle soup and house broth with everything in it-(also for amazing rounded taste best to add a little sugar and the vinegar/jalapeño condiment which is a typical condiment for Chinese and thai noodle houses, then I also add the dry chili flakes which are not like American chili) but my husband leaves his wonton noodle soup untouched there which is very good as is. Other top 3 noodle dish is 168 restaurant in el Cerrito which has the best wok stir fried almost like thick fresh udon noodles with seafood and beef #J25 3 flavored chao mo mein which comes spicy and no need to add any condiments as it is perfect as is. Mmmmmmmmm
author: Kimi W.

description: I been coming to this place for years. Its located in the skirts of Chinatown.  If there was a definition of hole in a wall spot, this would be it.  I'm not a snob, but I order it to go.  2 words... Scratchy utensils.  But this is the place for one of the best won ton soup in SF.  I always order the shrimp won ton with BBQ pork and noodles.  The shrimp won ton is fresh but small.  The BBQ pork is good.  The noodles is super fresh.  The real star of this show is the broth.  It is a sweet chicken broth.  Really good.  Combine all of that and you have a tasteful soup with noodles that is a meal in itself.  If your on Kearny St, come by here and order your soup to go, SON.
author: Chris P.

description:
Hands down the best wonton noodle soup in the city. The flavor of the soup can't be beat.

Order anything that has soup in it. They use the same soup base in all of their soup dishes. Add some soy sauce and red vinegar to the soup and it's magic.

Service isn't great but the food makes up for it. Portions are small but so are the prices so just order two of everything. =)

Make sure to bring cash. Cash only.
author: Andy W.

description:
Msg heaven... as the result Mouth runs dry insatiably
Won ton is small and no meat.
Hole in the wall trapping tourist with their cheap cash prices.

Where are the Chinese?  I mean locals!
Always on the lookout for the cockraoch... thank god no visits.
author: David H.

description: Hands down the best wonton noodle soup shop in San Francisco. The broth is flavorful and aromatic. The noodles are made at the shop and perfectly cooked (not too hard, not too mushy and most importantly doesn't taste last starch). The service is quick and efficient, which is perfect when you're on a quick lunch break!
author: Kitty K.

description: I'll be keeping my reviews short since we're on vacation.  Hon's Wun Tun House seems to be very well known for their wonton noodles, so I had to make sure our orders included that.  Let me just say I love wonton mein!  I've had some of the best wonton meins around the world.....no joke here.  The best ones are obviously the ones in Hong Kong and Richmond, BC.  I had really high expectations of Hon's since most reviews claim this is one of the best, if not the best, that San Fran has to offer.  After a few bites, I was quite disappointed.  The soup was average, and the wontons were average.  The only thing I thought was really good was their noodles.  It was thin and al dente like how it should be.  The brisket that we ordered was mediocre at best.  In fact, some pieces were kinda too chewy.  Another thing that a lot of customers seem to be ordering was their curry fishballs.  So we decided to order some.....that too was a disappointment.  It was too bland.  The good ones you get from Hong Kong usually would have curry penetrate throughout the fishballs AND would have a better "bouncier" texture.  Since SF has the biggest chinatown in the US, I would've thought it's best wonton mein would be insanely good.  But in fact, even Hawaii (where I'm from) has better options......
author: Steven L.

description:
One of those places where they are not nice to you if you're not Chinese.

1) Rude.  After I saw how small the bowl was, I tried to order "extra ingredients".  The man at the counter dismissed with a gesture of the hand and a very court attitude.  

2) Expensive.  $5.30 for a very small bowl. I had to get back to work and had no time to hunt for a supplement so I ended up having two bowls: over $11.  

I hesitated between 1 and 2 stars and went with 2 because the dumplings are good and the lady that took my second order was nice.  The second bowl took a very long time to come.
author: Paula H.

description:
Why don't I eat here more often again? Rock bottom cheap and there's always enough squawking action in Cantonese by the kitchen staff to keep me entertained. 

The $2 cheong fun is probably my favorite thing here. Every order comes with a plate of rolled rice noodles (similar to tteok for the Korean folk) drizzled in soy sauce and with two big dollops of hoisin and sriracha. Stuff is made to defeat Atkins dieters singlehandedly, but a solid snack while you're waiting on your noodles.

Thick soup noodles with beef on top is tasty here and around $4, if I remember correctly. It is true that the broth here is a lot more plain than other places, but it's great for letting the slow-cooked beef shine through. Nothing a few squirts o' cock sauce won't solve.
author: Kevin L.

description:
Best wonton noodles.  We came here for one more meal before we head out to the airport.  And yes, it is still the best wonton noodles restaurant, IMO.  We got to the place right before lunch time, so we were seated right away.   This place do get crowded and by the time we left, there was a line waiting.  And it is worth the wait. It is a small place and people do share tables.    

If you're looking for ambiance and atmosphere, there're none here.  But if you're looking for good food, yes, you're at the right place.  One more thing, this is a Cash Only establishment.
author: Polly P.

description:
Welcome to Hong Kong!  No really.. I felt like I was in a little noodle house in Asia.  Why?  They have a huge soup pot right next to the window (like they do in Asia), so you can watch them pour the yummy broth over noodles or wontons - it's a great marketing tactic.. it definitely made me hungry!  

I'm quite surprised that this place has received so many great reviews.  It's good, but definitely not the best I've had.  I ordered wonton soup - there were a lot of wontons, but they were tiny... I wish they would stuff more pork or shrimp into them to fatten them up..  The soup was good, but of course, loaded with msg... no wonder it was so flavorful!

And to top it all off, they are a cash only institution... not a fan at all.  

I honestly can't say I like this place very much, and I definitely wouldn't go out of my way to eat here, but for what it's worth.. it's not bad... just A-OK.
author: Cecilia S.

description: Not w good value for won ton noodle soup. I ordered with roast duck and I got three tiny (but tasty) pieces. The won ton was just ok too. Got the finger and it had no taste. There are better places or there should be. I grew up eating this stuff and was so disappointed.
author: Deal G.

description: Good Wonton. There was not much communication but the elder lady was kindly serve us tea, mutiple times. The food in general is average. The owner surely has the potential to make the place nicer and to expend a little bigger.
author: Yu W.

description: This was my childhood hot spot for wun tun mein so I was excited to come back here after so many years. It is still affordable but it is more of a snack than a meal. The portions are smaller than I remember and not as savory as I remember. Nevertheless, service is super fast. Yo order and food is on your table a minute later.
author: Andrew W.

description: Food was O-K- The curry beef has bits and parts of cow I didn't think were even edible-gross. The main reason I give one star is because the guy BLATENTLY inflated the price of the menu items when he looked at me. I ordered shrimp noodle soup and beef curry on the phone. He said the total was $15 at first...then he said, oh wait..HESITATINGLY, he says, Oh it's 19.45. The total SHOULD have been 14.45.  He just added an extra 5 dollars because I looked different. BAD. If you are from here and are Asian, it will probably be a good experience. If you look different, he will JACK UP the price if you look like you can afford it. Never going back here again.
author: Roy J.

description: Authentic HK wonton soup noodles, and the vegetables were great too! Tea eggs were also authentic.
author: Jeremy A.

description: The taste and style are the same as those you find in Hong Kong street food. Skip it if you expect something  American style because the taste, portion, and decoration are so original.
author: Patarida L.

description: My favorite place growing up. My parents even ate here before they had me. It's been 24 years and I'm still addicted to the food. The beef curry and rice is the best I have ever had. Also love the won ton noodle soup or beef noodle soup. The noodle is crisp and homemade, not overcooked and soggy.
author: TravelingHungry ..

description: Been going here since I was young. I ordered the beef tendon with dumplings and fun. Beef tendons were so good! They only gave me 2 dumplings! I don't know if I got screwed, he said those were the last 2, damn. My dish was around $8 and some change.
author: Karen T.

description: I use to come here pretty often as a kid and my parents and I remembered food being pretty good here. The 3 of us came here for lunch one day since we were walking past by. Place looks pretty much the same as we remembered. It's small. In terms of price, it wasn't cheap, pretty standard for price. But when we had gotten our food, portions are super tiny. My mom is not a big eater at all and she left hungry. I ordered their wonton noodle soup, my mom got their beef brisket ho fun and dad got a noodle dish is slightly spicy (don't remember the name of it). My dad is a pretty big eater but my mom is a small eater. We ate a total of about $22 and when we were done we left to go somewhere else to eat and had another portion. Super super disappointed about this place. Flavor wise it was overall bland, the rice noodle dish wasn't as good as I remembered it being and it also an extremely small portion. I think if you were feeding kids and yeah it can be enough but for adults I think maybe if they doubled their portions it would be good. Overall super disappointed and left very unsatisfied. I recommend going to "Yin Du Wonton Noodle" instead.
author: Tiffany Y.

description:
Won ton noodles is sort a standard food so perhaps the most useful way to review it is by comparison with another restaurant. I found it to be better than Yin Du. The flavor of the broth is richer, the noodles had a nice bite, and the won tons themselves had better flavor. There is a highly ranked and popular won ton place out in the Richmond district (name which I can't recall) and Hon's Wun Tun House is slightly better than that.

It's basically the best won ton noodle soup I've had so far. I'll still eat at Yin Du most of the time because it's less expensive, quick and pretty good. However, if I feel the desire for a best won ton noodle soup I know I can find it at Hon's Wun Tun House.
author: John W.

description:
The soup is bland! Watered-down chicken stock....
My moms makes way better wontons
The ho fun is not smooth, if you know what I'm talking about. 
The BBQ pork had no flavor. 
I'm not expecting polished silverware but don't serve me dirty spoons. 

I seriously don't understand why hella people be coming here? What are they thinking?
author: Yen Yen C.

description:
Good Wonton, Size of a wonton are the same size to that in Hong Kong or any other south east asian countries.

I also like their shrimps dumplings. Portion size are a little bit small. If you have 2 people in parties, then order 3 portion of noodle/ wonton in the menu.
author: Dan A.

description: i've been a customer of this Hon's wun tun house for countless years now & i got addicted to this place, best noodle for me in town! i always order #8 their shrimp dumpling is soooo good that i bought some raw ones last time plus their raw noodles! i want to try their beef soup with noodles next time but i'm a huge fan of #8!! good service the people working here are nice & they know me already by face! :) i highly recommend this place! if i'm in china town area i can't stay away from this place!!
author: Pinkangel U.

description: Flash news! Hon's is now (finally!) selling uncooked wontons to go. You can put them in your freezer (freeze on a cookie sheet so they don't stick together) and have this wonderful comfort food/treat any time!
author: Jane M.

description: First let me start off by saying that the wontons were great and the service was friendly and quick. Having said that, I was really disappointed! This place not only had good Yelp reviews but was also listed in an article as one of the top 50 lunch joints in SF. we all ordered the shrimp and pork wonton noodle soup. It was simple - wontons, noodles, broth, sliced scallions. The broth was borderline flavorless and the noodles were ok. Great for a cheap meal though! Only $5.49 a bowl. Good for a cheap filling meal, but don't expect any frills.
author: Brandi J.

description:
Love it! Good cheap eats from the hole in the wall restaurant in Chinatown. It's not immaculate, but none of the actual good eats in Chinatown are.

Got the bbq pork with wonton noodle soup. Came for dinner about 45 minutes before they close.

It's helpful if you can order in chinese, but the lady also speaks english.
Cash only.
author: Bonnie Y.

description:
Want to get in and out of lunch within 15 minutes after you sit down?  Try Hon's.  Service here is quick and efficient.  They normally don't do small talk but they will ask you how you're doing if you visit often enough.

This is a wonton place so please get some wonton noodles.  Lunch will run you about $4.  On a cold day, it's so nice to sip on soup and slurp up the noodles of the orient.  The wonton here don't rival my mom's or those of Mak's Noodle, the wonton king in Hong Kong, but for the amount of food and close-enough taste, it's worth it to stay in the 94108.
author: Winnie L.

description:
As a kid, I came here a lot with my sisters after Chinese school on Saturday mornings. We would always get here around 12, be quickly seated and ordered and never did we have to wait for our food for more than 5 minutes. The business hasn't changed since then.  

People say Hon's portions are small and they are. If you want wonton noodles but have a bigger appetite though, order the "wuntun meen ga dai," meaning that they'll add extra noodles to your bowl. Of course, you'd pay extra for it, but hey, if you're hungry, anything goes! The wontons are so-so, but I come here for the springy noodles and tasty broth. It's so good. I feel all warm and fuzzy inside after slurping a bowl down. 

If you are in the SF Chinatown area, this is definitely an establishment you do not want to pass up. The place is pretty cramped; you may need to share your table, but it's all part of the Hon's noodle experience.
author: Diana C.

description: The dumpling noodle soup was quite good and Was prepared quickly. Simple food done right.
author: Thomas H.

description:
Mom and pop shop located on the bustling street of Kearny. Perfect place for a get-in, get-out hole-in-a-wall restaurant.  
 
Be warned that this is the type of restaurant that it may get crowded to the point where you must share tables.  

A simple menu is plastered on the wall as well as a two sided laminated menu placed at each table. I usually like to go for a bowl of wonton noodle soup. They make a bowl for you right before your eyes as the chef is positioned right in from of the storefront window. That is freshness, baby!  
 
I believe they make their own noodles and wonton as well! The noodles are soft and tender and the wontons are miniature, so its perfectly bite-sized.
 
Cash only!
author: Becky Q.

description:
The only legit wonton place in the city, from my experience. 

Wontons here run a bit small but are the perfect blend of pork and shrimp in that wrapping that is divine. When so many people make theirs like one giant ball of shrimp, thank God someone is still doing it right. 

Noodles are crispy and tasty and merges magically with the wonton and the soup. Nothing ever overcooked and everything is always as we like it. 

Stewed Beef, shrimp dumplings, everything here is like home cooking with chefs that have done it for years. And yes they have been here since I was a little kid and they still recognize me even though I've changed a lot over the years. 

Portions are small; I can probably eat two bowls on the right days...but the price is cheap enough to make that work. 

If you're looking for the best wonton in the city, come here and end your journey.
author: Alfred D.

description:
I have been coming to the SF location for 30 years and before that at the original one in the  Vancouver B.C. location. I crave the noodles and wontons so often that even if I can't get there I will have someone I know pick up a bowl. 
Ignore the lack of decor and sometimes the staff can be a little gruff but the food is an authentic experience and enjoy the comfort of noodles that are still hadn made back in Vancouver.
Order a pound of noodles to take home and drop them in your favorite stock for a delicious midnight snack.
author: Citizen K.

description:
Actually not a bad wonton noodle place. 

Babe and I were walking around Chinatown and he brought me here because it was one of his favorite wonton places as a child. 
I wasn't extremely hungry, so I just grabbed all wontons and no noodles. The stuffing was very flavorful and I liked it quite a bit. One of the best I've had in the many Chinese joints I've tried. 

A great place to come if you're ever craving wonton noodles. Actually, writing this review is making me crave it. :( 

And just a tip, try not to sit near the bathroom, it reaks! It'll definitely be a distraction.
author: Harriet W.

description: The noodles are good but it's pricey and the portions are small.  There are comparable places that charges less.  Plus every time I go the lady there charges me more than I expect to pay off the menu, have no idea why that is.
author: Jackson Z.

description:
While this place has been an SF Chinatown tradition, it doesn't seem to live up to the hype.  Don't expect too much from this Chinatown hole in the wall.  For the price and speed, this place is fine.  

The beef tendon noodles was ok, but could use a little more meat.  I wouldn't make a special trip to come here.  They close at 7pm, so their focus is the lunch crowd.
author: Xiao B.

description: Homemade noodles and wun-tuns. They have secret recipe for making the soup. That's why the taste so special and tasty!
author: Carol T.

description:
I got the soup to go once before and I did not think it was anything special. I am so glad I came back and ate it there. The lady at the cash register is a little rude and impatient, but it is only because they are so busy! I am impressed by how quickly the food comes out considering how many people are there.

The flavors are incredible! I am excited to go back again!
author: Annette S.

description:
I love this place.  The noodles are the best in SF, and the broth is good as well (not too salty, not too rich, not too watery).  I try to stop by whenever I'm in the area because it's super authentic and delicious, and I've been going here since I was a kid and it hasn't changed at all.  

I would stick to the noodles in broth (either wun tun noodles or beef brisket) because that's their specialty!
author: Olivia L.

description:
The Chinese character for Hon, is actually closer to "Hung" or "Hohng" in Cantonese/Mandarin...same character in Chef Hung Taiwanese Beef Noodle in Irvine...or the famous won ton noodle and dried fried beef chow fun shop in Causeway Bay Hong Kong called Ho HUNG Kee.

Unfortunately Ho HUNG Kee and HON's are not related. Not even separated at birth or alternate dimension reality brother wannabe's.

It's no secret that wun tun meen (or won ton mein / WTM) is one of the definitive Hong Kong Cantonese old style comfort foods, and a symbol of homesickness. Homesick Taiwanese expats who've been away for a while, one of the things they have a hankering once they return is TW style beef noodle soup. Not sure if wun tun meen has that kind of equivalent fervor but I would hope so to an extent.

The ideal bowl of WTM is that of a mini snack size...served with a delicate yet complex broth of dried tilefish, shrimp shells (and shrimp roe for the nitpicky). Won tons delicately wrapped with silky smooth skin having excess slack to create a goldfish tail visual effect, with well balanced ratios of upper back leg pork and freshwater river shrimp (fresh product of course, not from frozen). The soup spoon should rest in the mini bowl first, with won tons resting on the spoon, then finally al dente toothsome elastic ideally bamboo pole kneaded egg noodles (more ideally made with duck eggs and alkali water) are cooked quickly in boiling water, strained then poured on top. And for a final touch, a drizzle of good ol' fashion LARD (aka pig oil, oink oink) to make it complete. Then some years ago, it became fashionable to bash this style for being too expensive with small portions, and the market evolved to competitions offering bigger bowls, siu mai dim sum sized won tons with no goldfish tail-esque slack, and a shrimpless broth replaced by Chinese Buddha fruit. Of course the traditionalists told the new style to go "diu lei lo mo" (basically something involving copulation with someone else's maternal unit). The sad thing is that now even in Hong Kong, the definitive bowl is pretty much starting to become non existent where you get maybe 2 out of 3 right, but still aeons and light years ahead of Northern California.

Why am I telling you this?

It's to frame everything within a particular context. 

Here in the SF Bay Area, you'd be hard pressed to find someone who does 1.5 of the 3 key components right (broth, noodles, won tons).

Hon's is an old style noodle house, as if Father Time took his polaroid, took a snapshot, and kept it frozen in time. That is, no innovation (and no improvement over the years). It's nice that before 10 am, this place is open and you could have WTM for a breakfast/brunch, and it will provide sufficient fuel to go shopping and strolling.

Hon's is probably the last (if not a small handful) place I know of that makes their own egg noodles in house, along with ju cheung fun (steamed plain rice rolls), as well as won ton skins. You can actually purchase these to go, which is a rare thing so see these days.

However even with that said, there are things about the WTM that are worth mentioning

- one bowl of WTM is a small snack portion, within the $5 mark. For traditionalists, this is about right, but for those looking to fill up stomach space will need to get another bowl of something or eat more elsewhere.

- the egg noodles unfortunately lack a lot of egg flavor...in fact it's not just Hon's but even supermarket bought Chinese egg noodles. But if you get the Vietnamese Chinese/Chiu Chow egg noodles, those are way more robust for some reason, but then that's not HK Cantonese anymore

- the won ton noodle broth...no idea what's in it. It's light and decent, but no dried tilefish flavor, and absolutely no shrimp or shrimp shells. It's not horrible, but it's definitely lacking

- the won tons are VERY enjoyable here and probably the saving grace. Visually attractive, small and decent bite sized (one bite literally) with a smooth delicate skin, with some excess slack (but not too much). Sure beats those golf ball siu mai's posing as won tons.

- the steamed rice rolls here are ok...unfortunately they're pre made (vs steamed to order) and already cooled to room temperature. When you request an order, the kind older lady snips them into bite sized little rolls, and NUKES them. Had they been resteamed instead, the texture would have improved a hundred fold. It didn't help that the sauces applied were lackluster (only 2 kinds), a crucial factor in the enjoyment of this deceptively simple yet messy/fugly looking snack.

To make a much better bowl, I'd take:

the noodles from King of Won Ton on Irving
the broth from Cooking Papa
the won tons from here 

for my WTM. But that's unrealistic.

This is one of those places where it's so old and old style, that they even bother to make some of these low brow high labor low profit margin items, even without putting a whole lot of effort in, is still appreciated.
author: Ken K.

description: Not as good as yin du. the broth is not as flavorful and the wontons are not as good. they overcharged me on my small bowl of wonton noodles. service is non existent. main problem is that the broth is bland.  I expected more from a place called wonton house.
author: J. W.

description:
So I wrote lyrics to the song that the old Chinese guy with the spinach goatee plays on his two-string, bow-fiddle. You know which one I'm talking about...he plays in the Muni stations and on the sidewalk next to Union Square. He's not popular like the plastic drummers because, well, it sounds like a cat dying, so I thought I should help him out...

Come to Hon's Wun-Tun...
Where you have loads of fun,
And you don't need lots of mun'
To slurp a bowl o'wonton.
So leave at home your gun,
And venture outside for sun.
But don't expect a big pork bun
'Cause all they got is a ton of won
And stewed intestines second to none.
It won't make your stomach run
Come see how the East was won
No need to wear your crinoline
OK, my song is done.

I haven't been here for years, so my return visit was not full of surprises. It's still the same non-descript place on Kearny. It's still the same old guy standing in the back waiting to give you a glass of water. I think it's still the same menu...in fact, I left that stain the last time I came, I think.

I sat at the semi-bright yellow counter like a good solitary diner that I am and went for the $4.95 bowl of Stewed Brisket of Beef and Wun-Tun Noodle in Soup (see my photo). The bowl is a bit on the small size, but it was chock full of beef parts, thin noodles, and yes, wonton...or is it wun-tun? I dunno...I just eat here. You can be in and out of there in fifteen minutes. It's not the French Laundry after all.

FOOD - 4 stars...a warm and cheap bowl of goodness
AMBIANCE - 2.5 stars...oh Chinatown, my Chinatown
SERVICE - 3.5 stars...fast, no fuss, no muss
TOTAL - 4 stars...a good penny-watcher lunch if you ask me
author: Ed U.

description:
Wonton noodle soup is one of the comfort foods that I have set a high standard for myself. Continuing down memory lane while visiting SF Chinatown, I thought it may be time for me to re-visit and pay tribute to Hon's, a landmark eatery in Chinatown well known for their wontons.

I wonder if this is just my personal preference. I like my wontons small and bite sized with soft silky wrappers so that they can slide down my throat. I don't care for the bigger ones that are the size of shumais (dumplings) or even worse when the wonton skins are thick and doughy in texture. The size of Hon's wontons seems to be a perfect fit for me and my throat! You can order a bowl of just wontons in a savory broth or a bowl of wonton noodle soup with fresh and springy al dente egg noodles. The wontons are stuffed with ground pork and shrimp that are marinated in sesame oil. Man are these yummy? I do recall Hon's wonton noodle soup to be without peers 30 years ago although I am not so sure if it is still unsurpassed today. My other favorite item in the menu is curry beef stew over rice that is still good as ever. I try to figure why their curry is still a stand out and the secret I concluded may be the curry powder they use and of course in part due to the beef fat. The beef is simmered for hours until the meat is tender. The menu is not as extensive as some other Chinese restaurant but there are still a lot more in the menu I have to try.

As far as the ambience goes, I remember the place was pretty run down 30 years ago and there have not been any noticeable improvements, remodels or clean ups done since then. As with any old restaurants in Chinatown, you have to learn to eat with one eye closed and hope the food would sit well in your stomach. The service is efficient and surly and I don't think the help expects a good tip either.
author: Geoff G.

description:
Passing by this little hole in the wall on my quick walks on Kearny, I never made it in until a couple of days ago when I was in search of some jook.  They, obviously, being a wun ton house, don't have jook.  So,  I made a mental note to come back and try out their wonton (wun ton).

Surprisingly, I actually made it back here yesterday.  Wanting something quick, easy, and basic, I opted for their #1, Wun Ton Noodles at $3.60.  They said it would be a five minute wait, so I grabbed a seat a the counter and watched the happenings of this place.  There's one guy who runs the whole won ton show by the window.  He gets the order, and sets about getting the noodles, wonton and whatever toppings you ordered for your bowl of dumplings.

Then there are the two waitresses who take your orders and collect the money.  They'll also bring out the food to you too.  Don't forget, there are a couple of other men running around busing tables and the like.  They have a lot of people in this tiny place, but they are fast and efficient.  They set you down with a plastic cup of hot tea, a pair of chopsticks, and a soup spoon.  Condiments like hot sauce, soy sauce, vinegar, etc. are available if you so desire.  (However, if you want any of those condiments to go, good luck!  They don't have any containers for this stuff, you'll just have to dump it into your soup.)

Their menu has 46 items, and that's including the rice and soda!  It's pretty basic though, and you can't go wrong with a dumpling order.

My order was ready and I brought it back to work.  I found about six small dumplings (tasty little buggers) and a decent about of egg noodles in a plastic container.  It was piping hot and I was burning my tongue with each slurp of noodles.  Oh well.

Not a bad place at all when you want something quick and easy.  And for that price, how can you ever complain?  I would be curious about their brisket and stuff too.

Sidenote: When looking around, I just had to wonder what their health inspection card would say.  Believe it or not...it was right there posted behind the counter!  They got a 96%, and that was just last week!  (Or was it a 76%?  Can someone please go by there and doublecheck for me?!)  Anyway, they must be doing something right in Chinatown!
author: Teri C.

description: Hot wonton egg noodle soup around 5 dollars? Sign me up! This is one of my goto spots around FIDI. Perfect place for a cheap, quick meal on a cold day.I've tried the   wonton egg noodle soup, stewed beef noodle soup, tea eggs, and curry fish balls. The portions are slightly small, but you have options of adding more noodles, wontons, vegetables, etc. The tea eggs taste like your standard tea eggs while the curry fish balls seem to barely have any sauce on them. More sauce and flavor would help a lot. Either way, this is a great spot to go to for a quick, cheap lunch if you work in the area!
author: Tim L.

description:
Delicious wonton soup.  

I visited this place during my recent trip to SF, not having been back for a few years.  I'm ad to say they no longer have almond paste for sale to go, but I'm glad to see the old owners in good health and running this staple joint.  They still sell their freshly made noodles, and though the wontons went up in price by a little, still tasty I say, and I'll still be back on my next trip.
author: Annie H.

description:
I really like this place! Hits the spot on a cold day, and not too strong with any overwhelming flavors. The portion is somewhat on the smaller side, so if you're a big eater like me, I like to add in extra meat or noodles for only a dollar more. Lunch can get crowded on some days, but otherwise, they try to seat everyone (i.e. share tables). 

Food comes out quickly, so there's not really a long wait. You can one of the guys making noodles by the window. Come here if you're looking for something comforting! Would definitely come here again for lunch! :)
author: Kristine T.

description: You can get much better food in the neighborhood for the same or lower price. Portion is small and food is meh. The rice roll is a huge joke. Dish with rice is basically just rice. Wouldn't come back & wouldn't recommend.
author: Aki J.

description: While visiting San Fran, we found the positive reviews on yelp  for this place walking distance from our hotel, Orchard Garden, and decided to give it a try. We ordered the dumplings (nice size) with noodles, #8, and enjoyed it very much. It wasn't a huge portion but for the price it was fair. If you want vegetables, you have to order it as an extra item. Fast service, even though she told us it will take a little longer for the dumplings. Complimentary tea, extremely basic decor. They open at 9 am even though the sign says 9:30 am and yelp shows 11am. Before heading back to LA in the morning, we had to go back one more time for another bowl. It was that good. We will go back for sure  the next time we are in town.
author: Dragonanna C.

description:
You have to understand this hole in the wall is in China Town and borders the FiDi.  Service is brusk and impersonal.  During the lunch rush, you may need to share a small table with other diners.  This is normal here.

If you can get past this, you will be rewarded with a hot bowl of egg noodle soup with wun tuns (#1) for less than $5.  Totally worth it.  Their egg noodles are the perfect diameter (thin) and have the right bite.  The wun tuns are delicious packets of ground pork and minced shrimp.  The broth is savory and seasoned well.  I've never gotten a raging headache after eating here but maybe I'm not sensitive to MSG?

And bring cash because they don't take plastic.
author: Khuyen H.

description:
I love this spot!

Have been coming here since I was a little kid.  Nothing really changes which is what I like about them.  The prices are still very cheap comparatively to food cost.  The ambiance is very old school like, but it's a really nice old school kind of feel.  

The noodles are top notch.  This is real noodles. Not the fake ones out there that cost $20+ dollars a bowl.
author: Bernie C.

description:
Charge me an extra $1.50 on top of the 5.99 for no explained reason. You only put noodles in my beef and wonton soup. Oh yes, all fat beef brisket, and like 3 won tons. And although i asked for veggies, i got 3 stems of something and a couple broken tops. Crap service and food. Threw it out ($8.20).

For $6.50 go to New Hong Kong Menu around the corner. Maybe I'm just spoiled, but they have the best quality i've found in my lunch explorations throughout Chinatown

Hon's sucks.
author: Adam X.

description:
Uh, delicious, cheap and homemade? Yess pleasseee. The BF and I typically make a stop here for a "pre dinner" snack (or just a normal snack) whenever we drive to SF. Yes, it's a little hole in the wall place, but I think that's what adds to the charm. 

I love the wonton soup and tea eggs; he always gets the noodle soup. If you're looking to get full, you might want to order more than one bowl.
author: Michele P.

description: Want some homemade old school wonton noodle soup? Check out Hon's Wun Tun House! The portions are rather small, but the prices reflect that. A bowl of wonton noodle soup is about $6 which makes this restaurant reasonable on your wallet. It's also across the street from Portsmouth Square and Chinatown is up the block. They haven't done much remodeling, but it's the food that matters, right?
author: Edgar G.

description:
This place is way too expensive for what it is, but it's been around for ever and there's no one else in the vicinity doing HK style hole in the wall won-ton noodles.

In HK, you find these restaurants on every corner...
author: Laurence H.

description:
I read many of the reviews below. 
1) People are too generous with their ratings. 
2) For some people, expectations are way too high or unrealistic. I guess I don't blame them since the other reviews raved about how good everything is . It hyped them up...

It's a decent place, a bit gritty, and very much old school. The food is decent. Good? Maybe. Great? Not so much. 

You don't go for decor, the great wait staff, or the fine dining experience. You don't go for all that hype and endless 5 star ratings on Yelp. 

I go for respect. They are doing their thing and going at it one day at time. They are their to work, pay their bills, support their kids, and just to survive. It is decent food at decent prices. Slow down and appreciate. Have a bowl of noodle soup. History. Respect.
author: Ethan L.

description: Good spot for noodles around the office.  it's mainly asian ppl in there so I knew I was in good company.  Definitely gets packed so go at like 11:30 for lunch.  Definitely get won-tons there.
author: christopher h.

description: Delicious soup. Broth is super legit, noodles are firm, and wontons are nice and chewy. Service actually isn't that bad, the owners are just a bit blunt. My tea got refilled very quickly and the soup came out in less than a minute. Prices are cheap, about a dollar more than Yin Du Wonton, but the soup is better imo.
author: Matt W.

description:
This place is great. 

Food:
1. The broth is the same in most of their soups. Very good!

2. #1 is a favorite for everyone; long and thin ramen noodles with "wun tuns." Simple, good and very comfortable.

3. I love #20. Shanghai Noodle with Salted Snow Cabbage and Pork. Shanghai noodles somewhat compare to thick spaghetti noodles for size comparison. Add chili oil and white pepper. This dish is fresh, warm, has just enough salty flavor from the pork and cabbage and is topped with a nice refreshing bite of green onion garnish. 
** There are two menus. One of them says this dish is called "Shanghai Noodle with Meat." Just look over both if you want to know exactly what you are getting. There are only 36 items on the menu, so it won't take long to glance. 

4. Rumor has it they make most of their noodles in house from scratch! Even better! 

~ You really can't go wrong with anything you order here.

Tips:
It's busy during lunch hours, so a mid-afternoon snack is great if you want to try during off peak hours. 

Enjoy!
author: Rox T.

description:
When I want wontons, this is the place to go. It's a dinky little restaurant, but all I care about is how my food tastes.  I had to come here within days of coming back from Hong Kong because I was in a wonton withdrawal. Try the 'sui gao' (dumplings) which are pretty similar to wontons but differ a bit in size. 

I wish I was there RIGHT NOW!
author: C. Z.

description:
Won ton noodle soup is good. Their dumpling (shui jiao) soup is also pretty good. I always get a combination of these. Can't comment on the rest of the menu. 

Definitely a hole in the wall, and the service is perfunctory. Not friendly, not horrible, but they will take your order, give you tea and food, and take your money. That's all I'm looking for.

A bit pricey by Chinatown standards (small bowl of noodle soup for $5), but it's at the bottom of the hill of Chinatown, closer to Financial District so it's a prime location. Good for them, they know their niche.

If you want bigger portions, better service and cleaner restaurant, I suggest Yin Du Wonton on Pacific. It's priced at $4-5, menu is slightly different but serves Hong Kong noodle soup too. Wontons aren't as tasty as Hon's though, but it's just a preference. Usually alternate between the two for lunch, but laziness sometimes wins out...
author: Kiki J.

description:
My mother took me here for lunch yesterday; we both ordered the lamb with wide rice noodles and then shared a third bowl of wontons with thin noodles. 

The restaurant itself is really clean and small on a quiet and clean street.  It's hidden away from the bustle of Chinatown but if you walked a block up the hill then you hit all the super busy grocery/fresh food stores.

I hear that it's really busy here on weekdays when the office workers come here for their lunch feasts.  You can definitely have a feast here since the prices are relatively low (all our medium size bowls of food were under 5 dollars).  You get a free tall cup of hot tea and the wait is minimum.  It's more efficient than IKEA.  You sit down and get your order and food in under ten minutes.  On a Saturday afternoon, all I saw were Asian elders.  I think the price and the fact that the food is really authentic and the basic broth is very simple (not too salty) makes this a really nice place to eat and run without feeling as if you just drank half a cup of oil and msg.  

The flavors are very clean, a purist's dream.  You can taste the unadulterated natural flavors of the lamb and its' juices in the soup and it's really reminiscent of eating a good simple meal at home.  The wontons are small but I enjoyed the whole tender shrimp and it's flavored just right.  Recommended if you happen to be in Chinatown.
author: Lorissa W.

description: A whole in a wall joint. Small table and chairs.  Some stools along the counter.  Wontons are small.  Noodle tastes fresh.  Pour over some msg filled soup base and there you go. Looking for a light meal under $5 -6. This is it.  It's A-OK in my book.
author: Elliot Y.

description: I was really excited to try this place because of how legit it looked from the outside, with the cooks in the window. I ordered the wonton noodle soup and was a little disappointed. The wontons were pretty small and there were too many noodles in proportion to the amount of wontons you get. The noodles were also a little hard for my liking. The broth was kind of bland. Overall, it was a good deal - only $5 something for a filling bowl of noodles - but not the best.
author: Jamie C.

description:
OMG delicious tea smoked five spice eggs!  First time I've ever tried them and they are fantastic.

There goes my cholesterol...
author: .Hon H.

description:
If you know me and follow my reviews, you know I'm a noodle soup connoisseur (100% self-proclaimed). I also love me some beef. So imagine my happiness to find this BEEF NOODLE SOUP was just blocks from my abode. 

The place itself is super run down - it looks like a chinese diner (if you can imagine). An old lady and man were running the counter. I ordered the beef noodle soup with rice noodles to go. The old man efficiently began cooking the noodles while I paid the woman (cash only). I love quick service! 

I got home and enjoyed a nice steaming bowl of noodle soup. The rice noodles were cooked perfectly but there were only a few nuggets of beef. So disappointing. The broth was pretty flavorful but there wasn't enough of it. 

Also, a small complaint but the noodles and soup were packaged together - if I had a further walk, this could be a problem (via sogginess). I wish they put them separately but I understand the need to consolidate. 

Would come back, especially with the price. Can't be beat!
author: Carmen K.

description: Been here for YEARS! I love it here. This is a complete hole in a wall, and it's only open M-F, during the day times. Obviously you have wonton soup w. noodles, but what I like to order is beef stew with the wide rice noodles, and a side of just wonton dumpling soup. Yup! The only other time I've had wontons this delis was back in the motherland, HK. Get it while they're still here. It's the same people working this place since I could remember, and they are getting old. I could go for a nice hot bowl now :)
author: Vanessa K.

description:
The 2008/2009 reviews give this place 4-5 stars, I guess that was awhile ago.  Today I popped in for a quick lunch.  Ordered a curried beef stew rice plate.  The portion was small, barely tasted like curry.  

Half way thru my meal, they gave me my check and wanted to split the table.  Five minutes later the waitress forgot she already gave me a bill and was writing another bill for me.  Come-on get your head into the game.  I will not be back.
author: Rich W.

description:
Yum.
Proper Wonton mein.
they make the noodles them selves which is a major plus.
Really tasty. However bowls are small. 
Order sides to go along or you'll still be hungry.
Or order 2 bowls...

yum,
-Herbal Tea
author: H T.

description: I just ordered my first bowl of beef stew wonton noodle soup here.  What I received was three tiny wontons and two edible tiny pieces of beef - the rest was all fat pieces.   It was tasty for sure but the portion size was very dissatisfying.  I was pretty upset that I paid  $7 for basically noodles that I can easily make at home for 79 cents and taste just as good.  I will never go back.
author: S L.

description:
Great place for beef stew won ton noodle soup for about $5.  The noodles have a good texture.  I like to add a little red vinegar to each spoonful of noodles.  The food here is tasty and cheap!

I know people complained about the size of the won tons, but I like the fact that the won tons aren't too big.  It's the perfect size for each bite.  This place can get a bit busy and you might have to share a table if you're in a small party and take a big table.  

The restaurant is humble - has everything you need.  This isn't a place where you go for the ambiance.  It's all about the food.  Kinda takes you back to a hole in the wall in Hong Kong.
author: Julia C.

description:
Wow what a hidden gem for really good won ton noodle soup and for only $3.60!
Thanks to my co-worker for sharing this awesome find! I'll definitely be coming back here for lunch...
author: Helen Y.

description: The food here is well north of dissatisfied. If you like Vietnamese food, look elsewhere. This is below average for San Francisco.
author: John Z.

description: Epitome of a Chinese hole in the wall. Don't get me wrong, I love AND grew up in Chinatown, so I know great Chinese food when I taste it. I was a bit disappointed by this place after reading all the great reviews. They ran out of ho-fun when I got there and was only left with the egg noodles. The prices are also more expensive than I'm used to paying, especially because after I received the food, the quantity definitely didn't match up to what it cost. The soup wasn't bad but not great. The service is also minimal and you have to catch the woman's attention, even when there's only two other tables in the restaurant.
author: Connie C.

description:
You'll have to bare with me, and my reasoning for my 5 stars this time.

My trips to San Francisco as a child consisted of quite a few things:
Stopping by my uncle's place at the Castro, swinging down Pier 39 and eating some good stuff, Haight-Ashbury to pick up some comics and scenery, and finally, lunch at Hon's Wun Tun House.

I actually didn't know what it was called until I recently stopped by again a few years ago.

And a few things I remember about the place have still remained: the proprietor (I assume Mr. Hon himself) manning the Wun Tuns, the rest of the workers folding and making the delicious Wun Tuns and serving the tea and noodles.

There was never any pretense as to why anyone went here; it certainly wasn't conversation, interesting Tchotchkes, or anything else.  It was the Wun Tuns.

And by God, after all these years, it tastes the same. 

The noodles with a nice chewy texture, the soup lightly flavored, and made perfect by adding hot sauce or peppers you add yourself.  And the Wun Tuns...oh my. The food, the ambiance of sitting in a place that hasn't changed for decades...its perfect to me.

A simple bowl of soup, Wun Tuns, Noodles, and maybe some BBQ Pork if i'm in the mood, and i'm 8 again with my parents.

I took a few friends around here, and while they don't share the same sentiments I do about the place, they certainly enjoyed themselves.

To summarize all the feelings I have: I can't wait to go back.
author: Julian J.

description:
This is a dirty little dive with the best soup. When you walk past and always see a packed restaurant this is a great sign. 

The wait staff is rude, blunt and talks to me in Cantonese. I can only guess as to what they are saying, it's definitely entertainment worth paying for. I always get the, "Number 1", Basic Won-Ton Noodle Soup. I highly suggest that if you want an authentic Won-Ton Noodle soup this is the place to go.

The best part is when I pay my $4.60 for the soup and give the cashier a five she then takes my money, throws my change down on the counter, and turns away its hilarious. Two stars just for the attitude and two for the great soup.

I've been here at least a dozen times and with similar results each time. The food is really good and the wait staff is in no hurry to rush you out the door while being somewhat attentive.

Please do come here and enjoy some of the best Wun-Tun soup in San Francisco.
author: Justin S.

description:
Wonton noodle is probably one of my comfort foods. I like their thin egg noodles with wontons and BBQ Pork. The portion is a bit small for the price you paid. I wish there're some greens (chopped spring onions) to garnish the dish. Well, it's Chinese fast food - what do I expect? 

Overall, it's cheap and tastes great. There could have been more shrimps in the wontons. Anyways, I'll come back here again for my comfort food.
author: Saran R.

description: I have sanitary concerns for this place...I think their food is excellent and the wait for food is next to nothing, but dropping a won tun on the table and serving it anyways is uncalled for.
author: Courtney C.

description:
This place reminds me of the Seinfeld Soup Nazi episode.  My favorite is the Noodle Soup and an order of the Rice Rolls.

Just remember they aren't super friendly.  They won't know your name like what's that bar where everyone knows your name.  


Follow these instructions: 

1) Order quick.  
2) No staring or reckless eyeballing.  
3) Just focus on the fact that the food you're about to eat is AMAZING and AUTHENTIC.  
4) Pat yourself on the back too because, this place very inexpensive.  I mean you'll be full for like 4.50.
author: Amro R.

description: Hon's Wun Ton is totally old school won ton, like the stuff I grew up with. I always get the wonton noodle, and sometimes wonton noodle with beef stew. The beef stew is really tasty with lots of gristle and some tendon, exactly the way it's supposed to be served. The wonton has pork and and shrimp, and the egg noodles are made freshly at the store. Hon's is nothing fancy, and probably nothing has changed in about 40 years. The prices are low and the serving sizes are small, so maybe you might want to order two bowls if you're hungry.
author: Allen T.

description:
Hon's wun tun has been one of the longest running institution in Chinatown. It's good, cheap, and extremely fast. The flavor, taste, and texture is exactly how it was 30+ years ago. I personally believe they can update their menu and fix it up a little but it's sorta like dive bars. You kinda just want to accept them for who they are, a Chinese hole in a wall in Chinatown. 

Are there better won ton houses? Yes. It's just something about this place that brings back memories of my childhood. This place is honestly a 3 star establishment but an extra star for the memories.
author: jason g.

description:
This place has been here seemingly for ages, and looks like they're still going strong.  My friend and I settled for dinner here last week after going to Hing Lung on Broadway and finding them closed (seems like for good, according to recent Yelp reviews).

I enjoy the aroma once you step inside.  I know I'm inside a won ton noodle place right away from that.  The prices are still excellent.  The won ton pieces are a bit small but they're still good.  I love their soup also.
author: H K.

description:
Small noodle shack, small portions cheap price, hot noodles. 

If that's not your style, this place aint for you. Cheap asian food that is authentic--service  and ambience not the greatest, but the food and speed is great. 

The wontons are really good, soup and noodles are typical. But not bad overall.
author: Ryan C.

description: This place deserves 5 stars for it's wonton noodles alone. My family (we are Chinese) have been coming here for decades, and we love the perfect wontons and soup stock and al dente noodles despite the smaller portion sizes. (My brother still complains about the small bowls each and every time, like he didn't know they were that size.) be sure to get the curried fish balls, and to try the curry beef stew over rice or as a side to share. Their shui gow is pretty outstanding too.
author: Grams B.

description:
Good beef brisket (either in noodle soup or over rice). Also, excellent won tons in soup. The soup base has depth and flavor - I sometimes order a bowl of plain soup in addition to my meal and drink it up. This is how authentic Cantonese beef soup is supposed to taste.

Most of the waitstaff were born during the Mesozoic era. They survived the comet that killed the dinosaurs. You may have to speak clearly and loudly to be understood. Service is perfunctory, as if that needs to be said.

Overall, great value for money. Have eaten here many times and never gotten food poisoning, so they are sanitary (or sanitary enough). Just ignore the person who is filling and folding wontons in the dining room - where else is she supposed to do it, anyway?
author: W. T.

description: This place was a'ight, not the greatest, but certainly not the worst.  It does offer very reasonable prices.  I think that I would rather go down the street into Chinatown and pay a bit more for something a bit tastier.  But definitely serviceable.
author: Dave N.

description: Went here because saw it on Bourdain's list of recommendations. Food was quick for being freshly prepared. Won tons were flavorful, but seemed like a lot of the side dishes were being nuked in a microwave. Also, portions were small, but I managed to get full. Noodles are very al dente--if you're not used to Hong Kong style, it will seem drier than most (even though it is in soup). Soup tastes of everyone else's orders because everything is cooked in one pot by the chef--not a bad thing, but no separate flavors if you order different dishes.
author: Anna M.

description:
While visiting SF, I came here to get a bowl of won ton soup with noodles. The broth wasn't too flavorful, a little bland, but everything else about the soup was great! 
I added in some hot chili paste, and it gave the broth a little bit of more flavor!
I loved the old man who was cleaning up, and pouring hot tea for the customers. :)
author: Peggy K.

description: My BF loves noodles and soup.  After having delicious dim sum snacks, we walked here to share a regular bowl of noodles.  Broth, dumplings, and noodles all tasty.  Price cannot be beat.  They serve a really nice hot tea gratis.  They make the egg noodles there and I saw a couple people purchase the fresh noodles to take home with them.
author: E T.

description:
I give this place a five stars not for the ambiance nor the service but the food.  The food is simple but great.  I always get the #10, won ton noodle soup with the beef brisket.

The service is slow because the people who work there are old Chinese employees.  The food is brought out fast and if you go at lunch time, there is usually a long wait out the door.
author: Thand H.

description:
I love this place. Every time I came down  to SF, I always make time to come to this place and dine here. Don't let the interior/exterior fool you. This mom and pop place delivers the authenticity and deliciousness of the food. I never order the noodle so I can't say anything on their noodle. But the wonton itself is great. What my sister and I have always ordered: pig's feet, curry beef, beef tendon, a bowl of wonton, and rice. I could eat this everyday....the feet were very tender and cooked in a soy sauce based. the tendon has a little kick to it since it was cooked in chili oil but they were very tender too...

Can't' wait to be back again and pig out :)
author: Jennifer W.

description: The old people that run this place are hard working. The food is great and affordable. My only complaint is that they only give you 3 wonton. That's OK though. You can add more pieces at a low cost.
author: Niroth K.

description:
I like this place for a quick, small meal. And I mean small. My family used to come here for food that was very similar to what my parents had in HK. The won ton portions are pretty small, compared to others in the city, but its GOOD.  The won ton's are really yummy. Small and perfect in just one bite. Yum!!  Usually, its good to get one noodle soup (won ton or sury gow is best!) and then some side of veggie or something.

Something to make note of - check your bill before leaving.  Last time I went, they wanted to charge us nearly 12 bucks for 2 people's won ton soups...and that should only have been about $10-11.  Yes, I know 1 buck is stingy, but its the principle of the matter!!  After asking them, the staff realized they told us the number for the soup in take out (50 cents per container), and adjusted accordingly. My partner in won ton crime went there before and they may have over charged there too...
author: Lily W.

description: Honestly the price for the food there is much more expensive than Any other restaurant in San Francisco , however , the quality is much more behind. I can find any better one in Chinatown but cost less and more delicious. So regret myself didn't take a look the menu first!!!!! Don't waste money there, honestly !
author: Babebaby Z.

description: 1st Timers! DO NOT GO BY WEBSITE PRICES! HAHA! What our office mates calculated as $24 became $42! Wth! At what we thought was a reasonable price for Won Ton noodle soup is too expensive with its current price. Really? $7 for Won Ton. You can get a humongous bowl of Pho at Sai's for $8.
