The owner got mad at us too for not knowing the prices! Lol! Like it was our fault. He also says," This is not Chinatown, I don't give discount here!" Uh, Kearny & Clay is Chinatown and secondly, we didn't ask for a discount. Oh well, lesson learned. 1st and LAST time going to this place.
author: Johann M.

description: Good solid wun tuns. I ordered the wun tun with noodle and bbq pork one rainey afternoon. Soup came fast and was hot. I sat at the counter. It is def. a dive old run down diner type place. If you ignore the decor and just focus on getting some wun tuns then this place is for you.
author: Zannie S.

description:
When we've got time to kill or want to treat ourselves to a fantastic bowl of won tons, this is where we'll head. I honestly think this is the best in the city! As asian as it gets, and in the heart of Chinatown.

Portions are probably smaller than what places in the Sunset or Richmond offers, but it doesnt matter! It's just plain goodness and cheap! Wontons are fresh, smooth, bite size and tastes great. They keep it simple and do it right.

I'm not a big fan of shrimp and abhor places who's wontons only consist of 2 large pieces of shrimp and wrap. And I also know people that love that, to each their own.

Their curry beef brisket is VERY tender and has such depth, you can taste it's been cooking for hours. They're not shady and give you a heaping serving of tendons either, it's a good mix.

Parking is just super tough in the area and they're not open on Sunday =/
author: Ly T.

description:
I was running errands downtown and suddenly I realized how hungry I was! I've always been a sucker for noodles, so I gave this place a try. 

Don't let the exterior throw you off. It's the type of place where my mother would use the first pot of tea they send out to clean off the chopsticks and plate. 

I got the noodles with beef brisket. The soup base was tasty, the beef was tender and the noodles were hand-made and cooked to perfection.

It's a perfect hole-in-the-wall spot for authentic chinese noodles.
author: Susan W.

description:
I really don't understand some of the reviews about this place.  Ive been coming to this place all my life and have never had a bad experience with the food.

They make their own egg noodles which I think are amazing.  They don't taste as processed like all the other places that server won ton noodle soup.  

I usually only get 2 things here.  The Beef Stew Won Ton Noodle Soup Dry and Curry Beef Stew.  As you can tell I like Beef Stew and for those of you who go and try it please know its not your lean beef stew. Its got tendons and fat the way beef stew should be made so don't blame me when you go and say OMG the beef stew was so FATTY.  Don't go then.

CONS: The price doesnt equal the portions.  I need to eat 2 bowls  just to be satisfied.  Still good tho!
author: King L.

description:
Best wontons ever! The hot sauce, soup base, and egg noodles (thin) is one of the best! I remember try used to make their wontons fresh. Although the quality isn't as good as it used to be, it is still my favorite noodle spot. 

This is definitely a hole in the wall. DO NOT use their bathroom as it might turn you away! I wouldn't recommend sitting upstairs as it gets really hot where I'm just eating with a tank top on. 

Portions are small. I usually beast 2 or 3 bowls easy. Prices have gone up but not the portions.
author: Dee Z.

description: Best wonton noodles. Noodles is "QQ" and love the little wonton. Very tasty ... I like they use porcelain bowls and wooden chopstick. Feel very traditional and environmentally friendly.
author: JayJay L.

description: We had their tea eggs and dumpling soup this afternoon.  Tea eggs were marinated thoroughly and have so much flavor.  Dumplings were small but very fresh.  You can taste the minced shrimps and pork with tons of mushrooms in every bite.  Perfect size for a snack.  It's now on my "return" list:
author: Yvette F.

description: this place rocks, sometimes there's a lil old lady making wun tuns at the table right next to you.  This place is real home made and legit, best wun tuns in SF.
author: marco f.

description:
The noodle itself is very good!! I think probably the best I have eaten in Cali so far. 

However the won ton is kind of a little sorry.. Very small and not consistent. Some have a small piece of shrimp in it, and some just meat... 

The oil veggies were good, just like how they do it in Hong Kong. Every surface is coated with oil ;) not the most healthy vegetable dish, but it's tasty. 

The spicy beef tendon noodle was ok. The tendon is nice and soft, but nothing special. 

Overall it's A-OK, as it reminds me of Hong Kong won ton place.
author: Coco L.

description: Solid mother-approved hole in the wall. The BBQ pork over rice rocked. And cheap! No ambiance to speak of.
author: Andrew K.

description: Still going strong. CBS is still the bomb..... I will travel for miles (and do) for this Curry Beef Stew.
author: Dabin L.

description: I had to try this hole in the wall establishment in the heart of Chinatown.  This small little diner had a dingy old feel to it.  I don't know how long this place has been here, but if I had to guess, I would say well over 40 years.  Despite it's damp decor, the service was quite fast and the food wasn't bad.  The wonton noodles had a firm chewy texture to it and the wontons were quite good, although a little on the small side.  The broth though was not that flavorful.  We also ordered the beef brisket noodle soup.  The beef brisket also could have used a bit more salt, but not bad.  If you want to try a real wonton noodle house, you have to come here, this is as authentic as it gets.  Side note the restrooms in this place are downstairs past the kitchen.  It's a little scary down there...
author: David Y.

description: The rice roll is definitely overrated. But the wunton soup is pretty good. The beef tendon is great. It would be awesome if they have other types of noodle for people to choose though. Overall, Not sure if it is the best in the city but it is quite worth the 15 min walk to get it to-go for lunch.
author: Yiwei C.

description:
I used to really LOVE this place.

I liked their thin silky wantun skin with well seasoned shrimp / pork fillings.  Choice of thin noodles - never over cooked.
I liked their soy based soup as well.

So why 3 star? Why did I stop eating at Hon's?
I saw the lady making wontun at the counter.  She was wearing a pair of plastic gloves.  Then I saw her blowing her nose with their small napkin without taking her gloves off.  DISGUSTING

I no longer eat at Hon's....
author: Chie J.

description:
LOVE LOVE LOVE THIS PLACE. The stewed shrimp dumplings are amazing. If you get it with the noodles you only get about 4 dumplings. But if you get only the dumplings you will get a lot more. Better for your buck! Soup comes out super hot. They serve you hot tea when you are seated. '

Sure, they make you seat yourself, get up and pay for your check, then throw you change on the table for you to pick up like a homeless man, but after you've eaten there, it doesn't matter. Could be a Chinese thing, could be a rude thing. Who the hell knows. 

4 stars for the look my friend made when she walked out of their restrooms.
author: Katie Anne N.

description:
When my family of 9 immigrated to the US many many moons ago - we met the owner on the plane.  30+ years ago, this place was the only place that had wonton noodles like HK so you can imagine how popular it was.  Even today, the aroma is still one to take you back to HK...alright, back to earth...

It's the broth, not the wonton so feel free to have a plain noodle or fun - that's good.  Their fun (fat flat noodles) are the best, just the perfect texture - you can buy them in grocery stores.  Their beef stew is also popular but I think it's a bit lean.  The rice noodle rolls w/ just soy sauce, sesame paste and plum sause are the bomb - again, they are one of the first to serve this - another popular snack in HK.  One other item I especially enjoy is the preserved cabbage w/ shredded pork with noodles.

This place is authentic and everything turns around quickly so be prepared to order, eat and run.  Go there for what it is or be disappointed for what it is not!
author: Gloria H.

description:
Food = good, cheap.  Not the best quality but for that cheap of prices for lunch, I really can't bitch much.

Tables, silverware, chairs = dirty.  

Service = Chinese style...order, leave, come back with food, and leave you the hell alone, until you flag for the bill.

Cash only.
author: Fannie S.

description:
terrible place and experience. dirty place, rude service, pricey and low quality food! the so called BBQ pork wun tun soup costs 9 dollars after tax, and there are 4-5 super thin slices of pork meat and small wontons. They claim it's shrimp and pork wonton, but seriously you can not see any shrimp in it and barely taste shrimp. The broth is just purely MSG. terribly small portion and gross utensils. 
It's run by people from Shanghai, so how can you say it's nostalgic or authentic cantonese wonton soup. All they are doing is to maximize their profit. Their food can not be compared to similar wonton stores in Toronto or Vancouver. 
not recommended at all.
author: Jiang R.

description:
I've been coming here for years, but not until recently have I learned to appreciate the quality and authenticity of the noodles they serve. This is by far one of the best places in all of San Francisco to satisfy your craving for a nice hot bowl of wonton noodles and the like!

They serve rice and egg noodles...but I personally like to order the egg noodles because they are chewy and never soggy so they taste great. I've been to a handful of other restaurants where by the time they bring the order to you, the noodles have become soggy, which is no good! And their soup is simple, but tasty...not loaded with MSG.

I do have to say that the portions are quite small for the prices they charge. An order averages about $6, depending on what's in it and most of the time you don't feel completely full after one bowl. But on the bright side, it gives you a chance to order two different types of noodles in one sitting. You can choose from such toppings as beef brisket, wonton, shrimp dumpling, fish balls, etc. They are all very tasty and I personally recommend trying all of them.

This is not a fancy establishment and it looks like your typical hole-in-the- wall place...also the chairs and tables are a bit old looking...but they are still pretty clean. Definitely not an ideal place for big groups, but parties of 2-4 can be accommodated here!

Overall, I give it 4.5 stars...it would have been a 5, if the customer service was slightly better. Sometimes they do lack attentiveness towards their customers.

If you are in Chinatown or near the financial district area and want to grab a quick snack...stop by here, but remember to bring cash!
author: Wendy T.

description: I've been coming to this place ever since I was a little kid.  They are cheap, good and fast.  I always get their won ton noodle soup.  Their beef stew is quite delicious too.
author: Patrick C.

description: A hole in a wall that dishes out simple delicious wonton noodle soup.   It's a place that specializes in wonton noodle soup, and that's really all you can expect, as opposed to other places with variety of dishes.  I feel right at home because the place reminds me of mom and pop jewels in China (and Japan, my home).
author: Mayumi H.

description:
First of all, I would like to say I enjoyed the soup base. Problem is, the won ton noodle lacked elasticity. My boyfriend prefers softer noodles so he liked them fine, I guess. The dumplings are actually quite small, despite how much wrapping they use on them. I'm glad I don't taste the soapy flavour I sometimes have at wonton shops in Toronto.

It was okay. Nothing fantastic, and the price was just right.
author: Jessica F.

description: Solid wonton soup !
author: Barry W.

description:
I am Chinese.  By definition, I am cheap.  And when I grow old, I will be cranky and have complete disregard for other pedestrians sharing the sidewalk with me.

But for now, since I'm fairly young, the second part doesn't really apply to me yet.

Hon's Wun Tun House is my 7th heaven.  It is located directly across the street from my office.  I mean DIRECTLY across.  Less than a block.  All I have to do to get to it is dodge the traffic on Kearny while jaywalking (I mean, I could walk to the street corner to cross safely and legally, but who has time to do that?).

$3.95 for a bowl of won tons and noodles.  SERIOUSLY YOU GUYS.  Although the bowl is somewhat small (maybe about 5-6 wontons, plus two palmfuls of egg noodles), it's $3.95.  When was the last time you had a meal that cost less than $4?  No, fast food doesn't count.

Yeah, it's a Chinese hole-in-the-wall, so expect little to no service or smiles.  It's not floor-lickin' clean, but I wouldn't want to lick the floor anywhere.  As expected, cash only.  But it IS fast and cheap, and they have more than just plain won ton soup, so the picky eater will still have options to choose from.

Thank you for making the best wontons I've had since I moved away from home (Grandma, if you could mail me some frozen ones that would be great).

I love you.
author: Tori S.

description:
Recommended by a friend, finally tried today. Funny, actually ran into the friend who recommended here. Ordered Shrimp Wun Tun soup. Wun Tun part was really good, exactly what I wanted. But the soup wasn't very amazing as I was looking for. But there are a lot of things on the menu I want to try next time! Oh my, a good spot! Great spot! 
Only one tip, try to come before 6pm.... I don't think they open very late.
author: Flora F.

description: Great little place to grab a quick snack if you're in the mood for a bowl of wonton and noodles. We ordered the pig's feet (delicious flavor and tender) and beef tendon with won tons and noodles. The portions aren't too big so order 2 bowls if you're really hungry. For the price, it's all good.
author: Zoey W.

description:
Walked by this place the other day and thought that it looked like a nice spot for my first official hole in the wall Chinatown experience.  The GF was skeptical when we walked in, but we sat and ordered two bowls of the won ton noodle soup.  I was so excited as I watched the old man in the window masterfully cook noodles and warm won tons to order.  Then the soup came and filled our noses with what smelled like dirty dish water. 

Unphased, I added a healthy heap of chili oil and went to town.  It tasted like dish water.  I kept going as I watched the regulars chow down and I have to admit that it grew on me.  I don't think it was very delicious but it wasn't terrible either.  The noodles tasted a little like cardboard but the won tons were delicious.  

All in we paid about $12 for two bowls of soup which is pretty cheap for near the office.
author: Peter M.

description: The Real Deal, no-frills, quintessential  won ton noodle house in the City. Basic dive joint with one main staple - Chinese fast food. Freshly made won tons, local fresh noodles, and a simple broth. Ask someone who's from Hong Kong and they will say this is the place that reminds them of home. What more can a hungry local or tourist ask for? You will pay more for parking in the area than for the food. I did! But you know what, it's worth it. I noticed on the restaurant wall that you can also purchase the food in its uncooked state to prepare it at home. Assuming you know how to boil water. ;-)
author: Jeff W.

description:
After seeing the high praise for this place on Chowhound I decided to check this place out for lunch. I had a very, very disappointing meal. I tried the recommended beef curry and was served a sort of meat and potatoes stew. I was expecting the sort of beef curry over rice dish that I've had at other Chinese restaurants. 

I got over it but then started examining the beef in the stew. There was only one chunk of beef I deemed edible. The rest were unidentifiable pieces - one just looked like a large piece of fat with no meat, another piece was yellow and cylindrical. I ate my one chunk of beef and a couple of potatoes and then gave up on lunch. I went to Mrs. Fields to drown my sorrows.

Perhaps people could mention next time if the meat quality is unusual.
author: Kathleen M.

description:
Cheap and service with a smile... OK no one there ever smiles, but it is Cheap!  

I will warn you there are a few things you have to get past to enjoy this place....

1. They wipe down your table with an ammonia soaked rag just before you are seated.  (In the words of Mike... that is how you know it is clean!)
2. You need to clean your own spoon before you use it.
3. You will need to shout your order several times.... Even if you are ordering by number.
4. Chances are at some point they will come back to you and ask you to order again.
5. On a bad day they will seat you next to a huge pile to tripe.

Once you get past this get ready to enjoy a inexpensive bowl of soup!  Where else can 2 people eat for $11!
author: John F.

description: come to this hole in the wall chinatown joint and look around. all locals, right? that's because their food is legit. the wonton here hits the spot. and this place is as stank as a chinatown noodle house should be. it means the broth is on point. minus 1 star because the price on a bowl isn't as cheap as it should be for a no frills, local lunch spot. for some reason, you're charged more than what's listed on the menu. the receipt,of course, is written in chinese so i don't know what's up. eh, hasn't stopped me from coming just yet. if you like wonton, def give this place a try.
author: Baroness M.

description:
Wun Tun Soup
and noodles if you want

Tendon is pretty bomb too.  

First time i came here I was around 6 years old.  I'm now 24.  The place has not changed at all.

3/14/11 EDIT:  They got new menu's.
author: Jas C.

description:
No frills, cheap cheap and oh so delicious and filling bowl of noodles, won tons and soup. $4.61 (including tax).

It's a true hole in the wall Chinatown joint, but people there speak English and quite friendly. I've never been yelled at, even though I don't speak Chinese and always take my time to order my food. I don't even know why I bother looking at the menu. I always get the won ton noodle soup. You should try this place.

I finished the entire bowl today and drank all the soup. I am extremely satisfied and I can feel the noodles expanding in my tummy. Time to close my office door and take a little nap. :)
author: Su K.

description:
Walked by this place every day while taking a class in the financial district. It started getting full way before noon, and had other signs I look for in a good lunch place, including a small specialized menu, open kitchen, and a fair price. I also like to see people of the restaurant's ethnicity taking people of another ethnicity to the place. I saw this in abundance at Hon's and even ease dropped on conversations. 

Ordered the #1 wantons with noodles in soup. I have eaten at wonton houses before and this version was fantastic. First the broth was flavorful, not oily, and not overly salty. People were adding soy and chili paste to the soup. The wontons were fresh, and I had no "window meat" , which was a surprise. I am pretty tolerant of a little grizzle in my meat but I know this is a deal breaker for some.

Note: "Window Meat" will be addressed in my restaurant reviews. This is a term for that hard grizzle you get in the dumpling, pork bun, or anything. If eating while driving this piece of grizzle must be  spit out the window rather then swallowed.

Again, NO window meat at Hon's on my first visit. The noodles were very thin vermicelli style, super firm and none of that sulfur taste some 'fresh' noodles can have. 

I also loved the staff. the guy next to me tried to order one thing but the women behind the counter made him get #8 (my next purchase). She was like "no no no that is for take out, you should get #8,  #8 is good order that.", and she walked away. Which led to the whole counter laughing and talking with each other.

It was a good lunch. I will be back with friends.
author: Brett N.

description: I did not know that wun tun's could taste this flavorful. It could sell for $10 a bowl if they put it in some fancy organic hipstery packaging, but thankfully, it's only $4 and change.
author: T. B.

description:
simple canton style thing egg noodles, big bone broth, with wontons and/or beef tendons. it doesn't get simpler than that. it is cheap, it is simple, it doesn't have much of msg (that i can taste). 

also, just seeing a restaurant like this, with the noodle stand set up front, is enough to make me miss home. similar style shops with tons more different kind of noodles (shan don shaved noodles are the best...). it is a piece of heaven in fidi when you feel particularly low on energy!
author: Fiona S.

description:
i used to really like this place because it reminded me of HK noodle shops, however, the quality of the place have changed since my last visit.

okay, let me first start off with that yes, we're in chinatown... and you have to know in the back of your mind that things aren't THAT clean and there's probably critters crawling inside the walls... seriously, i'm not gonna lie.  a couple of minutes after i sat down, i saw something moving with my peripheral vision... and load and behold... a small baby crawly thing... probably a baby cockroach or something... the bf killed it and we move on.  i mean c'mon, if the food is good... i can let stuff like that slide cuz u ARE in chinatown...

got my usual... the wonton noodle with extra noodle.  and it was a disappointment.  the noodles are no longer "bouncy" (aka al dente) but was soggy... their soup (which on their menu can be bought separately as superior soup) was bland and lacking flavor... their wonton... not so good.  

i can understand that shops raise the price due to inflation and what not... but raising the prices (yes, they raised the prices on each bowl of noodles) and lower their quality of their dish... that's like a double price increase in my opinion.

i am no longer a fan... need to find new favorite wonton joint.  sad.
author: Kelly H.

description:
Decent place to drop in for a quick meal if you're feeling a noodle soup. Basically sat down, ordered, and got my food within a minute.

The wonton noodle soup is okay and fairly cheap relative to most things in SF, but it's nothing special. It's basically a bowl of noodles with about 6 or so smallish wontons and a sprinkling of green onions. The wontons, though small, do have great texture and decent flavor, but I suspect they use MSG as an enhancement. I wish it came stock with vegetables and maybe some BBQ pork, because then that would totally bump up the value proposition, but it seems, at least, that you could probably customize it for an additional price, since the man to my right had vegetables and fish balls in his wonton  noodlesoup.
author: Jonathan L.

description:
I literally grew up eating at Hon's Wun Tun House.  When I was a kid my parents would take us here for dinner on a cold night and a big hot bowl of won ton soup would warm me up.  

Today, I still come to Hon's for their won ton soup.  Its a nostalgic reminder of my childhood and their won tons are meaty and substantial.  Service is always friendly and fast.  The decor has not changed in over 25 years so it has an authentic old school china town vibe!

Worth Checking Out!
author: Henry S.

description: I have a friend that's been going here for 20 years.  I love the broth and I've learned how to order the BBQ pork, won ton, and ramen noodle soup (chai siu won ton mei). The seating is Hong Kong style (sitting next to unknown people) but that adds to the charm IMHO. Can't beat the incredible soup for the awesome price!
author: Katie N.

description: I love this place....my go to place in the city to get wontons is this place. I don't know what they put in the soup but its AWESOME. It tastes like authentic Wonton noodle soup. They have other selections too but I would not come here for anything else besides its wontons and noodles. The owner is this old lady who works hard (she's a millionaire with a lovely house in Nob hill). The whole restaurant is family owned. Best wontons ever and hits the spot on a cold day in SF.
author: Eileen W.

description:
You want authentic Chinese old school style, then you come here.  This ain't the American Chinese or sweet and sour Chinese you may be used to.  It's very mildly flavored (compared to most restaurant Chinese) and is pretty good.

Don't mind the fact that the place hasn't been decorated since 1973 and that the chairs are falling apart.  It's ok to sit at a table where other people are sitting, so don't be surprised when someone plops their butt down in an empty chair next to you.  Also if the waitress ignores you when you walk in, just keep standing there or just sit at a table

There's a bilingual menu and you should just go ahead and order some sort of wonton noodle soup.  They bring a hot tea when you sit down and wipe your table down with a stinky rag that's supposed to give you the illusion that the surface that you will soon eat off of will not poison you.

They've got a guy in the window making noodles looking grumpy.  He's fun to watch.  The waitress is pretty grumpy too.  Don't make her mad or she'll spit in your food and then bitch slap you.  The bus boy is like 85 years old - try and go easy on him or his death will be on your hands.

It's authentic and it tastes good.  Everyone to Chinatown!
author: Nate F.

description:
After successfully tracking down the Kung Fu Taco truck, but unsuccessfully acquiring kung fu tacos. We came here for lunch.  It's a small place. Screams Chinatown - cramped, kinda run-down, sharing tables, cramping as many people in as you can into a small space, you get the picture. 

Their portions are on the small side, but in my opinion, they portion out well for people who tend to eat too much. *ME!* I am a comfortable full after a bowl of their noodle soup. It's about $4-$5 for a bowl of wonton noodle soup. It's good, quick, and gets the job done. Cash only.
author: Dolores L.

description:
I am slowly remembering why I didn't initially like Hon's in my first review.

This morning was a bit chilly and there was a breeze when I left the office for lunch. I wanted soup and I wanted something cheap. I remembered Hon's had a not too bad, very cheap noodle soup. I couldn't remember why I hadn't been back in close to a year.

I stepped in the front door and instantly remembered why I had stayed away so long. The place is tiny, and the service is absolutely horrible. I ordered a Won Ton (Or is is wun tun?) noodle soup from the woman at the register. She didn't take my money, and didn't acknowledge me. She came back and asked me to move to the side because she already took my order.

I stepped back and waited. When another woman called out an order for the wun tun noodle soup, I stepped forward but it was promptly given to another customer. The same with the next 3 soups after that. I'm not sure if they were actually there earlier than I was, but there was still line or semblance of organization.

On the plus side, the noodles were cooked just right but they're a bit stingy with the won tons. But for $4.50 for a sizable lunch, I"m not complaining. However, for a couple bucks more I could go to the Vietnamese place not a block away and get a really great soup. Now I'm going to try and remember why I don't go back...
author: Stephanie H.

description: Wonton Noodle soup. That's all you need to know and this is the place you go eat it. Don't expect fantastic service or anything else. The wontons while small are packed full of deliciousness and flavor. They have the right base, consistency and texture each and every time. Simply awesome.
author: Daniel K.

description:
Good bang for the buck meal. The wonton noodle and curry beef stew definitely hit the spot for a very reasonable price. The decor and service is no frills and they are good at what they do. Come here for a quick easy bite to eat for cheap.

Enjoy!
author: Byron C.

description: I love this hole in a wall place. My family agrees best soup ever and very cheap and affordable, we only get the wun ton soup with noodles and won ton!! So good and they cook it in the open so you can see its not super dirty. Bathrooms are disgusting!! Free tea automatically
author: Diane S.

description: Nice little soup spot down on Kearny. Foods good, comes out fast and the prices are fair. Bowl of wonton noodle soup and cup of tea $4.75, can't beat that. Broth alone is light but add a dash of soy and some chilli oil and you got yourself a nose runner! If you're feeling hungry add a plate of gai lan and you still won't pay over $10. Noodles and wrappers are made in house and you can buy them uncooked so you can diys at home. It's a bit of a walk from the Financial but well worth it. Sit at the bar or share a table w/ strangers and make friends!
author: I D.

description:
having lived in hk over 25 yrs..we came to hong.s from great reputation , major upset...taste less wonton noodle...the beef tandon dish  was colored reddish and not tasty
cash only...but they added sales tax to each food item.....so be careful uf you add tips..you need to discount the tax amount so you don't add another tip on tax!
very disappointed for driving shch a long way！
ed
author: Edward Y.

description: This place was recommended to me by the high food standard in-laws, so I had to check it out. I was in C-town and had about 15 minutes to spare and it just happened to be lunch time...yay for me. I was instantly transported to a stall in HK and sat at the bar, ordered #1 and before I could finish making my soy sauce + vinegar + chili sauce, it was already in front of me. Broth is clean and light, egg noodles were "QQ" in Taiwanese or more popularly known as "al dente". The won ton's (yes I'm ABC) were really juicy and tasty. Just the perfect amount of shrimp and pork in each delectable bite. Only change I would make is that next time I am ordering just the wonton soup. Quick and easy and under $5 for lunch, can't go wrong!
author: Kristina L.

description:
Hon's WunTun house is supposedly "well known" for their Wonton Noodle soup so I decided to try it out with my coworkers since it's so close to my work place on Kearny in San francisco. Lunch time is usually packed with people, why? Cheap dishes ranging from $4.50-$7.00. The bowls and orders aren't too big so you may need to order two!

If you like small holes in the wall, Hun's is a good example. Small, grungy and mom and pops owned. Not exactly the most sanitary and spacious, but it's Chinatown. The service is fast and straight forward. They get people seated, eating and on their way. No BS, no time needed to be wasted. I guess you can say it's even like a fast food noodle house.
author: Helen T.

description:
I've been coming here since I was a kid. It's one of my favorite places to eat in San Francisco.  I love the broth that they use for their noodle soups and everything is delicious.  If you're lucky and you come early enough, you can get a plate of "cheurng fun" which is delicious with their hot sauce.  They usually don't have too much during the day, so its always a hit or miss.  

i typically get two bowls of noodles here. Usually a won ton rice noodle soup and then a bowl of plain noodles.  The bowls aren't that small, I just eat a lot. 

They sell "mein" by the portions to take home and cook yourself which is really nice.  The company also sells prepackaged rice noodles in local markets and 99 ranch.  They don't produce as much as they used to because the parent company hasn't been doing as well. 

This store location ownership changed recently-- like around the beginning of 2011.  I wonder if there will be any big changes.
author: Christine L.

description:
Finally came here...AGAIN...small bowls but still good.  $4.15/bowl.

This place is filthy though.  They now sell "bulk" noodles and frozen wontons
author: Jboogie L.

description:
This is a very Chinese wonton shop. The wontons are on the smaller side but plenty. The BBQ pork was okay. Lots of noodles. They have a small upstairs which I was told was too stuffy to sit so we opted for downstairs sitting at the "bar."

Looking at the menu I am impressed to see the rice roll for $2.10 for 10 pieces! Now I know I will be coming back.
author: T L.

description: Today was my first time visiting Hon's Wun Tun House.  To be honest, I have been passing it by because I was a weenie and thought it was a little bit too much like a scary hole in the wall.  Color me stupid.  I decided upon passing it last week, and seeing it packed to the gills, I had to try it.  I love fresh made won ton and noodle soup.  Well, I will no longer be a stranger, I ordered the #23, BBQ pork with won ton and noodles.  It was everything a good bowl of soup should be, noodles al dente, won ton fresh, filled with great flavor and the thin slices of bbq pork were just enough with a great flavor.  I came away full and happy.  Not the largest bowl of soup in the neighborhood, but I am full and contented.  The prices on the menu do not reflect the price you end up paying, old menus, old prices, but who cares, it was damn good.  Colleagues shared tea eggs and declared them good.  One colleague already said, YUM, let's go back soon and since she knows her noodles and wonton being well traveled from Taiwan, that is good enough for me.
author: Donna H.

description: So quick and tasty... Menu is outside a lot of the options look exactly the same... I got whatever my coworker ordered.. I honestly have no idea what it was... Something with dumplings and pork ... Not much English going on here, not terribly friendly either... But definitely delicious I can wait for more!!
author: Andrea B.

description: needs more meat, tastes good though. some chinese recommended this joint when i asked for a good noodle house, and by the look of the place seems like it's been there for a long time. what i don't like though, is the smell of the sorrounding area just outside of the place. it smells like poop, and there was this homeless guy a few feet away who's probably the culprit. yuck.
author: Xavier E.

description:
This is one of my favorite go-to place for wontons.
Although the place may not look like it's clean and fancy, it's a nice place to go to for wontons. The beef stew wonton noodle bowl is the best. I love their noodles. Everytime I go there like an hour before they close, they always say they ran out of wontons. So I had to order some dumplings which were also pretty good. Their bowls are small for a good amount of price. They're WILLING to give wontons onto your bowl unlike other restaurants who give only three pieces.
author: Annie H.

description: Outstanding. BBQ pork won ton noodle soup and curry beef and rice were delicious. Rustic
author: Tim S.

description:
It's kind of a deliciousness factory. Sit down, slurp your soup, pay very little money, then get out so someone else can have your chair.

One of my friends is seriously addicted to noodles. He's been coming here since he was 4 years old, so clearly this is the source. I can see that. Best wontons I've had in the Bay Area, and the noodles were good too. The brisket was more gristly that I prefer, so I pretended the (delicious) pork was chicken and ordered that. (Hi God!)

Service is brusque. We were here the day after Thanksgiving, so there was no crowd. Which gave us time for my friend to have seconds, and me to eat at my normal pace. I'm not sure we'd get away with that on a weekday.

Based on the state of the floor, and other reviews here, I wouldn't recommend trying the restroom. However, it's near that hotel (which one is it?), so you can always use the one in the lobby in a pinch.

If you want delicious wonton soup, and don't care about ambiance, this is your place!
author: senga d.

description:
The menu is not vegetarian-friendly, but the lady who took my order tried to accomodate me (although there was considerable eye-rolling). I got some noodles (no soup) with oil and scallions, which is about all they can put together for those who avoid pork and oysters.

The noodles were decent but we're essentially talking about a lunch one step above ramen noodles. I'm really not their target demographic.

For those who like pork and oysters this place is apparently awesome. My co-workers rave and the soup smells amazing.
author: Jamie F.

description: I am never a fan of eating in Chinatown, mainly because of the parking situation, dirty and well dirty! I will step into Chinatown only for two places-- R&G and Hon's Wun Tun House! I love their curry beef stew. It's not quite curry like Indian or Japanese curry, but it's still very flavorful. Too bad you can't order curry beef stew noodle-- they only have it either plain or over rice. I usually get it a la carte and then an order of plain noodles! They also give a lot of meat in the beef stew! It's a must try place but be sure you have enough time on your lunch break because the line gets really long!
author: Tiffany U.

description:
Hole in the wall, not the cleanest place, but three words keep sending me back to this place 

CURRY BEEF STEW 
f-a-t-t-y 
g-r-e-a-s-y 
so good with rice 

I can feel my arteries clogging every time I eat this, but I will never stop!
author: Sharon S.

description: This is my all-time-favor lunch place. Its soup is so authentic that you can't easily find even in China nowadays.
author: hongdi l.

description: We had the bbq pork + noodles and the beef tendon won ton soup. Decent. Nothing spectacular about the broth or wontons. Roast pork was standard. Can't hang with Hong Kong! Sorry, I'm being a snob again.
author: Anthony R.

description:
It was okay.

I'm a fan of big, huge, bursting won-tons, probably b/c I was spoiled by my mother. And Chinese food from Vancouver. But the wontons were realllly miniscule. Dirt cheap though, I think it was under 5 bucks. 

The bathroom, however, was a different story. You have to go through the kitchen and down the stairs. When I went, there was a dude with a hose flushing everything down. It was quite gross. I recommend holding it in until you reach something more sanitary!
author: Emily C.

description:
I would have to say Hon's has the best wontons in the bay area. I've been a loyal customer for over 20 years and still find myself coming back till this day. 

I usually get a Large bowl wonton soup and an order Beef Stew Noodle Soup. Portions are a bit small for the price. This place gets pretty busy during lunch hours but thanks to the efficient staff, you'll be seated with a nice warm bowl of wontons coming your way in no time. Hon's is as close as it gets to Hong Kong style wontons. 

Hon's is definitely a must if you're in San Francisco.
author: Haley Y.

description:
If you want a feel of wonton mee spots in Hong Kong without making the trip over, this is the place! It's pretty close to the experience from the lack of hygiene to the kitchen at the front of the store. Okay, it's not as dirty as Hong Kong, but it did bring back memories from my childhood and how I had wonton mee with my family. 

The portions are not huge, but the price you pay per bowl is reasonable. It's not going to cost you an arm and a leg. I got the regular wonton mee along with my fiancée and a side of Kai Lan. The Kai Lan came out first and it was crunchy and sweet. Good veggies! The noodles came with several pieces of wonton that is actually small than I would like it to be, but the flavor was there. My dad taught me the trick to knowing what makes wonton mee good and it's all in the noodles. If the noodles has a bounce to it when you pick it up and bite into it (like a bouncy crunch), it's good noodles. 

Compared to other places, I thought this place can stand to be one of the best wonton noodles in the city. Service might be sketchy for some, but it's no different from most other Chinese restaurants out there. Go for the experience as though you made the trip to Hong Kong! It's pretty worth it!
author: Jeremy L.

description: I grew up in Chinatown and my grandparent's place is about a block away and I do not know why I have never tried this place. Even though I have been wanting to try it ever since I was in elementary school, I guess I just never got around to it. I just ordered the #1. It reminded me of my grandma's cooking of egg noodles when I was little, the soup was very fragrant. The noddles was yummy and the won tuns were too, although they were kinda small. But inflation, yes I remember. Looking at the pictures I want to come back here again, or I might just tell my mommy to make me some won tun noodle soup. And the food also came in a matter of minutes! But I guess it doesn't take that long to make. I was telling my best friend how I felt like I was in those noodle houses in china.
author: Janet Z.

description:
This is simply the best Won Ton & Noodle you can feast on outside of Hong Kong.  I've had other people try to persuade me about other places, but in the end -- they always end up agreeing with me that Hon's Is simply the best.

You don't go here for the service or ambiance.  You go for the food and then you're out.  Go in! Go Out!  It's like In N Out -- Food is good, No frills -- you IN N OUT
author: Sequoia S.

description:
I will never go back.

The beef stew rice was not good and the price was high at almost 8 dollars plus tip. This is in China Town. Not worth it.
author: Sheila S.

description: Just a classic...Simple setting but great chewy noodles and bite size won ton with an excellent steaming broth that makes it easy to warm up on cold SF days! Delicious, my favourite spot for a cheap and quick bowl of noodles
author: Geoff E.

description:
The broth - no taste
The ho fun - thick as hell, not authentic style
No credit card, only cash, had to go all the way to Grant Street to go to my bank's atm. 

Will not come again because this is not guang dong style wonton noodles! This place sucks!
author: Kay K.

description:
very good. i always go to hon's when im in SF.

very "ethnic" if you're not into "ethnic" food, then you won't like it here.
if you think PF chang's and panda express are chinese, then you
will definitely not like it here.

it a mom and pop shop.  and cleanliness is not their priority. but i think the dirt is what makes it good. ha ha.

the portions are small, but cheap. i always get wun tun noodle in soup. or the shrimp dumpling noodle in soup.  double noodle. 
yum yum yum.!
author: Heejin L.

description:
Warming, affordable, tasty soup you can ENJOY on a cold San Francisco day.

Hon's is a crowded place, best to get it to GO. Flee back to your work domicile and slurp in delight. There is counter space and tables to sit at though. Come during non-busy hours. If you have more than four people, there is an upstairs people rarely use.

Menu is straight forward, can choose from around a dozen dishes. Order #8 all the TIME. Shrimp dumpling in the soup. Serve it up in a large bowl, and go to work with your tools. Chop sticks and sipping spoon.

Price is always right here, can leave full for $4.00. And they serve a great TEA . Thought the water was dirty for a second, but guess NOT. And it is not served scalding hot.
author: Ryan G.

description: I like the noodl e here, which reminds me my childhood in China.   The favor is so familiar and the noodle is so chewy.  The soup base is very tradition.   People needa share table on site sometimes, so be prepared with the environment.  :)
author: Jessie K.

description:
My friend brought me here for lunch. Says hes been coming here since he was a lil tod. I can see why that is, the bbq pork with wonton noodle soup was delicious. It would have been better if the wontons were bigger, and I probably should have ordered double noodles because I downed the bowl in a jiff. 

Place is pretty small, packed, run-down....like your usual hole in the wall Chinese spot. We shared a table with this one woman who at one point grabbed our check thinking it was hers until finally she realized she wasn't a fat ass who ordered two bowls of wonton noddle soup. But on the other hand, if I was her..i wouldn't be surprised ordering two bowls all for myself.
author: Alexa M.

description:
Ive lived in San Francisco all my life and Ive never tried Hon's Wun-Tun..

Im such an idiot...but now I know 

wonton with bbq pork....it was delicious, it was hot and burned my tongue but it was worth it. 

Ive never eaten noodles this fast..just slurping..

I saw the chinese ladies smiling when they saw me eat...they probably thought "HAHAHA WE  GOT ANOTHER ONE!" and yes they are right..they got me..I will be back for more~
author: phillip w.

description:
Quick, efficient, cheap, and yummy. I love me some hole-in-the-wall wonton soup. Get the rice rolls with sweet and hot sauce. Absolute delight, except you can't get 'em on wednesdays because the rice roll guy doesn't work on wednesdays. boooooo. 

i came here one time after a particularly long night of hard drinking to nurse my hangover. let it be written that hon's is just as tasty coming up.
author: Glory W.

description:
My favorite: Ngow Jaap (Beef Organ) with Won Ton Noodle Soup

Broth:  EXCELLENT!  (brings me back to the traditional won ton places in Hong Kong)

Noodle:  Their egg noodle is superb.  They make their own noodle, a very traditional way with the right amount of firmness and egg flavor....

Ngow Jaap & Won Ton:  just thinking about it make me drool....

BUT WHY???  WHY ARE YOU SO SMALL SOUP NOODLE BOWL???

End of meal:  nothing left in bowl, not even a drop of soup....
author: Gigi T.

description:
I was steered here by one of the hotel staff when I asked for great, local, and REAL Chinese food. It's small, cramped, and somewhat dirty by most standards, but if you've traveled at all, that's what most authentic places are like.

The service is quick, almost abrupt at times, but the food is the payoff.
Excellent food!! Ok service. Avoid lunch.
author: Scott M.

description:
In Chinese, wun tun translates to swallowing clouds.  All over different parts of Asia you can find variations of this exquisite dumpling.  Done right, the ethereal puff of light wrappers float in the bowl of clear broth the color of yellow and gold, an intensely flavored filling that reminds you the land (from the ground pork) and the sea (the little tiny sweet shrimp) with the thin yellow wheat noodles that have the firm and lively texture.  While Hon's version may never compete with my childhood memories of one particular noodle stand in an alley way in southern Taiwan, Hon's does a very competent version of 'swallowing clouds' with plenty of authentic flavor ambiance and the attitude that comes with it.

I come to this place whenever I'm craving a bowl of Hong Kong style mein with wun tuns, cooked in a big stainless steel drum and columns of white porcelain bowls with pink floral prints stacked up against the big glass window facing the busy traffic of Kearny St.  Depending on the mood, I can either come with some friends during weekday lunch hour rush jammed packed with people or on Saturday morning after farmer's market for a solitary ritual in the half empty joint.  I recommend sitting at the counter when you are here by yourself so you can watch all the actions going on in the kitchen.

Among its peers of street style food in the city, Hon's is one my top choice in terms of flavors. Robust beef brisket, spicy beef curry with the slightest savory sweetness, the wun tun that's closer to shu mai than swallowing clouds, with the same plump chewy meat ball inside the thin wheat flour wrapper that turns translucent when cooked.

I've had the regular wun tun mein.  I've had the beef curry with rice, the stew brisket with blanched butter lettuce over rice.  I've had beef briskets, fish balls, tendons and char siu pork added to the mein.  Sometimes separately, sometimes all at once in the same bowl of noodle, at which point the tall Shandonese guy with the comb-over behind the counter merely raises his eyebrows then shruggs and puts the order in with the lady with a head full of big black curls, slaving away at the big drum full of boiling water (who reminds me of the land lord lady from Kung Fu Hustle.)
author: Sam W.

description:
1.5 stars. This place is disgusting. It's a health inspector's nightmare.

We were a party of two so the lady didn't want us seated at a table for four; she tried to convince us to share a table with another woman but we opted for two seats at the counter.

There was a platter of chopped raw meat at the end of the counter. I sat in the seat furthest away from it.

Five minutes later, a guy comes in and is seated RIGHT. NEXT. TO THE PLATTER OF RAW MEAT. They don't even bother moving it or anything, so if he coughs, sneezes, slurps his soup too vigorously, it's within spraying distance of  the raw meat. GROSS!

The woman who took our orders was really rude and impatient. She expected us to know what we wanted the minute we sat down in the stools. Not cool.

I ordered the wonton ho fun soup with beef. The broth was watery and flavorless; it tasted like what I imagine dishwater would taste like.  I got 3 wonton but for the price I'm not complaining. The wontons were small but flavorful. This was the only redeeming part of the meal. The portions were small and more like a snack than a full meal.

We also ordered the gai lan (plain) and the spicy beef tendons. The gai lan were cooked perfectly and the vegetables were tender. The spicy beef tendons tasted like spicy ketchup and there were many suspect pieces of "tendon", including many yellow clumps of fat.

While waiting for the food to arrive, I noticed there was a plastic basket under the counter with three servings of fun (the rolled type with chopped shrimp and green onion) inside it The basket was amongst various non-food items and  was maybe 2-3 ft above the ground. Then I saw them actually take the fun out of the plastic basket, pop it in the microwave and serve it to people. SO DISGUSTING, I thought they had put the fun down there to throw away!

Very cheap but I'm so grossed out by the unsanitary conditions and mediocre food. The gai lan and wontons were edible; everything else was not.  I'm aware that most Chinese restaurants are this dirty but I don't want to see the filth while I'm trying to enjoy my meal.
author: Bella L.

description:
I have only ate one item on their menu.

But I ate it so much that even the sight of me walking up to the restaurant had them already preparing it for me so by the time I sat down it would be there before i even said a word. No joke. 

So what was the item that kept me coming back over and over for years? Dan Dan Mien. Its called something else on the menu but basically its a szechuen sauce with pieces of pork over noodle with the soup base on the side. It came highly recommended from a co-worker I once worked with and he had been going there for 10 years for that dish alone. He also had friends that flew in from other parts of the country that there first stop had to be Hons just for this dish. He said I'd be addicted and he was right.
author: Patrick B.

description:
I LOVE noodles and Hon's Wun Tun House satisfies my noodle cravings the best.  You can watch them make their fresh won ton at the counter while you sit there and enjoy your own bowl of won ton. 

This place is nothing fancy...just a down-to-earth noodle house with nothing exciting except for the yummy won ton's they serve. The prices are extremely cheap and the food is awesome.  It can get pretty crowded during peak hours so you might have to share a table. The service is your typical Chinese restaurant service. They aren't rude but they're not going to ask you how your day is or compliment your new hairdo. This place is all about the food. 

Cash only. Pay at the register.
author: Becka T.

description: You want  Good Won ton Noodle soup you say? Good you're in for a treat at this place! I've been coming to this place since the 90's and each time, great meal! This place my friends is the closest you're gonna be inside of a Genuine noodle house in Hong Kong! You come in, you order, you eat, you pay, you get out...Just like that! No frills no small talk no chit chat, you come here when you're hungry. Anything you order on the menu is pretty much good food. My favorite is the Curry beef with rice & the wonton double noodle soup. But you might not like: This place accepts CASH ONLY. (They don't accept credit or debit cards). Parking in the streets is horrible so come early. Other than these issues, you're good and happy eating!!! :P
author: Joel A.

description:
I absolutely LOVE THIS PLACE!
smaller portions, but you can order a Large.

go support your local Chinatown joint!
author: Emily L.

description:
It's cooold outside today--in the middle of June--after a heat wave last week--and I am freezing.

Hot won ton noodle soup is just what I needed so I came here. Ordered it to go because seating was limited--I guess everyone else was cold, too. Good soup, noodles, wontons. 

The only problem was that us "to go" people waited outside and I guess the orders are ready in the 10 mins. that they tell you to wait, but no one tells you! So the girl ahead of me and I wait 20 mins. and finally go in to check--I ask for my food and the lady behind the counter got mad at me for not coming sooner--kinda soup-nazi-ish! Argh. 

But, now that I know the"system", I will return.
author: Kat H.

description:
Curry Beef! This place has the best Chinese Beef Curry. Not japanese curry, or indian curry, but good plain ol beef curry with tendon and all the spices. It's great. 

I think most people go to this place to have their wonton noodles, etc but everytime I go there, I get their curry beef which apparently they make on the side and is usually out by the afternoon.

Pros: Curry Beef!
Cons: Don't go here for the atmosphere and service. It is not romantic, it is not fancy, it's an old chinese place in chinatown so come for the food 

Try it. Let me know if you like it!
author: Brian P.

description:
Wow, I really don't get it. I read all these stellar reviews...I won't be back. For those of you who do like this place, let's hope the Health Department doesn't find out about it. The "fresh" wun-tun, noodles, meat, etc. is all just sitting out in bowls on the counters, some right next to other diners. Our waitress picked up our menu from off the floor in the kitchen and placed it right up by all the sauces for us to peruse. The man next to me ordered something very interesting...what I can only assume may have been the beef tendon, which was picked up out of some crock-pot device and placed into a bowl. From here, the "cook" picked up from scissors from the sink and began to chop away at it, cutting it into bite-sized pieces. 

This place is unlike any I've ever experienced...dead silent...the patrons come here to eat, and they are quite serious about it.

While two of us were able to eat shrimp wun-tun & noodle soup and drink the complimentary hot tea for $8 total, the noodles were kind of crunchy, the broth had no flavor and the shrimp wun-tuns I ordered contained no shrimp and what I believe to be pork and mushrooms instead. This is after cruising through crowded China Town trying to find parking, which we finally did in the parking garage for the main square across the street. 

My co-diner thought the glaring bright yellow Formica counter-tops were nice and cheerful, especially when the sun shines through the windows...makes the whole place glow. It's super cheap but when it comes to what I'm consuming, I'm not sure "cheap" is the proper criteria. 

For those who do like this establishment, I hope I didn't offend. I did, however, feel slightly misled and very unprepared for my experience here.
author: Angela N.

description:
One of the best places in the city for a good bowl of wonton tong mein.  The noodles are nice and crunchy, as they should be, the broth is tasty, and the wontons, so slippery and flavorful as they go down your throat.  Bummer it isn't open on Sundays anymore as that's one of the only open lunches I have but I do try to make  time to come here.  The place is tiny but the food comes and goes real fast.  It can seem sort of dingy but it's Chinatown.  The bowls are sort of small so for the boys out there, you may want to add extra noodles, as they say it, 'ga dei'.  

I always get the wonton tong mein but the pig inside of me is almost always compelled to get an order of fish ball flat rice noodle soup.  I have yet to get a second bowl of noodles.

Note...I have eaten in Chinatown A LOT and well, we always see the older Chinese folks doing the luggy cough-up spit thingy on the street.  That's disgusting even on the street but never had I seen anyone do that while other people were eating, in a restaurant.  I guess it was bound to happen sooner or later because the last time I was here, this older lady who had finished eating and was picking her teeth with a toothpick, started to hoff up luggies and all that good stuff while we were still eating.  I kept giving her stares to hopefully get her to see that she was being disgusting.  My bf was staring as well.  She didn't seem to get it.  Kept on doing it the whole entire time they we were eating.  They were freaking chillaxing, picking at her teeth.  UGH.  It made this last experience really unappetizing.  It's not Hon's fault, but I wish the owner lady would've said something.

I came REALLY close to saying something to the actual lady or even the owner.  To ask her to go outside because it's plain rude and disgusting for other diners.
author: Winnie L.

description:
#24 is way good- and $6.23 out the door!  My first time in there and I was in and out in 15 or 20 minutes- the won tons are great, bbq pork had good flavor as did the broth - needed a little kick from the hot pepper sauce tho.

Update 12/20/08: Consistent!!  Just got the same thing to go and it was just as good.  Man, this place is a great find!!
author: Catherine R.

description:
What? This isn't Hong Kong?

 The place was packed during lunch with hipsters, tourists, families, business folks. Every one is slurping down some noodles.

I had the beef brisket with wontons in noodle soup and it was awesome. The brisket was tender and the shrimp wontons were fresh and delicious. The noodles were chewy and filling. They have a chile sauce on the side that packs some heat along with garlic flavor. An awesome lunch for a ridiculously low price. Definitely wallet friendly.
author: Y C.

description:
I was prepared to be wowed by Hon's Wonton House after reading the Yelp reviews this AM at work.  When I arrived I was instantly drawn to the looks of the restaurant.  It is your typical, low-key, hole-in-the-wall Chinatown restaurant.  The food will be good I thought.  The prices were definitely cheap...most items around $4.95.

I ordered the beef stew, wonton noodle soup and my friend ordered plain wonton noodle soup.  We also shared an order of oyster sauce-Chinese broccoli (gailan).  Food came super quick and I was pleased by the amount of Chinese clientele.  However, I immediately noticed the portions were TINY and I only had three, yes, three wonton in my bowl.  What?!  My friend's probably had about five or so.  Usually when you order wonton with meat, you get the same amount of wonton as the plain order with the addition of the meat.  This ruined it for me.  You technically could order two bowls of wonton and get the standard portion size, but there goes the cheapness factor.

Right now Washington Bakery remains the place to get wonton until I discover somewhere better.
author: Christopher W.

description:
Walked by here a few times and always wanted to try it, but reviews from friends have been mixed. It definitely had the old chinatown feel with the dilapidated hole-in-the-wall decor (diner seating with cracked stools, dingy walls, steamy air) But it felt homely enough. I ordered the won ton noodle soup and curry fish balls, which was promptly served.

The food itself I would rate par to sub-par where the noodles were nothing a bit coarse and nothing special, the wontons were tasty but tiny, as were the portions. The curry fish ball barely had any curry flavor too.

I felt leaving unsatiated and not quite full for $8. For a place that specializes in won tons, I think they could do better. Might give this place another shot for some of the other items on the menu.
author: john l.

description:
Slurp noodle slurp!

Nothing special or fancy, but fresh Chinese soup, homemade, and tasty.  Way cheap, $3 to 5.  They sell uncooked noodles dumplings by the pound to take home and cook.
author: Gil S.

description:
We have been going to Hon's for almost thirty years now, and it's still great and the same as always.

Another dive, this small restaurant is right near Clay and Kearny Streets, and parking is difficult but not impossible.  And you can always shove it into the Portsmouth Square garage if you're desperate.

Hon's is a hole-in-the-wall, with a very specific menu printed on cards on each table.  Noodles, won-ton, other specialties and that's it.  Tea or water come in small, cheap plastic cups - likewise so does Coke or Sprite.  No wine, beer, absinthe, etc.

What I think they do best, is noodles and won-ton.  

You order by #, and I usually get won-ton soup with noodles and barbecued pork (cha shu); my wife usually gets the shrimp dumplings in soup with noodles, and we share an order of Chinese broccoli in oyster sauce - flavorful and sort of healthy!  

Also good is boiled lettuce in oyster sauce - the crunchy slurpy lettuce in the molasses-thick sauce is wonderful.

Hon's broth is so good, it's worth having by itself.  It has the usual Chinese melange of flavors which is both sweet, salty and delectable.  As good, but totally different from Vietnamese Pho broths, but on par.

Value - Hon's has to be one of the most reasonably-priced authentic food experiences in the Bay Area.  Everything is so-o-o cheap it's amazing, given the quality.

Of course, no one looks like they're getting rich working here, and you have to go through the kitchen & down a classic-ly dingy set of stairs to get to the pre-speakeasy bathrooms (forget about handicap access).

Another dive:  A dive to me is a small establishment with a very limited menu offering of tastes that has been honed and developed over time until it's really good, and there aren't usually a lot of choices to dilute this experience.  The classic dive has honed their assembling of food so they have their ingredients and methods down so it's a cheap as possible.  And finally, they spend little or nothing on their ambience and character - the food is the story.

Over and out.
author: Alan O.

description:
One of the best paces for wonton noodles in the Bay Area! In fact, Hon's Wun Tun makes their own noodles at their factory in South City and they supply their noodles to alot of the other restaurants and noodle shops in the Bay. The portions are a bit small so I normally get 2 bowls when I eat there. The noodles really make the dish - its fresh and has the chewy consistency that no one else has. I've only had better when I visited Hong Kong and Vancouver which are the best 2 spot for Cantonese food in the entire world hands down. Otherwise, Hon's Wun Tun is a close second.

My buddy Ricky loves the curry beef stew that they make there and have simmering in the crock pot behind the counter and he only eats that. I never had it before but others tell me that its very good. I might try it one day but for the past 10+ years, I only load up on the wonton and noodles so I never get a chance. Maybe one day...
author: Roger Y.

description:
For some, knowing where your food comes from, how it's prepared, etc. is too close to the reality of cooking at home...or living on a farm. My perceptions are unaffected by domestic tendencies (since I have very few). Therefore, I can take a great interest in prep and process...I enjoy the cooking show, as much as the final meal outcome.

Hon's has a no-frills, business-like philosophy that transforms great big bowls of raw meats sitting on counters into scrumptious won ton and noodle soups. Among the dishes that resulted from the assembly line of stirring broths, simmering meats, boiling won ton & crispy noodle formations, was the unique little bowl of beef stew with won ton and noodle goodness that I ordered from the waitress 5 min. before it appeared. The dish featured nice big chunks of simmered beef in a savory broth mixed with tender won ton and noodle fun. Who would have thought raw things could be turned into tasty things so quickly! 

And, like all good cooking shows, audience participation is key. You share a counter or table and leave as soon as you're done, because it gets packed at lunchtime. You order by number and food instantly appears. You pay your bill at the register and then you depart.

In the end, my bill for lunch and the show came to $7 (with tip). Can I just say Bam!
author: Julia C.

description:
Beef brisket and wonton noodle soup review: wontons were tiny, beef was fatty (the actual meat was tender, I'll admit), noodles were decent. And not only were the wontons tiny, they just weren't very good. Also, the soup itself was not hot enough, and really not all that flavorful. Altogether, not a whole lot of food, even for $5.50. I recommend going elsewhere for beef brisket and wonton noodle soup (I'm partial to Hing Lung on Broadway).

Staffing: Disorganized, inattentive, slow to give my a menu (actually had to just grab someone else's), and not the cleanest place. Of course, that pretty much describes every Chinese restaurant, but still. And yes, I am Chinese (Cantonese). 

I guess it was a cheap lunch\snack?

I decided to bump it up. The noodles and broth ARE pretty good, you just don't get a lot of them.
author: B Y.

description:
Best noodles in town! I grew up on Hon's noodles and wun tun in Vancouver, the SF version is just as fine, it reminds me of the original Main St. Vancouver Hon's in Chinatown, small, oldschool, not overly friendly to tourists, a great noodle house. 

Szechuan sauce noodles, curry, gailan and oyster sauce, or a fantastic wun tun soup. It's all about the texture of the noodles and the flavor of the food, this is a seriously good place, this is the real deal, highly recommended!
author: Samantha L.

description: Had a beef brisket and wonton noodle soup. OK on the soup and wontons, but the beef brisket was not so spectacular. That aside, my biggest gripe were the noodles. Not sure if we had come in too late, but they were pretty limp (although I do prefer my noodles with a bit more spring to them).
author: Aaron L.

description: GREAT place to come for lunch especially on a cold and rainy day!  My friends and I always get a bowl of the wun tun and beef stew noodle soup and then share a plate of the gai lan and beef tendon - mmm!!!!  So tasty and so cheap too!  We come here at least once a week.
author: Clara A.

description:
I've been eating here off and on for a long time (think carbon paper and slide rules) and it has always been the same. It's the real deal - kinda run-down and looking like it belongs in the heart of Chinatown. Some of the people in here look like they have been here for ever - especially that old guy down at the end of the counter. Watch how the noodles,  with just a little help from his chopsticks, seem to rise in a slow steady stream into his mouth. He's done this a thousand times.

I love the wun-tun here ( that's won tons to us gringos),  and the price cannot be beat.
author: Art S.

description: Hole in the wall.  Don't expect an amazing decor.  Service is prompt.  Food is served promptly too. Menu is simple.   If you're in the mood for wonton noodles this is the place to go.  It's affordable.   I love egg noodles and their shrimp wontons.  I always order their chinese broccoli on the side too.  Bring cash.  BTW, I'm not a fan of tea.  I'd suggest you go to the corner shop and get a bottle of water.
author: pengrin ..

description:
Truly authentic won ton is made here everyday.  This is the BEST traditional won ton noodles in San Francisco. 

We all have this misconception of how a won ton supposed to be....BIG dumpling with lots of shrimps!?!  This is indeed the complete opposite.  

The portion is right and the noodle is crunchy.  I love it.  (traffic & parking is a different story)
author: Jenny C.

description:
I love this place so much. Their wonton mein I think is one of the best. Their noodles are crunchy and their wonton is absolutely delicious
The place may look a bit dark inside but the food is so good x.x but I can't seem to want to try anything else because I like the wonton mein so much
author: Christina W.

description:
Cheap, freahly made won-tons served in a no-frills setting by waiters who are there just to do their jobs serving Chinese peeps who are there just to eat. No entertainment here. Go to some overpriced Marina "pan-Asian"  joint and bring your sanitizing wipes if you are afraid of your food actually having a smell and taste.
Basic good food in a decently clean setting.
author: Jackie P.

description:
Can I just say that I am planning on eating here WEEKLY because it's so CHEAP? YUM! What a great lunch spot! 

It can be intimidating if you're not asian when you first go in because it's full of mostly asian people and is run by Chinese people, but that's just our culture: Ya want good, cheap food?! Well grab a seat and eat! 

#1 = Noodle and Wun Tun Soup for only $3.95 plus tax. (I wish it came with choi (cantonese for veggies) but that's okay, you can order it on the side for a couple more bucks. YUM! 

Very nostalgic, reminds me of my mommie's homecooked food. I call this place Chinese comfort food for the soul! ^_^
author: Geneva X.

description:
This place is like all the Wun Tun places I used to go to when I was a kid and we'd only go there with the whole family (8+ Aunts/uncles + cousins) and only because the oldest Uncle is in town.

The food I think is pretty good, not great but for the price you're paying Its definitely worth it for either the wuntun or the beef one (Can't think of the name for it at the moment).

Parking: This is China town, good luck, I usually take the muni from Financial District or I just walk here.

Service: Service is a bit slow, which is ok since once you order you're food comes out pretty quickly (Soup stock + noodles + wuntun or beef etc).  Unless you're sitting on the upstairs area.  You're food will take a while to get to you and its dark.

Store: The store itself is what you'd typically find in SF China town in my opinion.  The store is on the small and dark side.

Menu: Menu is very limited, I usually stick the noodle soups but every once in a while my coworker will order vegetables.  So for non-Cantonese speakers I believe there's English on menu and just point at what you want :-p (like me)

Price: its cheap enough that I'd pick up a tab if I came in a larger group,  although there really aren't tables for large group.

Overall well worth trying this place out at least once.
author: Omar L.

description:
Their wonton soup noodles were good. The size is on the small size, but that could be a positive thing for people who aren't that hungry. I also like and order their rice rolls with the 2-3 different sauces. Although they microwave the rice rolls (which is weird, but whatever.. haha), the rice rolls were delicious! Their waitering service could use some improvements, and their place is fairly small and cramped, and on first glance, the place doesn't look very clean. But, that's Chinatown.

I recommend this place.
author: Sam W.

description:
I've had many bowls of won ton (that's how I'm used to spelling it from where I'm from) in my life, and Han's Wun Tun did nothing for me.  The won tons were nothing special (not enough shrimp) and the noodles were"meh.  Maybe it's because they're missing the "o"s in their name... ??

It takes years to perfect the won ton, and decades to get the noodles just right (hk style).  You want your noodles al dente, no different from your pasta... and the soup base is incredibly important, needs to have a perfect balance of pork oils ("ju yuw").  

I must have gone on an off-day, because nothing impressed me about that bowl of noodles.  Fortunately, it wasn't an expensive bowl of won ton, but you definitely don't get the value that a San Franciscan should expect.

if you find a good won ton place in SF, please let me know!
author: Natalie T.

description: Soo cheap (but you do get smaller portions)! Can't expect too much for these cheap prices... Not too clean, but its typical of most of the restaurants in chinatown.  I've tried the won ton noodle and the beef brisket noodle.  Both are pretty good.  Orders come quickly.  Broth is tasty.  Great for a cold day!
author: Tramy V.

description: I've been going to this place since I was a little kid... never realized how greasy and kinda unpleasant the ambiance was, but for me, this place is like home and the servers my aunties!  I think they kinda recognize me there... maybe because we were there practically every weekend!  If SF adopted the whole letter grading system, I'm sure it'd get a "C," which is fine by me!! Because "C" stands for Chinese!!!  This place is Chinese through and through!  The beef brisket, the curry beef, the wonton, the broth... oh man I would leave my world here in LA just for a bowl of 90% of their noodle soups!  Shhh.... don't tell the GF! :P  But I know she likes the curry from here also!  Extremely reasonably priced, and awesome food!  Always a go to spot for me when I visit!  Just please don't go, because I won't have a place to sit!!
author: Eric T.

description: very one dimensional.  for the same price, can get much more interesting, fresh and tasty noodles/broth/dumplings at Ramen Underground a couple blocks away...
author: H S.

description:
Great noodle soup place if you're looking for something warm on a cold day. The beef stew with wonton noodle soup is the best! The curry beef stew over rice is also a must have. 

Thumbs down - to the b!tchy lady at the register. Give the poor employees a break.  All she does is mutter sh!t under her breath.  Give it a rest, you'll live longer.

Thumbs up - to the lady the stumbles around the room with hot soups on her tray without spilling them.
author: Jenny W.

description:
Not even if you paid me. 
I shiver thinking about eating there again.  Was craving Pho' but couldn't find any; looked for closest thing which was a beef noodle soup. Can't be bad coz there are lots of older people eating there...huh! The place smelled like the soup which smelled like tripe. 
What was everyone else eating? So I ordered stewed brisket of beef with noodles.
The cook scooped the broth into the container, packed the noodles with his hands (no gloves or forks or chopsticks) ontop and threw meat of some unknown animal ontop. 
Noodles were hard, didn't eat them, beef was tripey and fatty, couldn't eat that, and broth was no go either as it tasted of unclean tripe. Had to toss the whole thing. 
I'm not against tripe as I do eat it but it has to be done well.... anyway I thought I was supposed to be eating brisket.
Never again.
author: Shiru M.

description:
Just because their speciality is wun tun, it doesn't mean its good! My colleagues and I came here with high hopes and left with low spirits.

Sure, $3.60 for a small bowl of wun tun noodle soup is cheap, but the soup was bland. My colleague kept adding red vinegar to his soup until it looked like blood. Then we realized that even the vinegar was watered down. 

Perhaps the egg noodles is something to cheer about, but whats the point of giving it 5-stars when only the noodle is deserving of it? Its like giving N'Sync a Grammy Award when we all know only Justin is the talented one.
author: Nancie T.

description: This review is to pay a tribute to this wonton place.  This restaurant has opened for 40 years I think.  When I came to the U.S 25 years ago, there were here, and I had great memory of their noddle.  Their noddle is closest one to the quality that you can find in Hong Kong.  You must be a wonton noddle fan to appreciate this place.  I had not been there for 20+ years, and last week I re-visited there again.  Noddle is still nothing but the best.  I can still even recognize the waiters and the owners.  They were at their retirement age and still working.  Like a review said, you don't come here for the decor nor the service, but just come here for that bite on the authentic "bamboo" style Chinese noddle taste.
author: Alex D.

description:
I've passed by this place before during lunch time and it's always packed with a good cross-section of FiDi types and old-school Chinese folks.  So I think to myself: "Hmmm, It *must* be good if it draws a variety of people".

Today I passed by and stopped to study the prices on the menu taped to the window.  Everything seemed to be in the $3 - $4 dollar range.  Cheap places tend to intrigue me, so I went in.

I eagerly sat at the last stool at the counter.  A male employee immediately directs me to sit on the *second* to-the-last stool at the counter.  O-kaaaaay...but whatever, right?  So I move over.  At this point, a little voice in my head is starting to think "Uh oh...", but I dismiss it. 

A lady wearing glasses that magnify her eyes puts a bowl of won ton noodle soup in front of me.  I look down to greasy noodles and about half a dozen smallish won tons - and nothing else.

The soup was okay at best.  Honestly, I'm used to larger bowls of won ton soup (with larger won tons) with bok choy/snow peas/shrimp/water chestnuts/mushrooms, etc. in it.  But I guess bare bones is what you get when you pay $3.60.  

It's cool though - the entire establishment was weirding me out anyway with their specific-stool request and a crazy Filipino dude (and I know he was Filipino 'cause 1) I'm Filipina and 2) he kept shouting "I'm Pinoy!" every few minutes) sitting next to me.

It's definitely worth it to spend a few extra bucks to get something you'll actually enjoy eating...

:/
author: Karen F.

description: The wontons are petite but oh so good.  For $5 and change, I got 12 wontons floating in a steaming hot broth.  One of the best wonton houses I've been to.  Definitely not a fancy place, but the service was quick and food was delicious.
author: Lorraine G.

description:
In my early youth (around 6 to 14), my family and I came here almost every other week for dinner on Fridays, since my mom worked at nearby B of A.  Over the years, the waitresses got to know us by face, and even when I went back a few months ago for lunch, one of the waitresses remembered me!   It's a really nice feeling to know that they care enough about their customers to recognize them.

It was about $3 for a bowl of wonton noodle soup, and despite the last 10-15 years of inflation and what not, you can still get that wonton noodle soup for under $4.  Many people also go for their steamed rice rolls, which are a great deal as well.  Sure, the place has been a hole in the wall, probably even since its conception, but they serve homemade noodles, use fresh ingredients, and do so with friendly, welcoming faces.  I hope this place never closes!
