author: Kalista W.

description: The wun tuns in this establishments wun tun soup are excellent.  Unfortunately, that's the only thing good about the place.  The noodles in the soup have, what I feel, is a nasty taste to them and the broth is so-so.  If you get the War Wun Tun soup, you get some pork and maybe something else I forget also in the soup which is nice.  The atmosphere is cramped and sort of stale-smelling.  The price is cheap, but not enough to get me to go back again unless someone had their heart set on it.
author: Marc S.

description: Quick n' fast wun tun soup, in a rush? get here before 11:45am or suffer! just kidding the service is mostly quick. Wun tun noodle with BBQ pork is tastey. Low cost n' quick.
author: Bert K.

description: stick with the basics: dumpling/won ton in noodle soup, and for under $6, it should satisfy you.  The won tons and noodles here are fresh (made daily).  Don't expect customer service - just eat and go.
author: Margaret W.

description: The lady at the register was rude. The won tun noodle soup's ok since the price was cheap. But the price isn't what I crave. Yes a quick fix, but I'm cool with not coming back here any more.
author: Quinallison D.

description: Good beef brisket with wonton noodles.  Not the cleanest.
author: Jim J.

description: Small quaint location with limited seating but excellent, authentic food. Worth the wait if there is one.
author: Susan C.

description:
A cold August day in SF?  Soup time!
I found this place on Yelp.  Needless to say, it was good and the food came out fast.

I got the bbq pork with wun tun and noodles in soup.
Roy got the beef tendon with WT and noodles in soup.
We also ordered a bowl of fish balls in soup.

Relatively small bowls.  I guess I'm used to big pho bowls.  Hot tea.  The place wasn't crowded, but all the seats were taken.  Cash only.  Our total for three bowls was $17.  I will definitely be back, but I might have to order a side of just WTs - the filling was perfect.
author: Lynnie P.

description:
I can't believe you can buy lunch for $5. Seriously, a bowl of noodles for $3.80? That's so cheap. 

I went to Hon's Wun Tun for the first time today after going to Macworld. It was crowded so initially my friend and I were seated at a table with another diner. We relocated within 2 minutes so it wasn't a problem. Once you order your noodles, they're served within 5 minutes, so if you're looking for fast and cheap, I'd recommend Hon's. 

I liked the broth and the noodles weren't bad either. You totally can't beat the price. It seemed like all but 2 were over 55. An old man kept coming back to fill our water glasses. That's better than at so many other restaurants.
author: Amy D.

description:
Craving some homemade wonton noodle soup? You have to come to this place. The parking is a little annoying, but it's completely worth the trip if you're in the mood for some good food. 

Everything is fresh (the woman was folding the wontons behind us) and you can see the noodles they hand made that morning. This place is great and reminds me of mom's.
author: Angela L.

description: Great place for a regular wonton soup brunch. Thank God they're not making gigantic dumpling-like wontons as in some places I went before. I've been staying in the deep south for years and most Chinese restaurants were spicy, greasy & overall too Americanized. It's just wonderful that I finally found something that's really Cantonese. The old coupe running this place make it feel more like a 90s Hong Kong movie. This place feels more like a diner than a dinner-restaurant. Veggie and meat toppings are charged with an extra, so make sure you read through the menu. Also recommend their fish balls and tea eggs.
author: Julia S.

description:
OMG.

OMG OMG OMG OMG.

This place is very special  VERY special.

Don't go here for the service.  It's not great.  Don't go here for the ambience.  There is none to be had.

Go here for the NOODLES.  And go here for the Wun Tun.  They are so awesome.  Every time I get exicted and go here, I expect that I was building it up in my head and it's not going to be as good as it is in my head.  And EVERY time it's STILL as awesome as I thought it was going to be.

ZANG!

Go here.  Yes.
author: Uriah F.

description: These are the worst wontons I ever ate.  You get wontons like these at a chop suey place in Kansas.  If they ever serve these wontons in Hong Kong, they 'll be out of business within one day.  Hong Kong wontons are big wontons full with  prawn and a little pork.  These wontons are small and full of pork, little shrimp.  The two ladies running the front are not friendly.  They act very bitchy.
author: susan g.

description:
I love a good bowl of won-ton mein.  When I was in HK, it was my snack everyday between meals.  This place has got it down.  I don't mind the dirtiness or what not.  You're in chinatown, you gotta expect that.  Extra hungry?  Add extra noodles, "Ga Dei!"

My girlfriend also introduced me to fried flat rice noodles here.
author: Chris C.

description:
I left my heart in San Francisco, in a bowl of noodle that I can remember going to as a kid with my grandfather.  That was 20+ years ago, and today, it has remained the same.  This place is a wonton house, and is their specialty.  This hole-in-the-wall place seems like it was ripped right out of its hole in Hong Kong and plopped down in-tact on Kearny street.

As you can guess from how I started yelping about this one, the food is good.  The soup stock has probably been brewing since I was born, and all they did was keep on adding more to it, retaining it's flavor.  You can actually taste the quality broth.  The wontons are a good standard size, packed with fresh shrimp that give a resilient texture with every bite.  Serving sizes are just right, if you like the american sizes, then buy two bowls.  But if you want just a little bit more noodle and dumplings, just say "ga Dai", which can also mean "SUPERSIZE ME!!"  Well, that's an exageration, bit you do get some more, if you do tend to eat more.

The place has limited seating and can get crowded pretty easily.  With that in mind, they may seat you with strangers too.  Like two couples at a table of 4, or 4 complete strangers.  In either case, they've expanded to an upstairs in recent years.

Best of all, the prices aren't bad at all.  Other notes, they only take cash.  So if you're on of those poor saps that forgot their wallets, you can wash dishes for the day to make up for it I guess, it's not that expensive.
author: Henry L.

description:
I went to Hong Kong last year and had this amazing Won Ton Noodle soup that I still dream about today. I tried several Won Ton Noodle places in the bay area but they were not even close to the one that I had in Hong Kong. 

After reading these review for Hon's Wun Tun House, I decided to give it a try. I was actually pleasantly surprised. The place looks really humble and ordinary, but the Won Ton Noodle soup is the best that I have had in the Bay Area. It is still not as good as the one that I had in Hong Kong, where the shrimps were huge, fresh, plump and sweet. However, it was good enough to help with my craving for the Won Ton Noodle soup once in a while.

My partner tried the curry beef and I thought it was alright. 

I am difinately coming back again for the Won Ton Noodle soup.
author: WS P.

description: Every once in a while I trek it over to Chinatown during lunch and get me some of my peoples food.  One of my favorite spots is Hons, their won ton soups I would say is the best around.  I usually go for the beef stew won ton noodle soup (large).The noodles are al dente the way I like it and the broth is always consistent.  Everyone once in a while i get a side of pigs feet cause i get down like that!
author: Mike K.

description:
I work about 3 blocks in the financial district, and I think this place is a gem. I grew up in the city, so I'm used to great Cantonese/Hong Kong food. In terms of speed and quality, this place gets 5 stars from me.

My favorite is Ngow Jaap (cow internal organs) wonton ho-fun (flat rice noodle) soup. The bowls are small but if you pay an extra $1 or $2 you can get a larger bowl. The egg noodles are better than than the ho-fun, but they are both of good quality.

The place doesn't look very clean, but I'm okay with this. The service is a bit rushed but so am I.
author: William C.

description:
No frills, but this is the real deal.  The food is cheap and good. I had the stewed beef and wonton soup. The wontons are great, but the beef had too much fat for my taste.  I guess that's what I get for ordering stewed beef. Next time I'm going to try the bbq pork and wonton soup, which I'm sure is a lot better.

In any case, a real Chinese dive, with authentic Chinese food.
author: Steven P.

description: This has to be the best wonton spot in the entire bay area hands down. The only other place i have had better wonton is in hong kong. The portions here are quite small but at the same time you could just order a plate of rice rolls and you will leave with a full stomach. Its my favorite spot in the entire bay area to eat wonton. The only thing i dont like is the street parking.
author: Art N.

description: 3.5 stars kind of place. I'm a huge believer in mom&pop shops and this is exactly what this place is. You can always count on this place for a bowl of hearty wonton noodles. This place smells so Asian and the food tastes so authentic that I feel like I am in China or Hong Kong. Everything here is pretty cheap, you can pretty much have a bowl of noodles, veggies, and even some BBQ pork for ~$10. Not exactly sanitary, but that's typical of Asian hole-in-the-wall places. Everyone who works here is an elder and they all work hard because the place is always packed, so don't forget to tip nicely!
author: Melody L.

description:
Here's a good hole-in-the-wall restaurant that serves great food for a cheap price. Don't expect much in the way of service, though. The first time I visited the place, my friends and I had to seat ourselves, wait about 15 minutes to order, and then leave on the table what we thought we owed for the food, plus tip, since we never received our bill. In my most recent visits, we were seated at a round table with a random customer and had to wait about 20 minutes to place our order.

Looking around, I can see the main problem is that the place is understaffed; you have one woman acting as the hostess, waitress, and cashier. She's not cute and she's never in a good mood. Most customers, however, don't mind the inattentive service and (sometimes) uncomfortable seating arrangements. 

People seemed to respond to the lack of service by being just a bit more aggressive. A regular once told me that I "have to pull her if [I] want something." Well, if you're comfortable with that unique brand of service dispensation, then you might wanna give this place a go. Be sure to order the Wun Tun Noodle in Soup. Yum.
author: Eddie B.

description:
Okay...so I'm was totally a newbie to this place and I had it figured out by observing people. The trick is to basically sit yourself anywhere where there's space. This place is an eat, go to the counter and pay, then leave place.

Fast service. Noodles came really quick. I ordered #20 the snow cabbage chicken? I think. and the bf ordered #12 szechuan noodle soup. 

I didn't think the noodles were that spectacular and the portions weren't that great for a noodle soup. Some might think it's a great price but there are definitely cheaper eats in the Chinatown.

Even though the noodle soups weren't impressive, the rice rolls looked really yummy though. I also think that the rice plates are more worth it than the noodle soups.
author: Jay Z.

description:
If there is only one item of food that my husband MUST eat every time we visit San Francisco, it would be a bowl of steaming Wun Tun / Shui Kau (Dumpling) noodle soup - he would even drive 6 hours from a camping trip just to tuck into one. This is definitely a perennial favorite for us and beats all of the high-brow, chi-chi Chinese establishments that have sprung out around the area, with sky high prices and overrated food laced with MSG.

The ambiance here is spartan, no frills, even a little dark and dingy, but don't let that detract from the quality of the food. If you like a spanking new, sterile looking environment, smiley service amd Americanized Chinese food, this  is not the place for you. If you appreciate tender, velvety smooth Wun Tuns and Dumplings cooked to perfection and bathed in a delicate broth that enhances their taste - you have come to the right place. It feels like I have been transported decades back to old Hong Kong whenever we eat here, so that helps to boost its authenticity somewhat.
author: S L.

description: This place has the most authentic seafood won tons probably in the whole NorCal. The egg noodles are always cooked al dente and not mushy as they sometimes get from non-won ton chefs.  This place knows what they are doing.  Best time to come here is during non-peak lunch hours or not it'll be a while before you get seating.  YUM!
author: WeR5 L.

description: I don't know what happened. Hon's used to be so delicious. My family and I would park far just to get a chance to have some hot wonton noodles. Me and my sister love slurping the wide rice noodles after gobbling the wontons. This place is the only one I know of that has a higher ratio of shrimp to meat. It's pretty much a hole in the wall so if you're not okay with washing your chopsticks in tea, don't bother coming here. I noticed the same workers have been here ever since I was 5 so I can tell you theyre a loyal bunch. They make the wontons in front of you and after the hot soup is poured over the noodles, the food comes in less than 1 minute. On busy days, you have to share tables :/
author: Victoria Y.

description: As others have mentioned, it's a great place to visit for some nostalgia of childhood lunches/dinners spent in Hon's in Vancouver or generally in little wonton shops. But it's also a great place to get a hot bowl of soupy noodles for under five bucks and leave satisfied.
author: Amy C.

description: I admit that I am not always the most sanitary person.  I have eaten food that I've dropped on the floor, if it's something worth retrieving.  However, I don't think that it's cool to do this at a place of business, right in front of everyone.  I was hunched up against the door, waiting for my takeout order, when the cashier/server spilled a bowl of won ton onto the dirty counter and the "sous chef" then proceeds to pick them up and dump them back into the pot.  Lovely.  I think I was the lucky recipient of these contaminated won tons, cuz now my stomach is growling in protest.  The won tons were tasty, but not worth a bout of diarrhea.  I will probably be running to the bathroom shortly.  Don't go in there for another 30 - 45 minutes.
author: Lisa C.

description: Yum. This place reminds me of home. It's inexpensive but the portions are pretty small. Then again, I'm a small girl and I don't eat that much to get full anyway. I usually order the #1 with the Ho Fun noodles, sometimes with some vegetable choy on the side when I'm feeling a little more hungry. On a weekday, it could get a little crowded around noon so better to go after 1pm. The place is also small so you'll probably have to share a table too.
author: Anita W.

description: Classic no bullshit HK style noodle shop. Cheap prices, HK portions (not big), it even comes with an iconic "mein" sign at the front. Noodles cooked perfectly al dente. Best I've had in town. Yum yum yum.
author: Faffy L.

description: Wonton soup is tasty and they have hard to find dishes like pigs feet on rice which is really good.
author: Anthony B.

description: This place has good noodles!!  I love their Spicy Beef Tendon Noodle, I eat that every time I go to SF area.  I'm like addicted to that dish. Very small & simple place. Cleanness is alright. The dish is very small, lots of people especially men need to eat 2 bowls of noodles. Their Veggie with oyster sauce is small but very yummy as well. The steam veggie with oyster sauce is a must if  you eat there.  I never been to their restroom because it's kind of in the kitchen area.
author: Win C.

description: Chaotic, disorganized and so so food.  It's like being transported to the times when things took a long time and didn't taste as good, but are somewhat amusing to hang out; the head cashier/ waitress seems to order all the old men around and the staff wander by mindlessly.  The oh-so-popular wonton noodle soup is slightly better than ramen/ frozen, but most of the dumplings were pretty bland.  The noodles were kinda hard, perhaps that is normal.  Cheap, but what's the point if you're waiting around to get filled up?  I finished and filled up on dumplings somewhere else.
author: Tony N.

description:
Don't FXXX with Hon's.
It's a hard core Chinese.
Just don't FXXX with him.

There was a waitress drove me crazy because her voice.
She was chatting with other waitress right behind me but her voice was just like after you suck in whole air out of a balloon.

Don't FXXX with Hon's.
It's a hard core Chinese.
Just don't FXXX with him.

I was here so many time before.
I remember the Wun-Tun Noodle soup was $1.75 when a pack of cigaret was 75 cents. Muni and a cup of coffee were a quater.

Don't FXXX with Hon's.
It's a hard core Chinese.
Just don't FXXX with him.

There are so many things changed last 30 years.
There was no cell phone.
There was no CD, DVD.
There was no i-pod.
There was no Wi Fi.
There was no hybrid.
But there was Hon's Wun Tun, so as MacDonald and KFC.

Don't FXXX with Hon's.
It's a hard core Chinese.
Just don't FXXX with him.

It seems like nothing has been changed except the price.
Same decor, same flavor, same wun tun, same noodle, same soup.
And same menu!
Hon's has more than Wun-Tun too!

1. wun-tun noodle soup, 3.95
2. noodle in soup, 3.25
3. wun-tun in soup, 4.10
4. stewed brisket of beef & rice noodle in soup, 4.30
5. stewed brisket of beef noodle in soup, 4.30
6. oyster sauce w/ noodle, 410
7. stewed brisket of beef & wun-tun, 4.30
8. stewed shrimp dumpling & wun-tun noodle in soup, 4.20
9. stewed shrimp dumpling in soup, 4.30
10. stewed brisket of beef & wun-tun noodle in soup, 4.95
11. stewed brisket of beef with rice, 4.95
12. szechuan sauce & noodle (hot), 4.30
13. oyster sauce & vegetable ( broccoli or lettuce), 4.10
14. stewed brisket w/ special sauce, 6.40
15. wun-tun & double noodle in soup, 4.95
16. pig's feet w/ rice ( noodle, or rice noodle) 4.95 
17. curry beef w/ rice, 5.80
18. curry beef, 6.95
19. pig's feet, 6.40
20. shanghai noodle w/ meat, 4.30
21. bbq pork noodle ( or rice noodle) in soup, 4.60
22. bbq pork on rice, 4.95
23. bbq pork & wun-tun noodle in soup, 5.80
24. bbq pork & wun-tun in soup. 5.80
25. stewed brisket of beef w/ noodle, 5.59
26. ngow jaap ( beef organ) w/ sauce, 6.40
27. ngow jaap (beef organ) & noodle in soup, 4.30
28. beef tendon w/ special sauce (hot), 6.95
29. beef tendon w/ noodle (hot), 5.25
30. pig's feet & noodle in soup, 4.60
31. fish ball & noodle ( or rice noodle) in soup, 4.60
32. rice, 0.92
33. soup, 0.74
34. soda, 1.20
35. red bean in soup (sweet), 1.57
36. rice roll, 1.95

I don't know how they decide the pricing..... rice 0.92, soup 0.74, red bean in soup (sweet), 1.57
What the FXXX?
But,.....exact same menu for last 30 years!
That's something.
Don't FXXX with Hon's.

Please note number 15. wun-tun & double noodle in soup, 4.95
It is double noodle!
This item should be number 2, don't you think?
And the beef tendon taste reminded me of "Gei-kan", canned whale meat. I grew up with whale meat, it was very cheap & popular red meat in 60's in Japan.

#-19, Pig's feet, written as "Pig's(boar) hand" in Chinese, the other side of the English menu.

By the way, There is a peep show at the next corner.
How handy is this?
I thought it's a great combo, wun-tun & porn.
But, after I got Hon's Wun-Tun, I said, " FXXX the peep show."
I might throw-up wun-tun watching it.
I could not go in.
The wun-tun satisfied me very well, I didn't need anything else but a nap.
author: Nobu K.

description:
situated in the front window, the chef is easily viewable to all incoming patrons.  his eyes say it all:  "i keeps it real".

this is a no-frills, back-to-the-basics won ton noodle house.   you will not find fancy decor, you will not get personable service and you will not receive a menu filled with pages and pages of different cuisine.

you *WILL* get fresh, tasty noodle soup stocked with your favorite meat toppings.  i highly recommend the beef brisket.  oh, and the won tons themselves are fantastic.

each serving is cheap, $3-5, but are relatively small.  perfect for lunch, although a heavy eater could easily finish two bowls.

working in the FIDI, i see myself coming here on a weekly basis.
author: vuForce Fresh n.

description:
Best wonton in SF.
Best noodles in SF.
Best beef brisket in SF.
You must try this place. Period.
author: Rich C.

description:
I give this 4* for THE FOOD. I loooove their "ja jeung mein"! It's soooo delicious. Yes, you don't get service. Yes the lady cashier NEVER smiles. I"ve been a customer for 20 yrs. I remember onen time when I was in hs the nasty lady insisted I gave the exact amount in bills and coins which i didn't. I gave her a $10 bil. Anyway, after some fussing, she finally gave me my rightful change. Rude and irritating. I think she's one of the bosses. She also gets a bit verbal with some of the employees.

But their mein is out of the best. It's not soggy and made just right. Yes, I wish t hey were open Sundays and holidays but hey they cater to the Financial District. I wish it was easy to park there. If it were, I'd definitely go  more often. Yes, portions are very small. You'd have to eat at least 2 bowls.
author: Tiffany W.

description:
Simply the best wonton noodle house in the City, no ifs, ands, or buts. They make their own everything from scratch. If you spend enough time here, you'll see that other restaurants buy their goddamn wonton noodles from this place. Yes, Hon's sells their own noodles to other restaurants without fear of losing business. Take that, suckers! You can even purchase Hon's products from Asian grocers or supermarkets like Ranch 99 [look for Hon's on the label]. The rice rolls at Hon's are also available all over the City in packaged form, but they're obviously not as good as the ones you get freshly made at the wonton house. And if rice rolls are what you dig, you better get there early because they always sell out. The rice rolls come with a few sauces and I've gotta say that the chili hot sauce is packin' some heat.

Con: Hon's closes on Sundays, traditionally the busiest day of the week. What the hell is wrong with them?

Pro: I know -- it's because their wontons are just the right size, with a soft wrapper and not too much meat. The noodles are not too smushy and the soup is just begging you to finish it all.

Con: Obviously, the service and setup leaves much to be desired. The waitstaff treats you like shit if you speak Chinese. 

Pro: So if you know Chinese, I suggest you speak English so they will treat you better.
author: Ken L.

description:
c'mon ya'll.  

I relied on my fellow yelpers' 4-star rating on this place, but was pretty disappointed.  I've had better won-ton soup at a poker table from the Oak's Card Club's kitchen in emeryville!

portions are small (even the won tons are tiny, not just the bowl they're in).  but, i guess that's why its so cheap.
author: dan a.

description:
i grew up around the North Beach/Chinatown area.  this is a old establishment known by most Chinese that want good & inexpensive food.  what makes this place great is the soup base that they use in the noodle or wonton soups.  it is a genuine meat stock ole chinese style/KFC secret receipe.  they will kill you if you try to infiltrate and learn the secret. kidding

not a first date type of place unless you want to loose her quick. small seating areas, often crammed with people.  this is a busy busy place. if your dining alone don't be surprised if you're  asked to share a table with a bunch of strangers.

watch out if  you use the stairway to the toilets. slippery there and once in the bathroom, the floors are wet.  Falling and killing yourself=no pay for them.  Mgmt  will be hella pissed dragging your ass up the stairs, around the tables and around a of  sea of chinese patrons.  

on the way back up, go thru the kitchen fast cause you might not like the food handling methods.

service is the usual old school chinese resturant, 

1-so so service
2-they want you to eat and get the hell out.--it's all about volume.  maybe that's were the old joke about chinese sex/foreplay arose.  i can say this shit because i'm chinese.  i know it ain't true but these places don't help the image much.
3-shitty take-out packing-like most chinese resturant.  don't they know we have to make it home.

good flavor, good price, hard parking but worth the trip if your in the area.
try the wonton with shrimp egg noodles & beef stew.  i like a side of chinese brocoli with oyster sauce.

hopefully i didn't piss them off or i might find a roach in my soup....awww  hell, it's just protein anyway.  enjoy
author: Dan W.

description: One of the best wonton places in SF . Their wonton  is cooked to perfection and each bite full of flavor . Just thinking about it makes my mouth water hahah .The noodles that go with it are good too .. they don't get tiring like wonton noodle soups you get from other places . The soup was good as well . So basically I ended up finishing the whole thing and left the container empty lol . Best of all , it's very cheap .. 3$ something for  a wonton noodle soup !! Does it get any better ?? This place is definitely worth a visit =]
author: Eileen L.

description: wow! it's been a while since i've been here. their noodles and soups were one of a kind a while back. now many have imitated and probably improved upon their recipe. beef brisket won ton noodle was my fav. some day, i will return to savor some fond memories.
author: Victor G.

description: OK, Another place Debita took me. At first we walked in and I was like "I'm going to get Sooooo sick" but of course I be wrong. This place was fantastic. Great soup and noodles and cheap. Got a side of broccoli with oyster sauce and shrimp won ton soup. I'm gonna keep going back. Another cold day food that I will always eat.
author: Tony P.

description: Yes they are rude and no you don't get service there and even though the restaurant is the size of a closet....you still can't seem to get there attention. On the flip side, prices are great and the won ton is pretty good. I prefer the dumplings over the won ton but m bf loves the won ton. It's worth trying it if you are in the area.
author: Diane M.

description: 5 STARS.  Ok so...I've been coming to Hon's since the early 80's (yep, some of yall weren't even conceived yet!)...yes, that's how authentic this yummy hole-in-the-wall is.  You either LOVE it or HATE it.  I LOVE IT.  I just show up, order by #, shut up and swallow with a big smile!  Aaaahhh...gotta love slurpping the heck out of #9 shrimp dumplings with double rice noodles with the hard-to-find Koon Chun red vinegar and housemade chili to inhale my soup with.  Don't forget to try out the sides: rice rolls and chinese broccoli!  Can we say YUMMMM!?!!!  Overall rating:  try it - it's addicting.  Oh and it's CASH ONLY.
author: Carmel D.

description: Great won-tons, made the right way.  Their noodle soup with braised beef is spectacular.  I'm not sure how non-Chinese speakers will be able to get by, though.  Thankfully, they have a limited menu :-)
author: Serena Y.

description:
beef stew with wonton noodles for really cheap.  sure the bowls of noodles are small, so for your average hungry guy, one bowl certainly isn't enough.

but the beef stew (ngao lam) was quite good, and the wonton is super good.  though the wontons are smaller than what you'll find at other places, they actually dice the shrimp (like oldschool cantonese / more authentic) than the lazy places who just throw the whole damn shrimp inside.

definitely a steal, since the bowls cost less than $5.  

also, when you come for a financial district lunch, you will have to wait a bit.
author: Jason J.

description: Really good food for very cheap, though I'd rather pay a little more and get a larger portion.
author: jeremy m.

description: This place is small and it doesn't look that clean.  Don't expect the servers to do anything more than taking your order and your money for the bill.  But i must say their noodles are really good.  I always order the wonton and brisket noodles.  The portion is small, I can easily eat two bowls for lunch.  The pig feet noodles is another yummy choice if cholesterol is not a concern for you.  For rice plates I love the curry beef with rice.  Again, order two if you are kinda hungry.  It's nothing fancy there, but I'm happy just to go in and out for a quick yummy meal.
author: Tadaa T.

description:
*seats myself at counter after initial confusion about how seating vs. takeout works*
*Old Chinese woman (OCW) walks over to me*
OCW: Order?
Me: Oh, um, can I see the menu please?
*sees OCW furrows her brow*
*gets feeling that this is an unusual question to ask*
OCW: Mah-nu? 
*receives menu from OCW*
*I make my selection reasonably quickly: Barbeque pork with wonton, no noodles*
*waits for OCW to take my order*
*waits*
*waits*
....
*finally catches eye of OCW across kitchen*
Me: Can I place my order?
OCW: Yes
Me: Um
OCW: Numb-ah?
*realizes she has no intention of walking over to me*
Me: uh, twenty four
*gets my food in about five minutes*
 
The food here is good, though not particularly impresive. The restaurant and the set up did make me feel like I was in China, which was kind of nostalgically nice. While the broth is indeed very savory, the wontons served here are the very dense meat-filled kind. I prefer my wonton soft, with a bit of meat and mostly wrapper. It was nice to eat char siu since I haven't had any in awhile, but it was on the blander side.
author: Ada T.

description: I've been coming here since I was a little kid and it's still my fav wonton noodle place.  the wonton is the perfect bite size and noodles arent the soft and soggy kind.  I just wish they opened on Sundays.
author: Jen L.

description: So since my gastrointestinal fortitude was left in shambles after last night's snack at an undisclosed Indian restaurant, my stomach has been begging me for something to restore it to its prior glory... or at least to fill it with something that would really hit the spot. I knew I needed something light and soupy, and instantly thought of Hon's Wun Tun House a few blocks from my office. Ordered, as always it seems, #23: BBQ Pork and Wun Tun Noodle in Soup (classic, simple flavors) and a side of Chinese Broccoli with Oyster Sauce... Got back to the office, devoured it, and now my stomach can rest easy once again. Thanks Hon's!!
author: Alex C.

description: Good wonton noodles here, but I don't know if its worth the bad service. This is literally a whole in the wall. You go in and the place is small and dirty. It gets crowded though so you might have to sit with a stranger. Worse possible service here, but hey, it's cheap. Wonton noodles for less than $4. However, I'd rather toss in another dollar and go to the New Hong Kong Menu restaurant a couple blocks away and get a bowl three times bigger (with bokchoy) and friendlier service. (Plus free soup and dessert.)
author: Jonas T.

description: I've grown up on Hons Wun Tun noodles.  When I was a youngun (basically from age 3 to age 17), you could find me at Hons for lunch with my parents on the weekends.   They also have a good curry beef over rice.  They are now closed on Sundays but open every other day of the week.  They have about 9 tables and 6 or 7 counter spaces on the main level and on occasion, they will open the upper level but beware, it gets really hot up there on the upper floor.
author: Herb C.

description: Tasty wonton soup with 10 tasty small pork+shrimp won-tons for $4.10, leaving you plenty of stomach room and cash left over for other stuff.
author: Rob T.

description: Bad attitude. check. Cheap. check. Fast. check. Somewhat filthy. check. This place meets all four criteria of a hole-in-the-wall Chinese restaurant; and it's pretty darn good. A bowl of won ton noodle soup runs about $4. The place is always packed with Chinese during lunch time. You have to share tables with strangers. And they don't ask you for permission before putting them next to you. It's hard to flag anyone down after you've ordered (to ask for something else, for example). And the place is not clean at all... but it is fast and it's yummy. So if I just want bowl of tasty won tons on a cold day before a meeting in 30 minutes, this is where I come.
author: Yuan W.

description: This is my favorite noodle shop. I've been going here for about 5 years, and I hope to grow old eating the noodles here. The place is super greasy spoon small, and most everything on the menus is under $5 a plate or bowl. Great food at a great price. cash only, pay at the register when you leave, no thrills services. Highly Recommended!
author: Paul V.

description: Uh OH there are WAY too many people reviewing my secret won ton supplier. Their soup is soo good as is the curry with beef. MMM. Fatty all around with that delicious potato in it. The staff is not friendly and the place has no charm but it's all in the food.
author: Cindy F.

description: BEST WONTON PLACE EVER, I can't thinking of a better place beside my own home. This is the only place I ever ate at alone because it was so good that I didn't care I was by myself. The dishes were small but the noodles were great and meat like won ton and beef stew were perfect. People expecting fine dining are going to be disappointed because this is the perfect Chinese home cooking.
author: Cameron H.

description: the noodle is good but dont expect fancy place :)
author: Pikachu P.

description: We came here after the lunch hour, and perhaps the dim sum we got on the way filled us up, but the food wasn't spectacular-slurptacular. I got the standard wonton noodles. For less than 4 dollars, I'd come here again, but i don't think I will be craving it.
author: Jenny M.

description: This place is great but the prices have gone up. The food is tasty however they past health inspection is still beyond me. The owner is not always the friendliest but the staff does take your order and get you out on time.
author: Nicholas C.

description: As an Asian obsessed with the best wonton noodle shops in Hong Kong, I have very high standards for this dish.  I have come to the realization that Hon's is probably the closest you can get to premium won ton noodles in San Francisco. The famous Mak's Noodle in Hong Kong is the platinum edition: Hon's is the silver standard. Still haven't found the gold standard yet, but silver is pretty good this side of the Pacific.
author: Pink P.

description: I love this place! I've been going at least once a week (to go) for the past month. It's very small, the lady at the register is pretty scary, but I just do it "soup nazi" style. Just pick  a menu number, pay, and step aside.! best wun tun noodle soup ever!
author: Mina T.

description: This place is usually packed during lunch hours -- but it's not hard to see why.   It has that "Chinatown" feeling with their fast service.  I've only had the wonton mien and chinese broccoli (which was cooked just right).  Even though the wonton mien portion is small, it's hard to complain when it's $4.75.  I wish they had an "extra noodle" add-on option.
author: Sophie K.

description: I remember coming here with my dad when I was little and the place hasn't change in 20+ years.  I did notice a new awning though, so they've made some improvements to the decor.  :)  My favorite is their wonton beef stew (with miscellaneous parts) noodle soup.  I'm not sure if its on the menu, but its the only one I order.  Their noodles are always cooked al dente, which can only be done with their freshly made noodles.  The broth is chock full of flavor and the braised stew is so tender.  Yes, the bowls are small so I usually order two bowls back to back, but for under $3/bowl, its worth it.  Oh, and don't forget to add a little bit of hot chili oil.  It makes all the difference.
author: Wendy L.

description: Wonton noodle soup was my favorite growing up in Guang Zhou. When we visited SF, I was determined to find some good ones. Though not as good as the ones in HK or Guang Zhou, it's pretty close and the best I've had in Boston, NY and SF. They make the noodles themselves and it's cooked al dente like it should be. The portions are not big but just enough for me. I also visited Sam Wo for a different taste of wonton noodle soup and that was a disaster. I went back to Hons the next day so I can end my noodle soup quest on a positive note.
author: Cris W.

description: i've been a fan of hon's since i was 5yrs old... so i have to give it a 5 star review base on food, the noodles here are good not over cooked.. the curry beef stew is Good and yummy... i see all the reviewers saying "it's dirty" and they "need to clean very badly" honestly you guys need to remember where u are, in chinatown 95% of the places are dirty..
author: jonathan h.

description:
yuuuuuuuuuummmmmmmmmmm!!!!!!!!!

definitely a down and dirty hole in the wall joint, but they serve simple but good won ton mein.  the noodles are nice and firm and the broth is clear and tasty.  a big bowl of noodles, plus a side of chinese brocolli?  can't beat it.

oh, and you can buy their noodles, won ton and broth separately to take home so you can make it later yourself.
author: Reina M.

description: The soup here is delicious, and always hot. There are only a few tables, so I always get mine to go and privately enjoy my little bowl of bliss. My favorite is the BBQ pork and greens with wun tun noodles in broth, the dumplings are good too though. A delicious lunch for under five dollars - you can't beat that!
author: Rhiana M.

description:
straight up good won ton noodle soup place!  they have some other rice plates also, but really known for the wontons.  

it's very cramped inside this little establishment and don't expect much service.  they serve you the food and when you're done you pay at the counter.  

def worth a trip to hon's wun tun house!
author: Wendy S.

description: I had a killer bowl of noodles and won-tons for $3.80!!! $3.80!!!! $3.80!!!!  kind of stinky but super good!  I can't get enough.
author: Chard M.

description: Delicious inexpensive noodle soups, rice plates, beef stew, and curry when you want good food quick or on the go.  I work 1 block away from this place and frequent here weekly with coworkers.  When it's real crowded during lunch time, which seems to be daily, it isn't uncommon to share a table with others.
author: A W.

description:
i've been here like..what? 2395823957235981230598 times?

I always, always, came here with my dad. We both love this place to death. The taste is unbelievable. UNBELIEVABLE! No other place in Chinatown, or in the USA will compare to THIS place! And maybe even HK, too! I went back to HK once and ate at a place and ordered their wun tun, hoping it would be even BETTER than this place. but it wasn't.

I always order the original wun tun noodle soup. The wun tun is BEYOND WORDS. The flavor is seriously indescribable. The hint of sesame oil in it really seals the deal on all the delicious flavors/ingredients in it. And the SOUP! What do they put in it? I always drink my bowl clean. haha.

Go get some NOW. NOW!
author: Betty T.

description:
Literally a hole in the wall!  This is a kind of place where you just "close your eyes" and eat the yummy wonton mein. 

Angela N.'s review about the noodles /wonton sitting in bowls is correct. But, once you get pass all that, the wonton noodles are good. (Noodles are not overcooked.  Portions are just right.  )  This is total comfort food, esp. on a cold rainy workday when you need to eat and run back to the office and work. This lunch choice will not put  you to sleep and will not bust your budget. 

Weekday lunch crowd consists of chinatown shoppers and FiDi workers. It gets pretty packed and you might have to share tables  if you don't come early.
author: vernice l.

description: This place is one of them places you'll dislike more every time you go. In the beginning everything looks great. I mean you walk by the restaurant looking in and see a ton of people eating, so it must be good right? The you see how they make the noodle right in-front of you, so it must be super fresh right? Finally you look at their menu, O, wonton noodle just 5 bucks or less, cheap right? NO, NO, NO. First of all, the bowl of wonton noodle that only cost 5 bucks can only feed a little girl, I would say for a healthy lunch, a normal person will need two bowls. So they're not cheap that's forsure.
author: Wes Z.

description: Maybe my fave comfort food place in the city, if not the entire state. First came here in '97 upon seeing it full of Asian folks (good sign for good Chinese food). No-frills place with quick service, noodles made fresh, and the same folks working there all these years. Like home cooking, in spite of the fact that my family's Italian. Beef brisket can be a bit gristly, greater veg selection would be good; hence 4/5 stars. Call it 4-7/8 stars.
author: Stephen S.

description: Another hole-in-the-wall gem down in Financial District!  If you don't mind the old-acclectic decor, the abrupt-short service, and the non-air conditioned room....then DIVE right into some truly good authentic HK style wonton noodle soup!  I kid you not, this is a TRUE example of an authentic wonton joint in HK!  For about $3.50 for a good sized bowl....this gives me the true strenght to bear all those cold windy SF days!
author: Alice T.

description: The inside is not a fancy 4 star restaurant, the wait staff is hurried. But oh how delicious is their ngow jap wonton noodles?! A little piece of heaven in my mouth. The noodles and wontons taste absolutely delicious with tons of vinegar and hot sauce. I use almost the entire bottle of vinegar on one bowl of noodles. Just the thought of it is making my mouth water...........
author: ann t.

description: Service was fast and the food was delicious.  I haven't had wonton soup like this since my mom made her wontons.  Each bite was very flavorful.  The prices were cheap.  I ordered the number one and my frined ordered the number three.  I will definitely make it there on a regular basis.  It's a good sign when all the locals are seen eating here. I highly recommend it for those cold days when you don't want to spend too much for lunch or dinner.  It's a hole in the wall place but these types of places are always the best food finds.  My tummy was warm inside after having a heaping bowl of wonton and noodles.  The broth is flavorful but not overpowering.  I'll be telling family and friends about this place.
author: Nancy K.

description:
I don't make it downtown as often anymore, but when I do, I like to get take out from Hon's Wun Tun House.  My family and I love their curry beef wun tun noodle soup, although instead of beef tendon, I wished they used just regular tender beef.  It's still very good though; especially on a cold day.

So after I ordered, I paid for my take out and told them that I had to quickly park in the yellow zone out front and I explained to them that I would just sit in my car and would be right back to pick up my order in about 5 mins.  (didn't want to take a chance in getting a ticket - those meter maids are sneaky!)  I was in the car and it wasn't even a few minutes and the little old Chinese man came out and brought my food to me.  It was above and beyond service for such a busy and small restaurant!  I picked up their "to go menu" for next time!
author: Agnes P.

description: I don't understand how this place can have 4 stars because I just had a very unhappy and unsatisfying meal. I was curious about this wun tun noodle place because I read in Yelp that it is a chain from Vancouver. That's the ONLY reason why I am curious to try it. The staffs are older Chinese people (which usually a good sign). They have a board listing take out prices for their wun tun noodle, wun tun skin, peanut butter, almond paste and etc; which is another good sign if people buy their product to cook at home. The wun tun was not cook right, too raw for my taste. The beef tendon was full of fat with THIN layer of meat, if you can even find it. My friend ordered the pork hand noodle, which turn out to be super bad to. There was no meat at all, only thick chunk of skin. Look and taste nasty. The only decent dish we ordered was the beef tendon curry. Needless to say, I do not recommend this place and will not come back even if someone is buying. Sorry, I have high expectations towards wun tun noodle.
author: Ervinna L.

description: Enh it's ok. It's cheap, but the food is on the more bland side. Had to add hot sauce to bring flavor to my soup. I'd go back if I was sick, but I've had other good wonton noodle soups even in Chinatown. (A better one is outside of Chinatown in the Outer Sunset - Ming Tai)
author: Jeannette L.

description: definitely the best won ton place in the city and probably the closest you're going to get to the real deal in hong kong.  i usually get the beef brisket won ton noodle soup.  i have been coming here since the mid 80's.  nothing much has changed....same expressionless service but the food is good so i'm good.
author: Leon C.

description: for a cheap lunch, wun tun is the spot to hit up.  i've had better soup in chinatown but for my co-workers and i, this is a nice default for a real cheap lunch.  the broth itself is hit or miss but the actual wontons are pretty nice.  the bbq pork is nice and so is the brisket but i wasn't to fond of the curry beef.  the tendon is OK too for those who like that type of stuff.  one thing to keep in mind is that service isn't the quickest and they could care less if you haven't gotten any water yet!
author: Swarup B.

description: I feel this spot's wun tun soup has received sufficient and accurate coverage in previous reviews (to reiterate - it is the shit), so I will say only this - Hon's has the Chinese curry beef and rice game on lock like a motherfucker. There is nowhere else in Chinatown I will go for my meat and potatoes. Period. When I'm feeling particularly gluttonous (like maybe half the time) I'll add on a side of spicy tendon, which I should mention is also hella on point. This combo offers the added benefit of letting you leave secure in the knowledge that, at about $11, you have balled harder than 95% of the patrons that day. A piece of advice if you're hungry - don't sit down and wait for someone to take your order unless you brought a snack with you. Just walk up to the counter and let everyone back there know what you're in the mood for (which, in case you've skipped to this segment of the review, should be the curry beef and rice with a side of tendon) until you see someone write it down.
author: Dil D.

description: hon's wun tun house is your typical chinese hole in the wall noodle joint...  there's not much glam or glitter about this place...  the bowls of soup are litterally prepared next to the front door...  the place gets pretty packed on the weekdays around lunch time, so i usually get my order to go...   their won ton noodle is good (the won tons are kinda small), their beef brisket noodle soup is good, their beef tendon noodle soup is good...  the food is really cheap here (around the $5 range)...  the people who work there do not speak english well and are pretty rude...  the only advantage for the chinese speaking patrons is you can communicate with the staff, BUT regardless they're rude to everyone (at least they don't discriminate)...  they don't take plastic or checks, it's a cash only restaurant...  h-100...
author: Herb F.

description: NEVER visit an Asian owned establishment and expect good service or good decor.  Being Asian, I can tell you this piece of advice with frank honesty.  With that said, GO to Hon's if you want a hot bowl of wontons swimming in fragrant broth, delish egg noodles, and fresh green onions.  This place actually has chili pepper sauce that's, get this - HOT!!   For me and the boyfriend, our lunch bill came to just under $10 - another reason why Hon's is well worth a visit.  Hon's also knows something about portion control (think "2008 New Year's diet resolution").  This helps when you're eating a carb-loaded meal that could easily induce a 3 hour food coma if you overeat.
author: Jennifer H.

description: I had searched some restaurants to eat at in Chinatown yesterday, and decided to give this place a try. Its really small, but cute and clean. My friend saw they had a 90 + for their inspection (pretty good for Chinatown ay..) Their use shrimp to make their won tons (YAY! cause I don't eat the pork ones). The noodle was chewy and delicious. The soup could've been more flavorful, but only if you're an MSG addict like me. My friend was like, "I could eat 4 of these" because it was a really small bowl. Okay, so maybe I can't get full off one, so we ordered one won ton noodles each and then an order of just won tons to share. The won ton noodles had 5 won tons in them and the order of just won tons had a dozen. We were good to go afterwards. And plus, its under $4 for the won ton noodles, so its worth its price already. The staff are nice and friendly. And our food came out in less than 5 minutes!
author: Elaine H.

description: minus 1 star, for being rude and not apologizing or even compensating the customer, after messing up their order.  that leaves a bad taste in my mouth.
author: Pickle R.

description: Came to the city for business trip and my office just few blocks away, so I've decided to come here for lunch with high hopes after reading all these good reviews on yelp. Ordered Wonton and beef tenders noodle and rice roll. The food weren't bad but certainly nothing spectacular.. I certainly have had better Wonton and rice roll. The menu says it's shrimp wonton but i didn't taste any shrimp in mine, which is kind of disappointed. Another thing that stunned me is that after I order rice roll, the guys took out a plate of rice roll from nowhere and heat it up in the microwave. hum... ok?! On the up side, cheap food and quick service. Went in and out in about 20 mins for less thann $9.
author: Peggy T.

description: The service here is spotty and it doesn't look clean.  The wonton noodle soup is ok, but I've had better wontons from Kingdom of Dumpling.  The portions are on the small side too.  I tried the pig foot here once and it was cold and tough.  The food is pretty cheap but there are lots of better places nearby.
author: Raz R.

description: No need to over-analyze it. No need to deflect one's personal issues upon it. It's simply @#$$^$#@ good. Period. Now shut your trap and slurp your noodles.
author: S L.

description: Reading all the reviews on here, makes me want to re-visit again. The wonton noodle soup here always stays with me. Its simple, the broth and wonton fillings are a natural sweetness of from the pork and shrimp. If you want more out of a meal, you order other things on the menu - they have the gailan w/ oyster sauce dish, a good veggie addition, and other sides, like beef stew or curry, etc. The food here is not stellar, but its at least equivalent or better than most won ton noodle houses AND with price at $3.60.. thats why its so special. I havent seen anyone mention the cold red bean soup dessert here, but its probably one of the best i've had. I dont know how they get the red beans to be so soft and smooth, but they do, and its worth coming here for. There's a bit of a orange citrus flavor to it, becuase they use dried orange peels in the soup - very nice touch. clean and refreshing taste!
author: Mai T.

description:
When it comes to cantonese-style wontons, Hon's has the best in the Bay Area (not that I've tried every single wonton restaurant by I have tried many of them).  The wontons are packed with flavors which includes a "secret" ingredient of deep fried dried (yes, sun-dried and deep fried) filet of sole.  It may be an acquired taste -- but if you like stinky cheeses, you'll love it -- but I am told is a very traditional ingredient in the filling from the Chaozhou seaport of the province of Canton.  What I like about them is that Hon's stuck with tradition.  Their wontons are not on steroids, i.e. not golf ball sized things (that will gag you) filled with whole pieces of shrimps just under the wrappers so you can see them with absolutely no taste because the shrimps have been bleached with borax for their "crunchiness".  Golf-ball sized wontons in my experience are for people who don't taste their foods.  They don't know a good wonton from a bland ball made more for the eyes than the palate.  Anyways, I digress but I take my wonton seriously.

 The service here is OK.  But for a wonton eatery this is just what one should expect.  What, no table cloth?
author: Dave M.

description: Meh, it's ok.  I went out of my way to try this place because of what I'd heard.  Well, it's great for a quick stop if you're craving some wonton soup, but I wouldn't head to C-town just to hit up this joint.  It's cheap, but the portions are also small.  Restaurant is rather filthy, so prepare for that.  All in all, a fairly authentic hong kong won ton noodle house experience in SF, but not worth the effort to get there.
author: Chris C.

description: I've heard that few restaurants in Chinatown are good but this was a really BAD experience. I read the reviews and ordered won ton noodle. First of all, the portion is really small. The won tons are tiny! And the worst thing was that I could not even find a piece of shrimp in it. What really upset me was the waitress' attitude. She walked away before we finished our ordering, and act like she hates every single customer. I'd never eat at this restaurant again. Period.
author: Keane L.

description: It looks crappy but the won tons are good there. I don't order anything else besides their won ton. I can comment that the won tons are fresh and so are their noodles. If you come here during lunch, be prepared to sit next to a stranger.
author: bob k.

description: man, i haven't had the beef curry in a few months and was really looking forward to it.  went in, got it to go, the price went up. to be expected. got it back to the office, opened it up and instantly knew it wasn't the same.  why?  the soup is watery.  what made it so good before was the thick curry soup.  the taste is till good, but it's not what you really want.  come on, curry, not thin liquid soup.  too bad.
author: Food Is L.

description:
obviously, you can't expect great customer service in chinatown.  but hon's is ridiculous.  i ordered won ton with rice noodle soup to go; when i got back to work, i untied the bag to find wheat/egg noodles with no won ton.  so i had to go all the way back to hon's to return the incorrect order.  a lady that worked there had this rude attitude like it was my fault, even though the other lady that took my order before knew she gave me the wrong order and tried to explain it to the other woman.  by this point, i lost my appetite for won ton and just wanted my money back - they hadn't started remaking my soup yet.  but the mean lady wouldn't give me a refund, because you know how complicated and hi-tech their cash register is....NOT.  apparently, it was my fault for walking away from the restaurant too fast for them to catch up to me.  so they remade my soup the correct way, and i tried to look past everything and enjoy the won ton noodle soup, but their food is too mediocre to make up for the bad service and horrible manners; i had to get a 2nd lunch of canned tomato soup to get the disgusting taste of hon's out of my mouth.

people get orders wrong all the time, which is fine, BUT HON'S NEVER SAID SORRY!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!  never going back there again; no matter how cold it is, or how uncomfortable my high heeled work shoes are, i'm walking the extra blocks to go to washington bakery for noodle soup.
author: Katniss B.
